Noah tries to keep them out. Devil says that either the flies go in or he does. Noah chooses the lesser of two evils. Later the devil slips in nevertheless.

First one to succeed may eat other. Hare loses.
Usually told of hoopoe and bittern.
The ancient animal cries out in difficulty. The present animal has the same cry.
The ancient animal loses something. Its descendants are forever seeking for the lost object. This explains the characteristic bearing of certain animals.

Bat brought money, bush put on clothes, and diver brought leather. All shipwrecked. Diver is looking for his leather. Bush looks for his clothers and holds fast to all passers-by. Bat is abroad only at night to escape creditors.

DESCRIPTION: Apparently senseless remarks (or acts) interpreted figuratively prove wise.

Prince sends servant to clever girl with a round tart, thirty cakes, and a capon, and asks her if it is full moon and the thirtieth of the month and if the cock has crowed in the evening. She replies that it is not full moon, that it is the fifteenth of the month, and that the capon has gone to the mill; but that the prince should spare the pheasant for the partridge's sake. She thus shows him that the servant has stolen half the tart, half of the cakes, and the capon.
This is properly understood as, how many helpers he had, and answered by lifting ten fingers.

DESCRIPTION: In famine all old men are ordered killed. One man hides his father. When all goes wrong in the hands of the young rulers, the old man comes forth, performs assigned tasks, and aids with his wisdom.
If one goes toward it, it flees; if one turns his back on it, it follows and at times catches up with one.
Holy man prays, "May God bless everything here that is good but cause to disappear all that is bad." Everything disappears.

REFERENCES: Icelandic, India, Indonesian, Irish myth, Jewish
DESCRIPTION: Counsel proved wise by experience.
Message is cryptic, but is finally made clear.

Nobleman gives fool a present; he is to give it to no one who is not a greater fool. Master is dying; doctor tells fool that master is going to take long journey. Since master is making no preparation, fool gives him the present. Master thus brought to repentance.
Fool says he does not want to go to heaven for he wants to stay with his master, who everyone says is going to hell. Master repents.
Man in dream willing to receive sacrament from unworthy priest.
Mother shown in Hell; father in Heaven.
Rules wisely.
He tries to buy them. He finally learns that advice was to marry a clever girl.
(Odin.)

(Sibylline). Nine books first offered at certain price. Finally after this is refused and the owner throws six of them into the fire, the king pays the same price for three of them. Finds them filled with wisdom.
Unjust judge skinned and his skin stretched over a footstool kept in the presence of judges, so as to remind them to be just.
This advice given hero by helpful horse.
That man has not what he wishes to have.
That all joys are mixed with sorrow.
That all evil and hypocrisy will have an end.
That those who are most respected are the biggest fools.
That those who speak of spiritual matters are usually the most depraved.
That man lives in a state in which he cannot die.
Man is ordered by Senate to make tyrant stop bloodshed. He kills himself and family to satiate tyrant of blood.
Author says that a prudent man notes only the good in a vain book; a malicious person, only the bad in a good book.
Man says that he is the youngest present, for he does not count the years before he became monk (or the like).
Latter prefers poverty with safety.
Horse killed in battle; ass content.
Latter chosen.

REFERENCES: English, Irish myth, Lithuanian, Rumanian, Russian

DESCRIPTION: Wounded animal (man) refuses to have the flies driven away since they are now sated and their places will be taken by fierce and hungry flies.
Parrot set to guard figs eats his fill. When replaced he calls attention to the fact that he is now full and therefore safer than another hungry parrot.
They would defame him among strangers. At home they serve to test the king's patience and to reform his life.
Wolf told not to do so lest hungrier ones take their places as he swims.
Finds that he must work to live and returns to monastery.
Prostrate soldier asks enemy to stab him in chest instead of back in order to save his honor. Captor frees him and the two become friends.
The man tells him to take his wife (or he runs away).
He suffers to help realm.
Angel takes hermit with him and does many seemingly unjust things. Later shows why each of these was just.
Done lest he love the cup too much.
Done because man is plotting a murder.
Gambler is generous, beggar hoards.
God justifies this to his sage.
Latter chosen.
Latter chosen.
Man chooses latter.
Had rather die than suffer longer from him.
Man chooses ugly mistress.

Bad master can do evil if he desires to do so; bad official can harm a poor person and complain against him to his master; bad neighbor can betray secret things about his neighbors. Bad neighbor worst.
Neither makes good leader.
Insists on his master putting hedgehog out of house. When master refuses, weaver leaves. Next master has two hedgehogs, and next has three. Weaver returns to first master.
Therefore choose the smallest woman possible for a bride.
Fool advises uncle, in letter which he did not send, to take money from wife's paramour instead of revenge.
Granted wisdom and wealth.
Sparrows and crickets ask peasant to leave tree standing. He refuses, but when he finds honey in the tree he consents.
Beauty of form does not give worth; pine grows slowly but it will withstand storms.
Fox's spirit worth more than panther's skin.
Chosen because of beauty; too weak to defend his flock.
Better be able to soar like crane than to strut about like peacock.
Advises both to look in mirror daily lest son exchange handsome face for bad character; daughter to triumph over face by good manners.
Man shown jewels that cost much money; he replies that he has better stones (millstones) that earn that much.
Devil says that they are strong nevertheless. Hence strong speakers rather than clever are to be preferred.
Bookman's swimming saves their lives.
Latter wastes time, former not.
Ruler admires jewels's beauty but neglects to inquire about their marvelous virtues.
He saves one who admits he will not help, because he will have to carry his own young.
Lioness thus answers fox (hog) who twits her that she has only one cub.
Fox sees man trying to count the waves. Advises him to count only those immediately before him and to pay no attention to those which have already passed.
Loses both victims.
Asked what it will profit him, he says that it will profit his family.
He is in heaven and God is to reforge him, but he chooses not to change.
Woman confesses that child is not by her husband. Child, however, chooses to keep the father he knows.
Finds cost of living more than enough to take all his profit.
Gets into trouble.
Lets all others he has in his hand fall in order to search for it.
She-goats die; wild-goats run off.
When water dries up he goes hungry.
Cuts it off and leaves it for pursuers.
Told that dust from flock of sheep will annoy him; he finds it useful.
King upbraids wind for blowing away a poor widow's last cup of meal. Finds that the wind has saved a ship full of people by that very act. The king is humbled.
Bull being pursued by lion tries to go into cave. Goat refuses to let him in. Bull must go on, for with lion pursuing he has no time to fight goat.
Owes more to her than to her own mother, who has deserted her.
Criticized for its smallness he says, "I wish I had true friends enough to fill it."
Presents to be received only from equals.
Shameful to be thrown by such a creature.
Lion angry at impudence of mouse.

King asks three sons what kind of bird they would prefer to be. First: an eagle, because it is ruler of birds; second: a falcon; because it is beloved by the nobles; third: a bird which flies with many others, so as to receive advice. King chooses third.
They let man choose between them.
He will be virtuous by comparison.
Brazen pot thinks that they should stay together for company. Earthen pot, however, fears approach of brazen pot.
He sees fire prepared to cook him.
The rat threatened by the weasel and the owl allies himself with a cat caught in a net. Saved by the cat, he rescues the cat with precaution and then prudently renounces further relations with her.
They soon quarrel.
Swan is blamed when crow drops filth.
Thus kept in order.
Ill-advised associations end fatally.
Heracles on his arrival in heaven fails to greet Plutus, the god of wealth: he has seen him in too bad company.
Doctor loses his life for him and lawyer his soul.

REFERENCES: H. Gombel Die Fabel vom Magen und den Gliedern (Beihefte zur Zs. Jewish: bin Gorion Born Judas III 71, *301f., *Neuman; Indonesia: DeVries's list No. 139; Africa (Ekoi)
DESCRIPTION: Debate as to their usefulness. All mutually useful.
Help of each was indispensable.
Foolishly debate their usefulness.
Owl gives them task neither can perform and ends futile debate.
King's sons each choose a god: Jupiter for power, Saturn for wisdom, etc. Father says that a god of all combined would be better.
All to be used.
Only one is good although they all look the same. Same with religions.
Camel prefers the level.
Both are good.
Blackberry reproves them for useless jangling.
Men with many wounds recommended as soldiers. King had rather have those who gave the wounds.
Widow would have things her own way.
If husband is good she will fear to lose him; if bad she will repent.
Her husband abides in her heart.
Less hard to satisfy.
Choice of three sins given him: adultery, murder (theft), drunkenness. He chooses drunkenness; the others follow.
Preacher prefers small men because the intellect has difficulty in reaching to one's heels.
By living alone he escapes sin.
Given the choice of his friend or his mistress, man chooses his friend.
Loses his voice and gains nothing.
Only increases patient's suffering.
Only spoils his own.
When they exchange duties all goes wrong.
Asks crickets what they eat to get such a voice. They answer, "dew." He tries it and starves.
Kills himself.
Killed.
Survivors advise their friends to let well enough alone.
Finds hunter, gazelle, and wild boar dead. Tries first to eat the bowstring, and is mortally wounded.
This causes his death.
Emperor thus replies to suggestion of a new tax to be laid on the people.
Discreet cock saves his life.

He tells his master what the servants have done during his absence. The servants whip him on his bare back, saying at each blow, "That is the truth." When the master returns and tells the fool to tell the truth, the latter replies, "There is nothing worse on earth than the truth."
Overlord asks two doctors whether he is entitled to all the possessions of his retainers. One doctor unrighteously answers yes and receives a horse. The other who tells the truth receives nothing.
He is driven off for his truth telling.
The woman plucks his feathers out. When the magpie sees a bald man, she says, "You too must have tattled about the eel."
Wiser of the two shows foolishness of such a fight.
Woman insists upon quarreling with a nobleman. He says, "If you wish to quarrel, I shall leave my helmet here. You can talk to it."
In Castile a Spaniard maintains to a Portuguese that the Spanish king is best of all. In Portugal, that the Portuguese king is best. "Each cock crows in his own barnyard."
Upbraided when found playing with children, he unstrings a bow and shows how good relaxation is.
When rebuked for making him a whistle he says: "I would have blown it for him had he asked me to do so."
Emperor rebukes overzealous servant as being a nuisance.
Instructions of mother followed literally by one daughter when she marries. All goes wrong. Second daughter follows them in conformity with her father's explanations and all is well.
The small task will be done; the large one will merely discourage.
Wisely refrains.
Desists.
A waste of time to make a bed for a dog who lies down wherever he happens to be tired. Likewise a waste of time to help unappreciative people.
Man thus restrained from hasty judgment.
Is almost killed himself in retaliation. He submits and says that he deserves this punishment for hasty action.
Three men are pursued in battle. First throws himself on enemies; second waits a little; third does not fight until the enemy begins. Latter is bravest.
He has drunk too much and sings in spite of the dog's warning. He is killed.
He finds the escape different from that which had been described to him.
Robber who wants to steal monk's cow and devil who wants to steal his soul quarrel as to which shall begin first; they thus awaken him and the neighbors.
Ordered to make honey. Dispossessed.
Meantime fox escapes.
Flea had attacked abbess and been chased all night; fever, a washerwoman who nearly froze it to death by going to the river and washing clothes. They exchange and succeed.
Swallow in vain urges other birds to eat seed as fast as it is sowed. Ridiculed, he builds his nest among the dwellings of men. Later, birds are caught in nets made from the hemp.
She is hatching her own destruction.
Zeus: "If you had bitten the first foot that stepped on you it would not be done now."
Barber makes heavy demands of customer while the razor is at his throat. Customer agrees but after the shave throws the barber out.
Later learned that he is a fugitive murderer.
Man dissuades simpleton from hanging himself by telling him that hell is a place of pain and torments.
(Told also of fish.)
He is then killed.
King Log. Zeus has given them a log as king, but they find him too quiet. He then gives them a stork who eats them.
He saves himself.
Following the advice proves fatal.
So says old man to conqueror.
Disregards advice of another frog and is run over.
They disregard and are caught.
Adultery committed.
Warning disregarded. Disastrous defeat.
One of them is caught in it.
Is caught.
He should have known better than to lay hold of something whose nature is to lay hold of others.
Thrown off.
Dropped and eaten.
Mice decide that a bell should be put on the cat but can find no one to tie it on her.

REFERENCES: Greek, India, Irish myth, Italian Novella
DESCRIPTION: Odysseus and the Sirens.
Tells fox that when enemy comes there are other things to do.
Two against me. I surrender.
Carried off by falcon.
Frightened, they run apart and injure each other.
Is no longer trusted by latter.
Cannot escape hunter; peacock flies off.
Bear tells lion not to eat the man, since he would grow hungry again. Rather they should have the man use his intelligence to get them out.
Man who is planting tree told that it will never mature in his day. He is planting for the next generation.
He leaves it smaller but much stronger and richer.
Monk goes about with downcast eyes until he is made abbot; then lives in luxury. He explains that he was looking for the keys of the abbey. Now he has them.
Bishop refuses to eat small fish as he used to when an abbot. "Then I used small fish to catch big ones I have now!"
Gives up his parish and immediately loses his fickle mistress.
Advice of a self-made man.
Lazy bird is put to shame by thrift of industrious bird. In winter he is in distress.
Loss is discovered and grain placed elsewhere. Mouse, who has saved nothing, starves.
Knowing that the custom is that he is to be deposed in a year, he sends provisions to a safe place out of the kingdom.
Ant brings stored grain out into sun to keep it safe.
Crow rebukes eagle for thus imperiling his own food supply.
Spendthrift youth seeing swallow concludes that summer has come and sells his clothes. There is frost the next day and he is cold.
Fox's house fails him in summer.
Servant about to be caught for theft rehearses the lie he is to tell his master. He finds lies so transparent that he decides to tell the truth.
Their spring having dried up, they consider jumping into a well. They decide that the well may also dry up.

Servant reports to master that there is but one person in the public bath Master finds three hundred. Only one person had removed stone from his path; rest had stubbed toes. He was only one worthy of the name of man.
Man allowed to manage the weather forgets to ask help of the wind. All goes wrong and he must give up management.
Scorned for lack of foresight.
Crane eats fish left at bottom.
Father sees that it is time for him to reform.

Miller has four horses to carry grain. He uses only one, so that it soon dies. Four horses are childhood, youth, manhood, and old age. Don't heap all burden of securing salvation on the fourth horse, old age.
Charges a pair of shoes to consort with men. When old she pays with shoes the men who will consort with her.
They only kiss container, so that if they die he will not be held responsible.

REFERENCES: . Spanish Exempla, American Negro, Italian Novella
DESCRIPTION: Ass divides booty equally between himself, fox, and lion. Lion eats ass. Fox then divides: gives lion meat and he takes bones.
Best part goes to himself as king of beasts; second, as strongest; third, as most valiant; fourth "touch it if you dare."

Lion decides to abandon lioness because of her bad odor. Ass, hog, and fox as judges. Ass says she has bad odor: lioness slaps him. Hog says she has not: lion slaps him. Fox says that he has a bad cold and cannot smell.

Has been imprisoned because the king did not like the way the musician looked at him. After a year the king returns as a conqueror and sees musician. The latter says that he saw the king's conquests in a vision and was blessing him when he looked at him. The musician is honored.
Jackal sees man with instrument he is unfamiliar with, comes up to him and salutes him "Lord of Delhi." Man calls him Lord of Jungle and tells above.
King of apes asks visitors how they like his children (courtiers). Truthful visitor tells that they are very ugly, and is punished. Liar praises their beauty and receives reward.
Two brothers go to the land of Naked People. One of the brothers wears clothes and is punished.
Philosopher pretends to know bird's language and to be translating what they tell him.
Asks if there is harmony among the cities and republics of Greece: philosopher tells him to ask it of his own house.
King sees jest and rewards poet.
Drunken king sentences unjustly. Woman asks to appear before the king before he has dined. Her case is retried.
He thus avoids trouble.
Angers a theologian by disputing doctrine of the Trinity. "Don't get angry," he says; "rather than have you condemn me to hell, I would believe in four persons."
Flatterer agrees: it is the king he serves, not the wretched flowers.
Angered bishop will not answer when addressed. Relents when priest says, "Since there is no one here I may heed the call of Nature."
The more reason to sacrifice. She will keep on good terms with me.

Steward buys the king a pair of slippers. King thinks not enough has been paid for them and refuses them. Steward buys another like the first and charges a good price. Learns that this is the way to deal with kings.
It is decided to drive the devil out of a man who is possessed. Devil sees the inevitable and flees so that they cannot say that he has been driven off.
What would you do if your enemy were to kneel before you and beg forgiveness? "I would forgive him." Reveals identity and is pardoned.
Save themselves while oak is uprooted.
Useful when one knows how to use it.
Man in pit surrounded by perils thus comforts himself.
Otherwise he will not enjoy the large amount of water that he must drink.
Chased from chicken coop by dogs. When he stumbles he says, "What a fine opportunity to dance if I had time!"
Dying toad thus comforts his paramour, the frog, whom he is leaving neither married nor widow nor maiden and pregnant.
Pretends that the grapes he cannot reach are sour.
Thankful to have saved life.
Says that he has drunk so much that he does not know how he got out of the house.
Hares take heart when they see that frogs are more timid than they.
Finds that elephant is afraid of the gnat.
Upbraided for not knowing answer to question, man answers that he was chosen for his position because of what he knew, not of what he did not know.
The measure of all that he has taken with him to the grave.
He had formerly been a potter and prefers the vessels which he had made to the ones now molding him.
He humbles self to please God.
Detected.
Large wolf, called by his companions "Lion". Presumes to mix with lions but is only a wolf.
Ass and cock are surprised by lion. Cock crows and scares lion, who runs. Ass thinks that he has scared lion and pursues.
Flees at lion's roar.
Thinks that the clog on his neck is a decoration.
Punished for presumption.
Is fleeing from dog's master not from him.
He has only rolled over.
He had not felt their weight.
He is attached to camel by string.
Fails to mention his mother.
Ape shows that he is a liar.
Bursts.
Kills itself.
Her young ones know her.
Master sees him and says, "Now that you are emperor remember your humble master."
Master asks: "What would you do for me if you were king?" Answer: "Give you 100 ducats." Master beats him for insufficient consideration.
Is given a stalk of garlic.
Is told that he can be made rich but not noble.
He is made to believe that he is wanted as an archer and is so frightened that he dies.
Vine and fig tree have refused.
His mother tells him to claim no more senses than he has.
He kills them.
Victor in cock fight crows over his victory. He is taken off by eagle. A second cock then comes out from hiding and struts about among the hens.
(Bull in china shop.) Only breaks the pots
Reprimanded for presumption.
Former reprimanded.
Dante throws his tools in the street. Blacksmith: "You ruin my work!" Dante: "You ruin mine!"
She sees how a little bird by persistence pecks a hole in a stone.
Peasant puts twigs together and cannot break them. Separately they are easily broken. His sons apply the lesson.
They are like donkeys when one is beaten the rest scatter. The enemy are like pigs stick together in trouble.
Lion succeeds only when bulls separate.
Wolves are all of one kind.
As soon as they quarrel they are caught.
When they quarrel they are defeated.
If they quarrel they are doomed.
They destroy wolf.

Lark leaves her young in the cornfield. They hear farmer tell sons to go to neighbors for help in harvesting. Lark tells young not to worry. Same when he sends for relatives. Farmer decides to harvest it himself. Larks move, for they now know that it will be done Pauli (ed.
Hides under hay and escapes until master himself comes.
Ox driver must put his shoulder to the wheel before Hercules will help him.
Attempt to please everyone with weather unavailing. Weather given therefore without regard to men's desires.

REFERENCES: . England, India, Italian Novella, Spanish Exempla
DESCRIPTION: Miller blamed when he follows his son on foot; when he takes the son's place on the ass; when he takes the son behind him; and when he puts the son in front of him.
Warns man by loss of appetite, loss of desire for drink, and sickness. Man does not recognize the messengers.
Advised to imagine that his treasure is still there: he will be as well off as before.
Scorned.
It is their host in old clothes. Guests are humiliated but forgiven.
He is silent because he fears that some day he may talk too much and not be able to keep silent.
Therefore he keeps silent.
By the third day he has ceased to attract attention. She concludes that it will be the same way in connection with her intended marriage.
The third time she meets him she has no fear.
Told that he has now seen the world, for he will never see more than valleys, hills, fields, meadows, water, streets, cities, and villages.
It must have been an extraordinary bed to permit a man with so many debts to sleep on it.
Thus answers goat to herdsman who begs her not to tell master that he has broken off her horn.
Gets rid of money and is happy as before.
Wise man refuses to react to unpleasantness. "I don't hear the unpleasant."
Man pleads with thief who is stealing his figs. When pleading fails he brings him down from tree with stones.

REFERENCES: . Irish myth, Chinese, Icelandic, India, Jewish

DESCRIPTION: Makes gift to husband's mistress so that she may receive him fittingly. Husband is shamed into reforming.
Husband understands and reforms.
Knocks him down and pea rolls out.
Has tattered robe mended with scarlet. Ridiculed "I wish the rest of the robe were of the same material". Is given one.
Monkeys steal his caps. Traps monkeys and sells them.
Gives advice on many questions.
Crow advises young ones to fly away if they see man stooping for a stone to throw. Young crows: "What if he already has stone in hand?"
In order to obtain the prize, he confesses the earlier crime.
Debtor: "That is a lie; it was only a span."

Farmer will not pay servant wages due. Closing his bargain with the servant he had said: "May this stone be witness." Judge orders stone brought to court. The farmer: "Oh, but the stone is too big (or very far away)".
Guilty man chops end off stick.
Servant draws back.
Decision to go to whichever can go through end of reed.
Horses fight and A's is killed. In court B plays dumb. A says B could talk the day before, and repeats conversation. Judge blames A for not taking advice.
He confesses to carrying two persons in his body.
Others think that he has confessed and truth is discovered.
False message to thief's wife to send the stolen jewel case as bribe to the judge. She does.

Two men are in a lawsuit and before witnesses seal the documents in a bag to await arrival of the king. One of the men cuts the bag open, changes the documents, and has a repairer sew it up again. On the king's arrival the change is discovered. By having a fine carpet repaired the expert repairer is discovered. Confession follows.

A man buries gold and a thief steals it. The owner detects the criminal. He takes some money to the thief and borrows money scales "to weigh so as to bury with the other". The thief decides that he is detected and hastens to return the stolen money.
He is full of scratches and confesses.
Important man quarrels with commoner. Asks bystanders: "Who is right?" Silence. Newcomer states that the important man is wrong. "Had he been right the others would have said so."
Animals put to graze in man's garden. Owner greets everyone with: "I know about you!" No one pays any attention to him except the guilty one who says: "I did not do it." Confesses.
(Told that crossbow would shoot guilty person as he passed before it.)
Husbands ask suspected priest to talk to wives on tithing, and thus obtain sufficient evidence to convict him.
Thus gets self condemned.
The thief confesses.
The one with the heavier milk the mother of the boy; the other of the girl.
A woman's adulterous love detected through her pulse quickening at mention of her lover.
Too high to have been made by husband.
The secret hole into the building is thus discovered and the thief caught.
All animals must tell why they are thirsty.
Attacks murderer whenever possible.
Trespasser (lover, mistress, ghost, fairy, etc.) leaves footprints in the ashes.
Pitch is spread so that footprints are left in it, or that shoe is left behind as clue.
She dies from fright.
Man arouses the curiosity of the rascal who has swindled his wife.
A man masking as a maiden has committed adultery with the queen. A clever girl by challenging him to disrobe in a dance exposes the imposture.
Treatment successful.
Buried money is stolen from blind man. Latter has boy watch and notify him when passerby smiles at him. The smiler is the thief.
How would you treat a woman who came into your possession? Answer: "I would use her and then give her to the servants." This reveals his true character.
Silver buckles are not melted by the fire.
Guilty one wastes it uselessly.

Husband tells his talkative wife about treasure he has discovered. To discredit her report he tells her also of impossible things (woodcock in the fish net, fish in the bird trap, etc.). She repeats it all and whole story is disbelieved. Husband may keep his treasure.
Wife puts fish in furrow where husband plows them up (or like absurdity). At mealtime the husband says, "Where are the fish?" "What fish?" "Those I plowed up." He is laughed to scorn.

(Or rain of figs, fishes, or milk.) A mother in order to discredit testimony of her foolish son who has killed a man makes him believe that it has rained sausages. When he says that he killed the man on the night it rained sausages his testimony is discredited.

Trickster summoned to court on Jew's complaint refuses to go unless he has a new coat: Jew lends him his. In court the trickster says that the Jew is a liar: "He will even claim that I am wearing his coat." The Jew does so and no one believes him.
Witness agrees to the following facts in succession: that the person relating the facts may have been in anger, that he may have misunderstood, that he may not have heard it at all.

Adulteress is surprised in intrigue by unsuccessful suitor. He threatens to tell her husband. She tells her husband that the scorned suitor has accused her falsely of indiscretion with many men. When the suitor tells the husband he does not believe him.
Two parrots taught accusation of mistress in a particular dialect. They know nothing more of the language.
Testimony as to exact circumstances of her deed does not agree. Witnesses discredited.
Only one can answer questions just as she has. Other discredited.
Wife has parrot describe a storm very realistically. Husband observes contrast in the two tales.
Money is left by three joint depositors subject to their joint order. It is stolen by one. When the banker is sued he agrees to give up the money when he receives joint order from all three.
(Fleischpfand.) Literal pleading frees man from pound of flesh contract. Contract does not give the right to shed blood. Impossible, therefore, to carry out.
Man has earth from his own land in his shoes.
Before swearing, the cheater hands a stick containing the stolen money to the man he has stolen it from. He then swears that he has repaid it.

For three years not to drink wine, not to lie in bed, nor sleep with a prostitute. He goes to a convent, sleeps on eider down, and sleeps with the nuns. (God's daughters). When the pope condemns him he says he will go to his brother-in-law (Christ: he has wedded God's daughters).
He has fulfilled contract.
Smith reveals the solution on receipt of 100 crowns bearing the ruler's likeness.
Has both his hair and his cloak cut half short and half long.
Agrees to do so if the other will hold back streams emptying into the ocean. Agreed to drink only the ocean.
Servant takes master's cape with his teeth.
A nurse falsely demands pay for caring for a child which she says is the hero's. In court: "The child is indeed mine; give him to me." The child belongs to a peasant. Nurse confesses and is punished.

Robbers claim a man's knife. In court: "The knife may indeed be theirs. I and my father were attacked yesterday by robbers. I fled. On returning I found my father killed and this knife in his body." Robbers condemned.
Knight hailed before king for fighting blasphemer, tells king that he would fight to protect the honor of the king's name so why not for the name of the King of Kings?

Physician called to doctor woman's eyes bandages them and then steals things each day. She refuses to pay fee and is haled to court. She says that her sight is worse than ever for whereas she used to see many things in her house she now sees very little. Theft is thus revealed.

Lawyer declares unjustly that stolen horse has been bought and paid for. Angry farmer: "Yes, behind the village he bought and paid for it" (meaning that he stole it from the pasture). Lawyer pleads successfully that it is as well to buy a horse outside as inside the village.
Knight attacks enemy contrary to orders. Part of army helps him and is killed. He disclaims responsibility since he had not asked their aid.
King vows to sacrifice first thing he meets. It is a miller driving an ass. Miller pleads that the ass preceded him. They behead the ass.

King has trickster's horse's tail cut off. Trickster retaliates by cutting off part of upper lip of king's ass. At trial the animals are brought forth. Everyone laughs at the ass. Trickster: "If everyone laughs at the ass, how could the ass help laughing at her companion without a tail?" Freed.
A tailor makes a Jew a coat of stolen goods. Accused of theft, he says that the Jew has the cloth.
Man hires ass and driver for trip across plain. In the heat the traveler sits down in the ass's shadow. The driver pushes him away. Plea: he didn't hire the ass's shadow.
Judge demands that a pseudo-prophet show a miracle. Latter offers to cut off judge's head and resuscitate him. Judge agrees to be the first disciple.
Famed for his clever decisions.

LOCATIONS: Cape, Gleiwitz, India, Indies, Islands, Italy, Spain, Verde, West
REFERENCES: . Breton, . Cf. Cook Group, Cape Verde Islands, India, Italian Novella, Jewish, N. A. Indian (Menomini), Spanish Exempla, West Indies
DESCRIPTION: Two women claim a child. Judge offers to cut it in two. Real mother refuses.
Three suitors dispute over a woman. When it is proposed to divide her, true lover is discovered.
One of the husbands refuses to bury her. She is awarded to the other.

Finder of a purse containing 800 gulden returns it to owner for reward. Latter says that purse had 900 gulden in it. In court. Decision: The rich man speaks truth. The purse found is not the one he lost. The finder may keep it.
Man sued for payment for enjoyment of the flavor of meat when roasting.

LOCATIONS: Africa, Cameroon, China, India, Indonesia, Milligan, Spain, United States, Vitry, jungle
DESCRIPTION: A man rescues a serpent (bear) who in return seeks to kill his rescuer. Fox as judge advises the man to put the serpent back into captivity.
Jackal as judge declares that real husband shall enter jar woman carries on her head.

LOCATIONS: Africa, India, Kamanga, Livingstonia, New, Niger, Paris, Senegal, Sudan, Tschi, Tumbuka, York

DESCRIPTION: Threatens him midway. Fox to be judge. Feigns deafness and makes turtle come so near shore man jumps and saves self.

(1) Man pulls off borrowed horse's tail: he shall keep horse till tail grows on. (2) Man falls out of bed and kills a baby (or causes a miscarriage): he shall beget a new baby for the mother. (3) Man falls from a bridge and kills boatsman's son: shall allow boatsman to fall from bridge and kill him
Judge orders woman's second husband to return her to the first in the same condition as he received her (with child).
Prince allows plea: "If we kill those who love us, what shall we do to those who hate us?"
Woman is allowed to take one in return.
Decision: deceived fiance is to sleep with seducer's wife, if he ever marries.
Accuses young man of raping her. When he tries to rob her of money she summons help. Decision: if she had shouted as loud before, the man could not have raped her. Youth acquitted.
Girls repulsed by man climb in his window at night. Become pregnant and demand marriage. Branded as prostitutes and must pay the man.
If he were the assaulter, the torn garment would be woman's.

One of four companions is left in a warehouse to care for a cat which has a broken leg. Cat scratches self near flame and sets warehouse afire. The three must pay the one left behind. Broken leg could not walk and it was the three legs belonging to the three traders which caused the fire.

Rich man wishing to get rid of a neighbor's tree sets it afire. Neighbor's house catches and burns. Must pay four times value of tree since fire is intentional, but only actual value of house, since that fire was accidental.
Soldier accused of stealing slavegirl from author. Girl told to pour water into an inkwell. She does it so skillfully that she must have learned it from the author.
Some full and some half-full wine casks left with man by neighbor, who accuses him of theft. Fraud of accusation detected by measuring the dregs.
Woman leaves honey-pot with neighbor to guard. It has gold below the honey. Neighbor steals the gold and substitutes honey. Theft proved by gold pieces sticking to sides of pot.
Two-headed man claims double inheritance. Hot water poured over one head. Other head cries out with pain. He is declared to be one man and to merit only one share.
Thus god masking as husband is discovered.
Judge tells story of the lady, her husband, her lover, and the robbers (+H1552.1). Which was the most generous? Witness says that robber was. This shows that he has robber's point of view.
David says pay money damages. Solomon says let laborers have flock till milk and wool have paid the damages.
Weaver makes blanket shorter than ordered. Weaver ordered to add a piece to the blanket and then to receive full price.

Merchants complain to nobleman that his servants have robbed them of money. Nobleman asks whether merchants had on those good coats when the robbery took place. When told yes, he said that the robbers were not his servants, for they would never have left good coats.
Tires of the bickering of two men over a trifling sum.
Man believing wife dead becomes a priest. Later finds her alive. Pope's decision: he may remain both a priest and husband but must not consort with any other woman.
Watchers could never have got her merely by watching.
There had been a great argument over this privilege.
Boy's friends demand eye of king's son in forfeit; king decrees instead destruction of swarm of bees so that guilty one may perish.
King may not execute Brahmin, but gets him drunk and brings about his death.

King ordains that guest who turns his plate shall be executed, but orders that anyone so condemned shall have three wishes granted. One of the wishes: to have all blinded who saw him turn the plate. He is freed.
As judge he frees himself and is in reality freed.

Fool is allowed to jump off cliff (balcony) as punishment. Master expresses surprise that in three trials he has failed to hurl himself from the height. The jester offers the prince four trials. Amused prince pardons the jester.
Lady has her women ready to give a trickster a beating. He is allowed to make one request. The one who has most often deceived her husband shall strike first.
Spared.
Executioner discovers that the prisoner's ears are of stucco, having been clipped for a previous offense.

A man ties his mare to a second man's wagon. The mare bears a colt which the wagon-owner claims, saying that the wagon has borne a colt. Real owner of the colt shows the absurdity (1) by fishing in the street or (2) by telling that his wife is shooting fish in the garden. Neither of these things are so absurd as the decision.
Countertask: harvesting crop produced from cooked seeds.
A king awards a young woman to a gardener, who is already married. The young woman performs a funeral ceremony for him. The king is pleased with the jest and takes her into the harem.
Hired elephant dies. Owner demands the live elephant. The god causes the elephant's owner to break pots of the other. Is unable to make specific restitution.
(Later children tell toy animals to drink. No harder than for woman to bear objects.)
Judge has refused to inquire for lack of witnesses.
As easy to cook rice thus as to warm a man at a distance from a lamp on a balcony.
Judge decides for greater bribe.

Trickster takes jar filled with earth but with honey on top as bribe to the judge. He takes the decision in writing. Cheat is discovered and judge sends message that an error has been made. Reply: the decision was right; the error is in the honey.
Clever animal says in court that she drops dung on ancestors of judges who take bribes (unless they confess). Judges confess.
The judge has told the boy that he should kill a fly wherever he sees one.

A judge awards damages of a penny against a friend of his for giving a blow. The defendant goes to get the money and is gone long. Meanwhile the plaintiff gives the judge a blow and tells him to use the penny as damages.
Man is fined half-ducat. Judge has no change. Defendant strikes judge for the change.
Bishop has instructed him to tell the truth and spare no one when he preaches.

Bishop has fined priest for incontinence. Priest hides and witnesses amorous intrigue between bishop and abbess, hearing bishop refer to the abbess's charms in biblical similes. Priest incorporates overheard references in his introduction to the Mass and is asked for an explanation. Bishop returns his fine.
He has seen his victim in a disgraceful position and is allowed the booty as a price for his silence.
Thief confronted by the officer tells all the circumstances of the drunkenness (with many shameful additions). The officer denies the ownership.
Answers in clever proverbs when called on to say what he has seen.
One of the disputants keeps the hens he is to give the judge in his hand and when the decision begins to go against him makes the hens cry out.
A thief steals a calf and keeps the hide. The owner makes a hue and cry about a stolen ox. The thief produces the calfhide: "You thief, to demand an ox for a calf!"

Two hunters, one with dog and other with dog-head, dispute. The claim that the dog-head captured the game is allowed and then the alarm is raised that the owner of the, game is coming to punish the theft.
Wine seller carries water into his cellar. Man raises alarm pretending that he thought the house must be afire.
Man claims to be thirty; has been doing so for the last twelve years.
Vaults away from them saying: "You may tell me anything you wish in your own homes!
Ruler had instructed jesters to tease him. The poet cleverly answers his questioners pretending to have the impression that the questions are addressed to the ruler.
You two take one sheep; the ram and I will take the other.
Two coins apiece given to two; other is to wait till two more coins are found.
Fools submit problem to trickster who solves problem by taking third fish himself.
Two fat fowls and one lean one at meal. Hero is lean, his two hosts fat. He is to divide. One lean fowl for the two fat people; two fat fowls for the one lean man.
Trickster alternates hands so fast that the other man never gets to put his hand in. He finally puts his foot in the pan.

To be divided among three students according to their skill in quoting. First: "And they cut one ear off" (takes ear). Second: "And they gave him a box on the ear" (takes other ear). Third: "And they took him away secretly" (takes whole hog away).
Three to the woman and one each to the men. Men already have two (testicles).
E.g., Where are you going? Forward. Where are you going to cut the tree? At the foot.
Nuns tell a man that they are daughters of God. " Come and marry me; I should like such a rich father-in-law.
Priest consoles sick man by saying that God chastens those whom he loves.
By the great bugaboo! If I was the Almighty and had a moon, I'd hang it out on a night like this.
She remarks. " Well I am more favored than my Lord. He had but one ass to ride, while I have two.
Sick woman calls the parson but recovers meanwhile He insists on her taking the sacrament and charges for it. " Set it here on the table; perhaps I can sell it again.
Priest offers to help peasant with "the body of the Lord".   " If God can be brought by a man, he is too weak to help me.
Thief about to be hanged is told that if he truly repents he will eat Lord's Supper in heaven. " If that is true, won't you eat the supper for me; I'll reward you well.
If that were so, says the apprentice, no one would have given it to you or me.
Says that he had his mind on God and did not remember what his body did. If those who criticized him had had their minds on God they would not have noticed it.
Shouts vituperations at him.
Says that he thought that the owl had stolen the Host.
Spectators tell him to thank God for not drowning. " I helped Him across!
Priest tells condemned man after confession that he will dine with Christ that evening. Mule that carries him to scaffold goes very fast and criminal says, "At this rate I shall lunch with Christ.

Beggar woman asks pope for shilling and, being refused, for a penny. Finally asks for his blessing, which he gives. Old woman: "If your blessing had been worth a penny, you wouldn't have given me that.
King asks how much his funeral will cost. " Give me the three hundred ducats now and when I am dead throw me into the Tiber.
At his mother's funeral a boy takes the money laid on the altar for masses. When the priest objects, the boy says, "When your mother dies you may take the money too.
Thief told by monk that he must return stolen cloth on Judgment Day "If I have so long a period of grace, I should like to take the whole monastery.

Franciscan claims that his cordon will save him from Hell. Benedictine answers that he once had a dream in which he saw St. Francis throw his cordon to save members of his order in Purgatory and so many clung to it that it snapped.

So answers a preacher when asked whether he preferred to stay at home and confess his flock or go to war against the infidels.
J1261.10	India	India	
J1262.1			Emperor: God is a thief; he threw Adam into a sleep and then stole a rib from him. " Emperor's daughter: "Would you call a man a thief who stole two earthen cups from you and replaced them by golden ones? " Jewish: Gaster Exempla 196 No. 55,

A Jew objects to the doctrine that God could exist in the Virgin Mary. A disputant asks if he believes God is everywhere; then if God is in a mud puddle. The Jew agrees. The disputant condemns the Jew for believing that God could exist in a puddle and not in a pure virgin.

A Jew slaps a Christian and tells him to turn the other cheek. The Christian beats the Jew, who says, "You do not act according to your Gospel. " "I am acting in accordance with the note. " "The note is worse than the text.
Chops down crucifix and takes money from box. Is told that such return would take place in other world. " I won't need money then, but I can use it now.

retorts wise man to atheist.
J1262.8	India, U.S.	concludes that ministers have deceived him in telling him the story of Adam. U.S.	
J1262.9	Italy	Italian Novella	Ruler trying to confiscate Jew's money asks him which is the true faith.  There are three, the one which the Lord knows is right and the two his children think are right.
They can always find patrons as ignorant as they are.
A bishop disgusted with priest's ignorance says, "Who consecrated you as priest? "   "You did, the time I gave you ten florins.
Peasants complain of his ignorance. He says that they stand so close to him that he is afraid they might memorize and then pay no attention to his reading of it.

Two priests apply for the position of chaplain and argue as to which one can say the mass more quickly. One clinches the argument saying: "You could not say it more quickly than I because I don't read half of it!
Ignorant student unable to pass his examination thus consoles himself.

Bishop is paid 100 ova (eggs) instead of 100 oves (sheep) for consecrating man as priest. To bishop's protests the man answers, "You should have refused to consecrate me. If I had been worthy I should not have had to promise oves or ova.
Pope says, "Who could withstand such an armored army? " and decides for the rich man.
Jew so decides when he thinks of the scandalous life of the court of Rome.
Cardinal rebukes abbot for living in luxury beyond that of the founder of his order. Abbot asks cardinal if the cardinals of St. Peter traveled in the luxury he does.
Many do not pray at all, many know their prayers by heart, and the great prelates look through their fingers
Ruler explains: "I want a lying priest so that if he repeats my confession he will not be believed.
Peasant sees priest at work in the fields. Tells him he wishes to confess. He is told to put money in the box and take the same penance as the year before.
Priest accused of being too intimate with parishioners' wives says that the church is his wife and that the men treat her far more shamefully than he treats any woman.
Monk says, "I vowed three things: poverty in the bath, obedience at the table, and celibacy at the altar.
Priest's son is thus taunted.
Nun asked why she did not call for help when raped. She says, "It was during the silent period.
He has nun as mistress.
Defense accepted.

Priest is entrusted with reforming five dissolute nuns. Gets all five with child. The priest is rebuked for not using his "talents" when tempted. He answers: "God gave me five talents and I have added five more! " (Pun on word talent.)
Man at his lady's funeral says to priest: "You enjoy them when they are young and then give them to us to bury.
Bishop has parson to dinner in the seat of honor. The parson fears that the dinner precedes punishment. Parson: "Don't let me be like Christ on Palm Sunday in Jerusalem"
An abbot calls the monks together and asks, "Whom from all you fools can I appoint as steward?" A monk answers, "That should not be difficult since an abbot was found from the same company of fools."

During the sermon the parson bids the sexton see if anyone is coming. The sexton: "A man is coming with a wheel on his shoulder" Parson: "God gives it to you." Sexton: "Now a man is coming with half a hog on his shoulder." Parson: "God gives it to me."
Chaplain accused of being first to start all knavery thus defends himself.
Bishop brought quail on Friday orders them cooked. Blamed. If he can turn bread into the body of the Lord why can he not turn quail into fish?
Bishop refuses a favor to an abbess on the ground that he does not love her. Abbess: "I can well believe that. The capon never loves the hen."
Man while praying refuses to salute superior. While standing before the King of Kings he could not show respect to inferiors.
God will not permit them to enter heaven unless we take their ill-gotten goods from them.
(St. Christopher.) Parishioner: "The ass, for he bore both the son and his mother."
Complaints against underpaid priest that he does not stay at home. Says he cannot stay at home for the mice are dying of hunger since he receives only forty florins a year.
Such is the answer given monks who insist that quarters occupied by the king and his train be reconsecrated.
The fire set by cat's tail gains headway.
When I look at the livers, you are to be a father. When I look at you, I see that you are not even a man.
Of three brothers the shoemaker makes shoes for the queen and princess; the tailor, clothes; the fool children.
Artist paints beautiful children but his own are ugly. One kind, he says, are made by day, the other by night.
A young man comes to Rome who looks like the emperor. Latter asks him if he mother has ever been in Rome. No, but my father has been here often. (Not son but brother.)
Father-in-law to son-in-law: "Do like my grandson and you will always be ahead of others."
Child born two months after marriage. Husband returns wife to her father (uncle) saying: "I can't afford a child every two months."
Groom leaves. Can't afford a child every time he lies with his wife.
Mother of twelve on deathbed explains to family that not all her children are legitimate. Gives the paternity of each child. Youngest leaves his food to say: "Please, mother, give me a good father!"

Returning sailor finds his hovel transformed into a fine house. "Where does all this come from?" Wife: "God's bounty." Illegitimate child greets mother. Same question, same answer. Sailor: "I don't want God to help me so much!"
Girl's father protests, saying that she has had three children.
The children of the Genoese are strong because there is more help.
Answer made by emperor to one who calls him a tyrant.
To be rewarded by ruler with a coin, an ass, a sheep, or a vineyard. Answers that he will take the coin, mount the ass, drive the sheep into the vineyard, and there pray for the ruler.
A king gives a man a coin. "Is that all you give your brother?" "Are you my brother?" "Surely, we both pray, Our father, etc." "If all your brothers give you as much as I you will be rich."
A widow stops a ruler on his way to war. He may be killed and he should not leave the act of justice as a credit to his successor.
Wronged woman thus addresses ruler, who is indifferent to insults directed at him. She wishes to be shown how to bear insults. This rebukes him.
A widow asks justice of a king. The latter says that he is too busy to hear her. "Then cease being a king," replies the widow. Her bold reply wins an audience with the king.
A thief condemned to the gallows tells the king, "I do what you do and it is against my will." King: "You shall also be hanged against your will."
A peasant goes to a judge and thinking to gain his favor addresses him with high titles. The judge calls him a fool. "I was mistaken, you swine!"
A judge asks a pseudo-prophet to prove his powers by opening a difficult lock. "I am a prophet, not a locksmith."

Peasant tells bishop, who rides by with forty horses, that he wonders if St. Kilian at W'rzburg is also riding with forty horses. Bishop excuses extravagance by saying that he is also a prince and that it is the prince, not the bishop, who is using the horses. "If the prince should become a fool, what would the bishop do then?"
Pope calls persistent courtier a fool. Latter says that there are people who call the pope the same thing and that he for one will not try to correct them.
Philosopher asks ruler for money Ruler says that philosophers do not need money. Philosopher: "If I am rewarded, I will say that you are right; I will no longer need money."
Shivering king (rich man) to tattered peasant: "Aren't you cold?" Peasant: "No, if you wore all your clothes as I do, you wouldn't be cold either!"
King to son who has been accused of rape: "I never did anything like that." Prince: "Your father was not king!" King: "Your son will never be one if you keep that up!"

Lord takes his tools away from him. Shoemaker begs for them saying that he cannot carry on his business without them. Ruler: "I thought ruling was your business so I took your tools to learn shoemaking."
Judge stops up one ear while first litigant presents his case. He is saving one ear for the second litigant.
King brought to sense of duty by philosopher who tells him to seek harmony in his own house before inquiring about the harmony in his kingdom.
A philosopher of the city came to him asking mercy for it King said he would do nothing he asked. Philosopher then asked him to destroy the city. This saves the city.
When he is tried later, he is told how at the earlier trial he had kept repeating that the judge was a very wise judge. When he hears this he admits that he must have been very drunk.
Trickster goes around king and says king is kingdom.
Jester flatters prince for bounty.
Jester answers: "The landlords."
Smoker: "Donkeys don't know how to enjoy themselves."
Question: How can black beans make a white soup? Answer: How can a white whip on the naked flesh make black welts.
Answer: The same reason blackberries are red when they are green.

Where was God before he made heaven and earth? and the like answered by "Why a louse bite raises a blister, a flee bite raises a swelling, and a gnat bite is unnoticeable?" If you cannot answer such simple questions how can you pry into God's secrets.
How many fox tails will reach to heaven? All depends on the length of the tails.
Just as much as for me, for what you have done for a poor person in my name you have done for me.
When your mother conceived where were you?
Minnow seeing absurdity of question (since tide could not be up without the moon) tells the tide to wait till he gets a drink and he will tell.
A large bird wishes to mate with a little bird. The latter says that she is going to swallow a large eel. The large bird sees the absurdity of his proposal.
Not more absurd than crow claiming swan as wife.
Judge shows criminal mercy: he will not punish him as he deserves, only take off his head.
Butcher buyer demands saddle and ornaments along with camel (or the like). Seller later buys all heads in butcher shop: demands heads of butcher's family.
Women insist on knowing how a man wants to be mourned when he dies. "Mourn me as a man who was tormented by women talking foolishness."
Priest complains that miller's mule is overloaded. "No, he isn't; he can still carry all your and your brothers' patience."

Aesop goes for fire to a neighbor's in the daytime and lights a lantern so as to bring the fire back. Fool asks him what he is hunting for with the lantern in the daytime. "I seek a man" (not a busybody).
A man goes forth in black clothes. People are curious as to the reason. "I am wearing mourning for the father of my son."
Mother asks newly-wedded daughter if she approached her husband the first night. Answer: "He approached me.

REFERENCES: Indian asks if man's face is cold. Indian replies, U.S.

DESCRIPTION: Answer: Only once.
Disgusted father-in-law: I have eaten half and your father half, to have such a fool son-in-law.

A servant is so trained that when the host asks for wine from a good cask he brings it from a cheap one. When the guest objects, the host says that the servant brought not what was asked for but what was wanted.
Server of diluted wine thus taunted.
Server of diluted Rhine wine thus taunted.
Christ's making wine from water has made all landlords try to do it too. Man prefers Jewish wine to the baptized kind.
Man given his choice of old or new wine says, "We must honor old age.
To doctor: "If this is the way to get to Heaven (drinking) I don't want to know any other!
Man to friend who drinks very little: "If everyone drank as you do, wine would be cheap. " Answer: "On the contrary, it would be expensive because I drink all I want.
Guest criticizes host's small serving of wine which he said was six years old.
Man asks that large jug be filled with wine. Is told to go to the river. Is accommodated when he presents small jug.
Another drink and I could have slapped his face!

(Enemies are rum and hard cider.)
J1321.1	Italy	Italian Novella, Jewish	Father shows drunkard son a drunk man being mocked on the street. Instead of taking it as a warning the son says Where does one get such good wine?
Doctors consult how to rid fever-stricken drunkard of his great thirst. " You take care of the fever; I shall take care of the thirst.
Priest blamed for large amount of wine he drinks tells people to consider his great thirst. He has slept on a sack of salt and has enough thirst for a week.
Drunkard's wife takes him when he is drunk to a tomb and, masking as a ghost brings him food. " If you had known me better you would have brought me drink.
Doctor tells drunkard, "The goblet has stung you. " "If I had known that I would have drunk out of a glass.

A beggar will not come in but insists on the man coming down to the door. When he asks alms the man bids him come upstairs. Then he says he has nothing for him. " You made me come down for nothing; I make you come up for nothing.
A numskull tells his mother that a beggar is below asking for bread. Mother: "Tell him I am not at home. " Numskull: "He doesn't want you, he wants bread.
Beggar: "Good day, you stingy fellows. " They: "We are not stingy fellows. " Beggar: "Then give and prove me a liar.
They say they have no meat, no bread, no wine, etc. "Then go beg; you have more need than I."
So says beggar who asks goldsmith to plate his club with gold.
An avaricious master feeds bread-crusts to his servants. " The crusts are already getting soft.

Parents serve boy a small fish and keep back a large one for themselves. Knowing this, the boy puts the fish to his ear. He says that he has asked the fish a question; the fish cannot answer but tells him to ask the large fish under the bed.
Given very thin rice soup, wit inquires about the master's dogs. " He should have one to scent the rice in this soup.

Widow serves tailor one egg. He sings, "One egg, one egg. " She decides one egg is not enough and serves him two next time. He then sings "Two eggs are two eggs. " He is next given two eggs and a sausage, etc.
He tells of a cow with four teats who bore five calves. They ask what the fifth calf does while the other four are nursing. " It looks on just as I am doing now.
She always gives the servants a pitcher of weak beer before meals so as to fill them up. One of them: "I wash out my insides so as to have more room for food. " She changes her practice.
The servant says that he doesn't like sweets and takes the large lumps.
He slaps another son, and explains that the other boy was saying that he would not get any of the father's cherries. The father shares the cherries.
By telling a mewing cat that it could not yet have the bones because no meat has been served him, a collegian calls attention to an oversight on the part of a servant.
A guest is seen uttering a prayer before an underdone hen at the table. " She must be a goddess turned into a hen, for she has been over the fire and spared.
What music do you like best? The sound of plates and spoons.
A priest, asked when he would have certain choice wine served, before or after the meal, replies, "The holy Mary was Virgin before, during, and after the birth.
Having seen his hostess hide it, he tells about it in the form of a tale.
When host inquires, he replies, "If thou be the son of God, command that these stones be made bread.

If both of us had been present at the miracle of the loaves and fishes you would have eaten me too! " Pilgrim: "I wouldn't have eaten you but I would have chewed on you a bit! " Cent Nouvelles Nouvelles No. 83; Italian Novella:

A woman having given her cook leave of absence for the next day asks her what day it is. " Saturday. " "No, it is the day on which the prostitutes wander. " The cook: "Yes, from one prostitute to another. Today I am with you, tomorrow with your sister.
A woman accuses another of being a harlot. The second: "You would like to be in my place but no one wants you.
A king and his son hunting on a hot day put their fur coats on the fool's back. King: "You have an ass's load on you. " Fool: "Rather the burdens of two asses.
Young rival derides old one for his age. Oldster: "An ass of twenty is older than a man of seventy.
There is someone carrying a goose. How does that concern me? He is carrying it to your house. How does that concern you?
At market a man enquires of another: "How is the moon, three-quarters or full? " "I don't know. I have neither bought nor sold one.
You are a good man; there is not your equal on the earth. You have everything for yourself alone; only your wife is public property.

Two men meet a homely girl. One of them: "Who wouldn't call that girl pretty? " The girl overhears and says, "No one would say it of you. " The man: "Anyone might say it who would lie as I have lied about you.

To a prince who boasted that he was descended from the Trojans a doctor replies: "My people are of Nurenberg. Everyone knows who they are; but of the Trojans no one knows anything except that Aeneas was a traitor and Romulus a robber.
A messenger tells a man that he has a newborn son. " Thanks are to God, but I am not beholden to you for it.
In reply to women's taunts he boasts of his powers. A woman calls on the devil to come and ride him.
Impoverished spendthrift sarcastically to thrifty person: "Stop spending so freely! " "It's too late to give you the same advice.

Unworthy person is rewarded. Asks worthy one: "Why is it that I am rewarded and you are not? " Answer: "Because you have found more of your kind that I have of mine. " (Also told of Dante and a minstrel.)
Friend: "You had better spend 200 so as to not be found out.
An old man says of a youthful prodigy: "He will be an idiot in old age because perfection before maturity brings on deterioration of the mind. " Youth: "You must have been very wise in your youth!
One says: "I do not give every coxcomb the wall! " The other says: "I do, sir!
Answer: I am the Bishop of Durham's fool; whose fool are you?

A king, hearing that a man keeps an account-book of people's mistakes asks to see about his own record. He reads that the king has made a mistake in trusting a certain sum of money to a servant. King: "How if he comes back with it? " "I shall cross off your name and put him down for making a mistake.
White man asks Indian if he can safely leave some of his belongings inside the Indian's lodge. The Indian assures him that he can: "There is no white man within a hundred miles of here.
Parson tells borrower to get the corn at the same place as he got it last year. There is none there. " Then you didn't return it as you said you would, and there is none to lend you this year.
Many persons request a man on the way to market to buy them a whistle. Finally one hands him a coin with the request. " You are the one who shall blow the whistle.

To a man going on a voyage, various people give commissions for purchases, which he writes down on cards. Some give him money; some promise it on his return. On ship he looks the cards over, placing the proper gold on the proper card. A wind blows into the sea those not weighted with gold.
Stag tries to borrow grain from the sheep, using the wolf as security. Sheep says that they are both so swift that he does not know where they will be on the day of payment.
Guests in inn discuss reincarnation. " Since we shall come back in three thousand years, the host might trust us till then. " Host: "You still owe me what you didn't pay three thousand years ago.

Vegetable thief is caught in a garden. Owner: How did you get into the garden? A wind blew me in. How were the vegetables uprooted? If the wind is strong enough to blow me in, it can uproot them. How did they get into your bag? That is what I was just wondering.
A thief climbs over a wall by means of his ladder. When caught in the garden he says that he is a seller of ladders. Owner: "Is this a ladder market? " "Can't one sell ladders everywhere?
Two thieves caught with stolen sheep. One says that he told the other than sheep have lower teeth but no upper, and that they caught the sheep to see.
Man caught just as he knocks sheep in the head: The sheep bit me (or: I'm not going to let sheep butt me to death).

A hawk steals a piece of liver from a trickster and flies away with it. The trickster likewise steals some liver from another man and escapes to a high place with it. He says that he is seeing how he would act if he were a hawk.

King demands that each subject bring small amount of milk to put in his new cup. They plan to cheat him by bringing him water. Accused, they say that they were merely measuring the cup to see how much it would take to fill it.
Fox leaving merchant's warehouse: "I had wanted a needle as big as an anchor and an anchor as small as a needle.

A thief ransacks a man's house and departs. The man gathers together the rest of his belongings and tracks the thief. Comes to the thief's door. Thief: "What do you want with me? " "What, isn't this the house we set out for?
A buffoon says to robbers in his house, "You can't find anything here in the dark, for I can find nothing in broad daylight.

A numskull caught changing meal from others' sacks into his own. Miller asks him what he is doing. " I am a fool. " "Why then don't you put your meal into their sacks? " "I am only a simple fool. If I did that I should be a double fool.
A thief having scorned Demosthenes for his constant study, the latter says, "I know that you have not failed to notice that I study much at night.
The king in order to correct the habit has him robbed. He says that robbers get up even earlier than he.
Thus a hunter answers a thief who steals his hare.
A king noticing that a student has stolen a capon, asks, "Does not the Bible say that you should not worry about tomorrow? " "Exactly. I was trying to remove all chance of worry tomorrow.

A man takes a shirt to market for a friend who has stolen it. At market it is stolen from the seller. He tells his friend that the market was bad and that he was able to get back only the cost price (nothing).
A man complimented a hangman on the good job he had done in hanging a thief. The hangman takes off his hat: "One thief I hang, to the other I take off my hat.
A parson hides his money in a holy place and leaves a sign, "The Lord is in this Place. " A thief takes the money and leaves a sign, "He is risen and is no longer here" Pauli (ed.

A tailor dreams that at Judgment Day he sees a flag made up of all the pieces of cloth he has stolen Upon waking he asks his servants to warn him if they ever see him tempted to steal again. This happens. He replies, "The piece I am about to steal does not fit into the flag.
A parson arriving late at a city gate asks if he can get in. Guard sees that he is fat and in fun says that he doesn't know. The parson: "Why not; doesn't the hay wagon get in?
(Peace fable.) The fox tries to beguile the cock by reporting a new law establishing peace among the animals. Dogs appear; the fox flees. " The dogs have not heard of the new law.
A cat seeing a mouse leave a bath says, "Good bath! " Mouse: "If I had not seen you!
A falcon reproaches a cock for fleeing from the master who has fed him. The cock: "I have never seen a falcon roasted.
Two foxes in a trap converse: "Where shall we meet again? " "In three days at the furrier's.

Sick man: "I came to a place I know not where; something happened I know not how; I am sick I know not where. " Doctor: "Go to the pharmacy and buy I know not what, and eat it I know not how, and you will become well I know not when.

A bad physician having predicted the immediate death of a patient meets him recovered. " How go things down below? " "They put you at the head of the list of bad physicians, but I maintained that you were no physician at all.
Doctor forbids patient to drink wine. When patient reproves doctor for drinking wine the latter says: Just now it is bad for you and good for me.
Doctor throws patients into a pit of water. Servant warns queer-looking hunter to flee before master throws him into the pit.
When he killed animals he had to pay for them; but he did not have to pay for killing people.
Question from the king: "Who are you? " "I am God. " "Make my eyes larger. " "I am only God of the earth and have power only below the girdle.
King (to cynic): "What can I do for you? " "Get out of my sunlight. Don't take away from me what you can't give me.
Tells Alexander that the power of reason makes even a poor man as great as a king.
Leaving an unclean bath house: "Where can I go now to wash?
Why is gold so pale? " "It is in great danger.
Asked who will carry him to his grave if he has no friends: "He who needs my house.
When told that the beasts and the birds will prey on him he says: "Put a stick at my side so that I may chase them away.
Asked which wine tastes best, he says, "That belonging to other people.
Coming to a little town with big gates, he says, "Close the gate so that the town won't run away.
Cynic: "Be careful; you might hit your father.
Hearing a man discoursing at great length about heaven, he asks, "When did you come down from there?
His only reply to the baldheaded man's slanders is to compliment the hair that has left such a horrible head.
When the deceiver calls him wicked, he says, "I am glad that you are my enemy; for you do good to your enemies and evil to your friends.
Man tells friend that his wife has hanged herself on a fig tree. Friend: "Give me a shoot of that tree!
When he learns that a woman has hanged herself from a tree he explains: "Would that all trees bore such fruit!
One who has just escaped from drowning should not return to sea.
Of an evil choose the smallest part.
Man ordered to number the fools in the city replies, "It is easier to number the wise men.
A wandering actor rewarded by a city with a coat of their color gambles it away. When upbraided about giving away their present he replies that they hadn't wanted to keep it themselves.
A man has been told by a seer that there are two ways in which a believer may be distinguished. But he has forgotten one of them and the seer had forgotten the other.
A man strikes a priest with a cane: "This is Moses' staff. " The priest shoots with a pistol: "This is Aaron's holy censer.
Dog reproaches sow that Venus will not allow those who have eaten swine to enter her temple. Sow says that it is because the goddess abhors those who kill swine.

A husband planning to punish his wife, who has yawned in church at the same time as a man, sees his error when his wife in the woods calls out, "The squirrels hop from bough to bough as the yawns from mouth to mouth.

Badger: "I was a hundred years old when grama grass first grew. " Crane: "My daughter was a hundred years old when grama grass first grew. " Wolf: "I am only eight years old, but we shall see who gets the beehive.
Philosopher explains that with his own blood he was nourishing as large a population as that of the Roman Emperor (lice).
Soldier tells captain that the enemy are so numerous that their arrows darken the sun. Captain: "Good, it will be more comfortable fighting in the shade.
A man points out the statue to show the supremacy of man. The lion: "If it had been a lion sculptor, the lion would have been standing over the man.
Slave (workman) recommended to master whose recent slaves have died: "He has never died while I owned him.
A man attempts to lie out of having called another a liar: "You lie if you say that I said you lied. " The other: "It's a good thing for you that you didn't call me a liar.
An old husband tells his young wife, who is concerned about his gray hair, "A gray fox is as good as a red one. " "But an old gray fox is not so good as a young red one.
Village called on to join in war deliberates in meeting. A man says, "We have taken oaths not to go to war. We must now take an oath to break all the oaths we have taken.
Fool asked what made him gray-headed replies, "My hair.
Man who wears a red cap after his father's death says, "I can grieve just as much in red as in black.
Told that a forest dwarf with a long beard is a saint, a man replies: "If a long beard indicates sanctity, the goat is a saint.
A trumpeter captured pleads that he did not fight. Answered: "You may not fight, but you encourage your men to do so.
A man always drinks out of his own cup. In storm at sea a sailor says, "Today we all drink out of the same cup (the sea).

A duke invites a notorious eater. The latter consumes eight fowls, forty eggs, and other things in proportion. In leaving he apologizes for eating so little as he had not felt well the night before. He will do better next time.
Reproached with his mutilation, the eunuch says that his ill fortune is no shame. The only shame is to merit what you suffer.
Three brothers asked by princess what is the most beautiful thing in the garden. The youngest replies, "Yourself." He wins the princess.
He dreams that he receives nine coins. He demands ten. He wakes and finds that he has dreamed. He is willing to accept the nine.
A man prays for a thousand gold pieces and says that he will not accept one less. A joker sends him 999. He says that he will trust God for the other coin.

A sailor says that all his ancestors have drowned. Citizen: "Aren't you afraid of drowning?" Sailor: "How did your ancestors die?" Citizen: "All of them in bed." Sailor: "Aren't you afraid to go to bed?"
A peddler scolds the dog who is waiting and tells him to get ready to go with him. The dog replies that he has nothing to carry, that it is the peddler who is late.
A hide is in the river. River: "What is your name?" Hide: "Hard hide." River: "Hunt another name; I'll soon soften you."
A man boasts of his jump on Rhodes and says that if he were in Rhodes he could prove his boast. Reply: "No need to go to Rhodes. Show us your jump here."

A wife served overhot soup, forgets and burns herself so that tears come to her eyes She says that her departed father liked soup so much that she weeps when she eats it. The husband is also burned and weeps: "I am weeping because your accursed mother didn't take you with her when she died."
Says that he is crying because so many have left the monastery.

After her husband's death a woman cannot find a hammer and anvil. She goes to a dying neighbor and says, "If you die, as you surely will, and go to Heaven, as you surely will not, ask my husband where he left the hammer and anvil." The dying man's wife replies, "If you go to Heaven, as you surely will, if you die as you surely will not, do not run around and get into trouble, but sit down by the Eternal Father and observe and keep still."
Man tells parson secret and asks him to keep it. The parson refuses; "If you can't keep the secret, you must not expect me to."
Jester: "You did have a swift horse. When I had to stop because my horse was tired out, you went two miles further."
A man on a runaway mule is asked, "Where are you going?" "Wherever my mule wants to."
An inexperienced rider borrows a horse, which runs away with him. He says, "There are no such storms on sea as on the land."
The rider: "I couldn't; you see, it ended there" (pointing to horse's head).
An unskillful barber keeps cutting a man's face. A noise is heard. The man: "What is that?" Barber: "A smith shoeing horses." Man: "I thought it was someone being shaved."

Farmer has whiskers shaved off, hair cut short. He gets home late, slips into bed with his wife. She runs her hand over his face, says: "Young man, if you're goin' to do anything, you'd better be agittin' at it, 'cause Old Whiskers'll be here pretty soon."
A lazy youth explains his late rising by saying that he lay abed to hear the argument between industry and laziness.
A man sends his two sons to schools and later enquires of their progress. One: "I am past Grace." The other: "I am at the devil and all his works."

Paid guide climbs tree and leaves traveler to mercy of a bear. Traveler feigns death and the bear sniffs at him and leaves. The guide: "What did the bear say to you?" "He said, never trust a coward like you."
Is engaged to decorate room. Owner: "You did not paint as many birds as I told you to." Artist: "The windows were left open and most of them flew out."
King pretends to see the picture. Courtiers reveal that there is no picture.
He has broken his master's pots while dreaming of future profits. He has therefore lost more than the master and excuses himself of blame.
The lame cannot flee from the enemy; the one-eyed soldiers will not see enough to make them afraid.
The ghost runs beside him. The man stops to rest; the ghost stops, says, "That was a good run we had!" The man says, "Yes, and as soon as I get my breath, I'm going to run some more."

Man attempts to stay in haunted house all night. One cat after another enters, says, "Everything will be all right when Caleb comes, won't it?" (or something similar). Man finally says, "When Caleb comes, tell him I was here and left." He leaves.
At table the peasant says, "We will only act as if we were eating." At work the servant replies, "We will only act as if we were working."
A peasant compels his servant to call turnips bacon. Under favorable circumstances the servant compels the master to call a cat a rabbit.
When man asks for his fee, other takes a frog and gives it to him: "Know that the frog of the Ganges is a cow."
