A woman feigns periodic attacks of a sickness that can be cured only by eating a great number of delicacies. The husband feigns the same disease.
After dinner a servant feigns a fit and goes to sleep. The master thereupon feigns a fit and beats the boy, who is thus cured of his laziness.

A host spills his customer's wine so that he must buy more. He consoles the guest with "It is a sign of the great abundance you shall have this year." With the same remark the guest draws the spigot from the host's wine cask.

A man offers a porter three wise counsels for carrying his goods. "When anyone tells you that hunger and satisfaction are the same, don't believe him." The second and third are similar and equally valueless. The porter throws down the load: "When anyone tells you that any part of this load is not broken, don't believe him."

Friends tell a man that the next day is the Day of Judgment and urge him to kill a lamb and give a feast. He apparently consents. He then burns up their clothes. They will not need clothes on the Day of Judgment.

A husband forbids a wife to think. During his absence she roasts a chicken, eats it, and leaves two drumsticks on the table. The husband asks for the chicken. "Since you have forbidden me to think, I did not think of you." The ban is lifted.
Holds up food to master's back and then not having objection raised, eats it.

A priest who has lent money to a Jew, but will not lend to a farmer, on being reproached by the latter, says that the money he lent the Jew was "false". When the Jew gets to know of this, he claims that as soon as he heard the money was false he burnt it up.
Father, chastising his lazy son, also speaks in "Latin".

The master orders his serf to watch the manor at night in place of the dog. When the thieves come, the serf barks: "Dress, dress .... They take, take .... They lead, lead .... " The master does not understand the barking and pays no heed to it   is robbed of his property.
Later Oisin gives Patrick quarter of a wild boar, servant ivy leaf and rowan berry.

Man reproves another for picking his cherries that overhang the highway. He is told that things on the public highway belong to no one in particular. He invites the man to climb the tree for better cherries, drives off with his horse and buggy, giving the same answer about things in the public highway.

Priests come to an inn where host gives them good wine and bad. They insist on having all good since they must drink only one kind of wine. On their return he serves them with all bad. They claim to have had the rule changed.
Later deceived man disguises and sells sharper another ox for "handful of coppers." He is allowed by court to claim the hand as well.
Priests burned with iron since she had asked to be cauterized.
A king demands a hundred men's drink from the milk of a hornless dun cow from every house in the land. Wooden cows are made and bog-stuff substituted for milk; the king must drink it.
Let me have your other so that I can see whether the one I bring you matches.
The student as healer hangs this sign around the neck of a sick calf. Later as parson he is sick. It is proposed to heal him with the same remedy.
Condemned man insists that the priest, who is guilty also, shall lead the way.
Thieves steal mustard and leave all else.
Thieves take box filled with stone (or dig up field).
Thieves stung by hornets.
Tricksters induce a numskull to climb a tree, planning to steal his shoes. He takes them in his belt with him. "Perhaps I shall find a nearer road home up there and shall need my shoes."

A monk at an old man's deathbed asks if he hasn't promised this and that to the church. The old man from weakness rather than understanding nods "Yes". The son standing by asks, "Shall I throw this fellow down stairs?" The old man nods "Yes".

A ruler receives gifts from his subjects and later demands them as he due. The fool sets the nobleman's bed on fire. When the nobleman commands him to put the fire out he refuses, since he would ever afterward have to be putting out fires.
A woman entrusts three coins to a headsman. He denies her claim which she fails to substantiate in ordeal. She now claims more and happens to succeed with ordeal.
Claimant has called dead cricket "something" and must be content.
A man asks to be shaved at half price. The barber shaves one side. He must pay the other half for the rest of the shave.
They think he has been responsible and honor him. He reforms.
He frightens her and later mocks her with her words of fright. She plays the same trick on him.
Army major approaches sentry, takes away his rifle, and reproaches him for allowing himself to be disarmed. Sentry draws pistol from inside shirt, demands return of unloaded rifle.
Priests misinterpret raja's dream and get his horses. Trickster advises raja to announce dream demanding cauterization of the priests. They return horses.

Borrower of golden pumpkin returns a brass pumpkin and claims that the gold has turned to brass. The lender takes the borrower's son and returns with an ape. He claims that the boy has turned into an ape.
Jackal as judge comes late. "Tank of water caught fire."

REFERENCES: India, Indonesian, Italian Novella, Spanish Exempla
DESCRIPTION: Trustee claims that mice have eaten the iron scales confided to him. The host abducts the trustee's son and says that a falcon has carried him off.

Man keeps dog for boy, tells him when he comes for it that the chinch bugs have eaten it. The boy borrows a mule from the man, later tells him that a buzzard has carried it away. He gets his dog back.
A borrower returns a pot along with a small one saying that the pot has had a young one. The pots are accepted. He borrows the pot a second time and keeps it. He sends word that the pot has died.
(Modus Leibinc.) A sailor's wife bears a son in his absence and says that it came from eating snow. Later the husband makes away with the boy who, he says, melted in the sun.
One partner claims a deer he has captured in his bird-net. The other pretends to be watching water flow upstream.
Courtier rebukes king by asking that he be given an ecclesiastical post.
Bishop reverses the order.

A scholar, showing his skill in logic, proves that two chickens (or eggs) on the table are really three. His father (or host) takes one chicken for himself, gives the other to the mother, tells son that he can have the third one.
A man pledged to give his wife only good words hits her with a prayer book.
Man pledged to do so with his wife follows instructions literally. Beats her a joy to him and a sorrow to her.
A man overcomes his quarrelsome wife by playing the flute as long as she is scolding.
He placates her by telling her that he wants a handsome child.
Man keeps the house, gives the wife the road.
A wife whose husband has beaten her sends a rumor to the sick king that her husband is a skilled physician but will practice only when he is well beaten. He is seized and whipped.

A husband disguises as a priest to hear his wife's confession. She says that she has been mistress of a servant, a knight, a fool, and a priest; i.e., her husband when he was her servant, and later her knight. He had then been a fool for demanding her confession, and was a priest because he had heard it.
The wife has cooked so many dishes that when he complains, she can always supply another. Finally he says, "I had rather eat dung." She produces some.
Wife shows that she does many more tasks in one morning than the husband.
Fault-finding husband threatens to hit wife with shoes. She: "You will have to have some shoes first."
A wife driven from home is allowed by her husband to take her one dearest possession. She takes her sleeping husband and effects reconciliation.
(Women of Weinsberg.) Permitted to carry from the city their dearest possession, they take their husbands.
She retorts that he has the key.
Husband who feigns death hears wife propose this. He upbraids her; she replies: "If you had really died I should have given myself up to be burnt."
Husband declares that he will drown himself. The wife shows him a deep spot in the stream.
Husband (son) tells her that they have decided that each man may have many wives. Gullible wife believes it.
A woman demands money for a visit which she dreams of having had from a merchant. She is shown the money in a mirror.

A penitent confesses that a plan to sin had entered his mind. Priest tells him that the thought is as good as the deed. Assesses four florins as penance. Penitent says that he had only had it in his mind to give the florins; he must take the thought for the deed.

A monk gives a man a stick instead of the candle the man has wanted to burn before a holy picture. The monk says that it will have the same effect as if the candle were burned. The man takes out his purse and lets the monk touch it.

A man receives a present of a hare. Later a crowd comes to him for entertainment saying that they are friends of the man who presented the hare. This happens a second time. He serves them clear water. "It is the soup from the soup of the hare."
Man claims ownership of bulls because he has dreamed of them. He is given their shadows.
Clerk tells person to imagine that blue cloth is green. The customer walks out without paying. The clerk asks for payment; the customer tells clerk to imagine he has been paid.
The monkey to the grocer: "You sold half water and half milk."
Shows him the Host through window, and says: "Have hope and imagine you receive it." The man shows the priest a coin through the window, and repeats the same phrase.
Jester later redecorates house in fragments of pictures.
A man wants to borrow an ass. The owner goes to see what the ass says. The ass is unwilling.
A man wants to borrow an ass. The owner says that the ass is not at home. The ass brays and the borrower protests. "Will you believe an ass and not a graybeard like me?"

When told by servants their master is not at home, man says it is a fool that goes out in such midday heat. Whereupon master sticks his head out of the window, saying "Thou who art moving about at this time art the big fool: I have been seated all day in my house."

A man asks for credit, although he has always paid cash before. He is refused on these grounds: either (1) he has never found anyone to trust him, (2) he has never bought anything, or (3) he is rich and does not need an extension of time.

The would-be borrower gets one from another neighbor. He overworks the horse and renders him useless. The owner of the horse sues the man who had refused to lend his animal. Reasoning: "If he had lent his horse this would not have happened to mine." Settled by compromise.
Two farmers ask a priest to lend two measures of grain to each of them. The priest refuses to lend them any but donates one measure to each. Thus he saves two measures.
An abbot presents a lawyer with a fine horse. Later the abbot comes to Rome and calls on the lawyer for help. The latter returns the horse. "I did not know that you had a lawsuit in Rome."

A young man is ransomed by giving God as surety for the ransom money. He fails to return as agreed. The creditor sees a wealthy abbot, who says that he is a servant of God. He robs the abbot and when the young man finally appears he tells the latter than the debt is already paid by God's servant.
A student leaving the university sends back a small coin to pay for the knowledge he is carrying away, although he says that he is really paying too much.
A trickster when told that food cooking is clothes being boiled retaliates by throwing his dirty hose into the pot.
An abbot has his innkeeper treat his guests with the most shameful neglect. A guest retaliates by telling the abbot that he has been very sumptuously entertained. The innkeeper is discharged.
A man at a banquet is neglected because of his poor clothes. He changes clothes, returns, and is honored. "Feed my clothes," he says, "for it is they that are welcomed."
Recites a satirical rhymed grace.
Otherwise she would be glad to give something to eat. A joker brings along the necessary spoons.
No butter on the bread.

Man refused hospitality tells rich man he is a relative. Asked for the "connection," he tells him there is a box connection. Rich man not understanding, man explains his cart is made of box wood and is tied to a rich man's box tree. Rich man, ashamed, entertains him with all due respect.
Neglected guest thus gets his portion of food.

A cuts the meat and puts all the good things on his side. B turns the plate around: "See how all things turn about in this world." A turns it back: "However the world may turn, with good friends like us the plate will always remain the same."

He serves small birds and a roast chicken to his guests. Guests each take a small bird, leaving only the chicken when the plate reaches the host. He takes the whole chicken saying: "Since everyone has a bird, I must have one too."
It attracts his dog and he is exposed.
He keeps calling for more bed clothes. The host finally piles a ladder, a trough, etc., on top of him until he calls for help.
Guests call each other ox and ass. Host offers green grass for the first and fodder for the second.
Tells guests husband uses it against guests. They flee. Tells husband they left because she refused to give them pestle. Husband pursues to give them the pestle, but they run the faster.
Food being considered unclean then, guests depart empty but unwitting of true reason.
Thus man treats his sons-in-law.
Tells them he has that morning confessed man with plague.

He is asked a question by his master each time he tries to eat a date, so that he always has to spit out the date. He revenges himself that night when the master tries to carry on an intrigue with his wife's maid. He comes with his answers at embarrassing moments.
A rabbi who has been inhospitably treated is afterwards invited to dinner. He keeps the guests so amused by his jokes that they fail to eat and the feast is spoiled.
Fox serves the food on a flat dish so that the crane cannot eat. Crane serves his food in a bottle.
It is the only place he can find at the royal table not covered with gold and jewels.
Servant who leaves off the salt is instructed to bring in the step-ladder so as to see what is missing.
Stingy host rebuked.
Mother of girl tells suitor that she cannot have him burning her midnight oil. The next night he brings his own lamp and a can of oil, tells her he will stay all night if he wishes.
Answer of hungry man when host asks for suggestion for a picture to be painted of something that has not been seen.
None comes.

A poet gives the emperor a poem, hoping for a reward The emperor later gives the poet a poem in return. The poet thereupon sends the emperor two pennies, saying that this is all the money he has. The emperor, seeing that he is defeated in the exchange, laughs and becomes the poet's friend.

A clown asks for alms and receives nothing. He then throws pellets made of herbs at the steward, saying that there is great power in words, herbs, and stones: he has tried two of them and plans to try the third. He is given alms.

A peasant always puts a bad penny into the offering. The priest has a penny baked in a wafer and gives it to the peasant at communion. The peasant, unable to swallow it, thinks that he is possessed of the devil. The priest asks whether he has ever done wrong with a penny, secures confession and a pledge of reform.
Parishioners put base money into the collection. The priest burns sulphur instead of incense He tells them that their money will buy nothing better.
Preacher tells parishioners (regarding the day's offering): "You will get back 100 for 1." Donor of a penny: "I'll be glad to get back my capital!"
Stingy king insists on trickster asking any boon desired. By asking king to perform disgusting act, trickster compels king to give expensive gift.
As the fool brings the new ass home everyone wants to know how much it cost. He has all publicly assemble and announces just what it cost.

Philosopher gives a penny to a man who throws stones at him but advises him that it will be wiser to throw at one who can afford to give more. The advice is followed and the rascal is arrested and hanged.
A man who has stomach ache from eating bad bread is treated for his eyes so that he will thereafter be able to tell good bread from bad.

A particularly obnoxious man delays others while he haggles over prices with a butcher. Meanwhile a parson takes the three fish the man has laid down and puts them into his large sleeves. The man is angry and searches in vain for them. The parson then shows them and advises him not to let people cheat him.
A man steals a large sum, keeps half and distributes the rest among five hundred persons. He says that he has committed one wrong but has done five hundred good deeds.

Entertained by a lord, they say that they are going to certain waters to recover their appetites. They are taken to a chamber and locked in for a day They recover their appetites without further journeying.
The owner of a dog has him given Christian burial. The bishop thereupon pretends that the dog has left the church a large legacy.
The ass absents himself from the parliament of beasts. The lion sends the fox and the wolf to summon him. He pleads his charter of exemption and invites the fox to read it in his hoof.
A man buys three pounds of meat. His wife eats it and says that the cat ate it. The man weighs the cat and finds that it does not weigh three pounds.
Loaded with salt, he falls down in the river and lightens his burden. His master then loads him with sponges so that the next time the ass tries the trick he increases his load.
A Jew, fallen into a pit, refuses to be rescued on Saturday, his Sabbath. The next day he calls for help but the Christians refuse to rescue him on Sunday, their Sabbath.

A parson boasts that when he asks his maid if certain work is done she always answers that it has been done long ago. A guest wagers that she can be trapped if she is asked whether she has thrown the parson's suit of clothes into the tub of water. She overhears the wager and has the suit in the water before he asks the question.
A tenant promises his daughter to his master against her will. The master sends for "that which was promised him." The daughter sends the horse, and it is taken into the master's chamber.
Soldiers are admitted neither to hell nor to heaven. They remind Peter of his denial of Christ. He admits them.

A woman tells her brother of God's omniscience. When he is ill and the priest has been called, he creeps under some straw and hides. The priest leaves. The man: "If God were so omniscient he might have found me for the priest."

A guardian of monks in need of food approaches the prince The prince is busy and says that he will permit the guardian but a single word. The guardian says, "Soup", and secures all the food he wants from the prince.

Two men on parting agree to share everything they receive. One returns with much money. His friend reminds him of the pact. He replies that he has also received many wounds. The friend is willing to forego dividing.

They are forced to sleep together because of lack of room. The blacksmith tells the horsetrader that he often dreams that he is striking the bellows and that he may accidently strike him in the night. The horsetrader retaliates by dreaming that he is riding a horse and drives the spurs into the blacksmith.
When he claims to see two roast chickens, his wife takes the one chicken away and he falls into the fire trying to find the other.

A woman crosses herself when she meets a priest, as if he were the devil. She says that meeting a priest always brings her bad luck. The priest knocks her down and steps on her. "As ye believe, so shall it be."

One king sends large sack of seed to the other to represent the number of his soldiers. The second replies with a small bag of peppercorns: "My army is small compared to yours but has all the power of the peppercorn compared to your lifeless seed."
An apprentice harpmaker is blamed that he has not made the harp sound. He throws the harp at his master's head and breaks it to pieces: "There you have your sound."

A nobleman embezzles money from the public treasury. When counsellors urge an accounting, he replies that he is ready as soon as they have themselves made an accounting of all their transactions. They are ready to let well enough alone.

A traitor is hanged in effigy naked. Later the citizens sue for peace and arrange a meeting. They find him in a hot room swathed with many blankets. He says that he has taken cold when the night wind blew on him as he hung naked from the gallows.
A shoemaker's apprentice greases boots as he would grease a fowl. The owner in anger returns and breaks a window.

The cobbler learns the minstrel's songs and sings them so that the minstrel loses his trade. He in turn sews the cobbler's leather into crazy shapes. He has done no worse than the cobbler, who marred his songs. When they sing together the people realize the contrast and patronize the minstrel.

A man failing to receive alms in a village, rings the bell for mass. He tells the sexton that he is ringing because of the death of brotherly love. The sexton rings another bell. It is for the death of the other man's patience.

In order to test a favorite, a king says that he is going to retire from the world and offers the regency to the favorite. On advice from his philosopher, the favorite says that he is going to accompany the king into retirement.
Ruler to servant stealing his game: "If you wish any I'll send you some."

Merchant at inn deprives monk of fowl. "It's against the rules of your order." Later the monk undertakes to help merchant across stream. In the middle of the stream he asks the merchant if he has any money. "Yes." The monk drops him in the water. "It's against the rules of our order to have any money on us."
Man asks directions to a certain place. Native attempts to give directions, then in disgust says, "If I wanted to go to   , I wouldn't start from here."

An undesirable abbot furnishes adequate grounds for his dismissal when he cannot find the needle that all monks are supposed to carry with them. If careless in little things he will be careless in great.
Oracle that the first of three sons to kiss his mother will be king. One of them kisses the earth, mother of all. He succeeds.
Peasant calls on lawyer for advice. Lawyer says that he is busy. Peasant returns with lamb. The lawyer hears its bleat and grants the audience.

A she-camel has passed, blind in one eye; on the one side she carries wine and on the other vinegar; two men lead her, one a heathen and the other a Jew. Solution: She is recognized as a she-camel by the footprints; she is blind because she feeds on only one side of the road; the wine dropping down has soaked into the earth; the vinegar makes bubbles; the heathen is not so careful in his manners as is the Jew.
After dinner the king begins to dance. He is therefore called illegitimate. His mother acknowledges an intrigue with a dancer.
It falls apart; therefore it was kneaded by a weak person.
Told by shape of hoofs.
Has drooping ears.
Can not get enough to eat.
The jewel is warm.
Cauldron has been buried in river. Thief has no taste of salt on his body: he must have been immersed in fresh water recently.
Another (interlocutor) identifies them.

LOCATIONS: Africa, Angola, California, India, Magoun, Romania, Spain
REFERENCES: . Roumanian, India, Spanish Exempla, cf. Africa (Angola)
DESCRIPTION: She saves herself on a tree. The fox, who knows a hundred tricks, is captured.
Female jackal saves herself and husband by quick thinking.
Rainy season or winter (debate between animals). Solution by man as umpire: neither as cold as windy season.
Makes the horses run by binding a bundle of hay to the shaft.
Penny demanded of every bad man, two pennies of every good man. Thus two pennies received from every man.
Husband is imprisoned and wife detained by judge. She accuses her husband of having stolen her.
The messenger arranges it so that the king says the words in the form of a question.

A nobleman seeing an ass letting water in a river remarks that it reminds him of his king. He explains to the king that just as the ass puts water where it is already plentiful, so the king awards wealth where it is not needed. The king says that it is all in the nature of the nobleman's fate. Subsequent events prove this.
Clever man avoids saying "one" (which king considers a curse on his one eye) by saying that first is the rock that must not be called by name.
Separates hogs into tenors, bassos, etc. So arranges them that when he pricks them they render a tune.
King requires story. Poet recites list, ending with account of the destruction of his dun. Reparation granted.

When steadily unable to be admitted to presence of a king, a clever man demands an interview saying he is the son of God come down to earth and will condescend to see the king. When asked to show the king Heaven and the path to it, the pretender retorts that when he was sent down by the Father, he was told to look to matters relating to this earth.
Two men cannot agree to bride's dowry. Third party tells each parent that the other has agreed. Marriage. "Now that you are relatives you can settle it between yourselves."

REFERENCES: . Swiss, Hindu, N. A. Indian, Oceanic (German New Guinea, Banks Is., New Hebrides)

DESCRIPTION: Sheep, duck, and cock in peril The duck swims; the cock flies to the mast.
Three men greeted by a stranger. Quarrel as to whom he greeted. "I greeted the biggest fool among you." A contest is held in which tales are told to decide which is the biggest fool.
Both are put to death for their foolishness.
A wise man is persuaded to taste water which has turned many persons into fools. He also becomes a fool.
A wise man refuses to join a foolish crowd who stayed out in an unexpected rain after a long drought. He is punished by them for being a fool.
Failing to convince people, they go into a cave. After the shower they come out. The people call them fools.
Stupid people and gossipers are praising it.
Leaves when placed between two fools at table.
Unwilling to admit that he does not know what a honeycomb is, a stupid man asks the innkeeper's wife to roast a slice of honeycomb.
He squeezes the inside out and takes the covering for a sack.
(Similar for watermelon, plums.)
The sheep does not understand why the pig being carried to slaughter shrieks.
A farmer takes some of his master's urine for examination. The doctor asks where the man comes from. "You will soon see," says the man, expecting the analysis to tell.
Numskull keeps the candle at his right side as he goes to bed so that he can do so.
Shoot it and build a rampart around it.
Only after his return from an absence does he notice it.
Peasants take their old crucifix to an artist for a new one. The artist asks them whether they want a living or dead crucifix. Argument: living God takes less for upkeep and he can be killed later.

Preacher in backwoods asks congregation members who are friends of Jesus to rise. No one rises. "What, are there no friends of Jesus in this house?" A cowboy rises to his feet: "Stranger, I don't know who this man Jesus is. I never heard of him before, but I'll stand up for any man who hasn't got any more friends than he has."
Backwoods preacher tells couple that they are living in darkness. The woman responds that she has been trying for years to get her husband to cut a window in the house.
Pergamus, a rival city of Luca, objects to the reading of the Evangelium secundum Lucam, insisting that it be "secundum Pergamum".
An ignorant schoolmaster interprets many of the texts of scripture as commands for the priests to live lives of luxury.
The questions are not given in the order he expects; comic results.
Mayor asked about where he lives, names his village and directs the enquirer to a big high house.
Thinks latrine is kitchen, refuses to take a walk because he fears high houses will fall upon him, etc.

A stupid man at confession says, "I confess myself guilty of all sins that I have committed since Christ's birth." "Are you so old?" "Yes, and I have a brother who is three years older than I." Wesselski Bebel II 106 No. 17;
Then they explain that Lent will be short because it has been a short winter.
Woman misinterprets calendar notation "February 22, Wash. B'day." Washes their bee-hives.

The numskull groom on his wedding night does not know how to get to the bed, the curtains being drawn. He scales one of the posts, clambers to the canopy, falls upon his bride below, who screams for help.
Fool asks what he is to talk about when guests arrive. Is told: "Their wives and family." He asks the archbishop about his family.
The names of the participants are not the same as those in his sample form.
I know you well enough, you have put on a blue coat.
In the man's absence eats the mare.
Hero in search of monster brings home a dog, zebra, etc. thinking it is the animal he seeks.
Servant sent to bring in cows is found chasing rabbits.
Fool trying to steal goat in dark catches thieving tiger.
Rides him.
He shoots several times before he notices the trouble.
Sailors light a fire on his back.
The bird who tries to keep the monkeys from this error is killed for her pains.
Numskulls therefore throw away their fish.
Bites tiger who tries to play flute.
Four blind men feel an elephant's leg, tail, ear and body, respectively, and conclude it is like a log, a rope, a fan, and something without beginning or end.
In a ghost house he is thought to be a tailor who snips the devil with his scissors.
The godless man is cheated and attacks a bear thinking it is a saint, and barely escapes with his life.
The strong man meets a bear in the forest, takes it for a German and struggles with it. Having strangled the bear, fears he has killed a man.
Man with abhorrence for corpse sleeps with one thinking it alive.
Killed with guns and spears.
Numskull thinks he has hatched out an ass's egg. He thinks that the rabbit which runs out is the colt.
Small boy examines bedbug eggs under pillow every morning. One morning he finds a terrapin there. "I don't see how we raised this so quick."
Cuts his mouth.
Start morning journey evening before.
Numskull tries to sell it.
Knocked to pieces.
It drops on the floor and the man thinks the place is haunted.
Fools knock it in two.
Becomes red.
I am a psalmsinger and a worshiper of God!"
I am a righteous man and a psalm singer."
Fool in the dark mistakes cat's eyes for embers. Is attacked by the cat and he thinks it is the devil.
The numskull sees a cow drink from a pool where the moon is reflected. The moon goes under a cloud. He thinks the cow has eaten the moon and slaughters her to recover it.
A numskull sees the moon in the water and throws a rope in to rescue it, but falls in himself. He sees the moon in the sky. At least the moon was saved!
Man (animal) sees moon reflected in water and, thinking it a cheese, dives for it.
Fools dive for it.

LOCATIONS: Africa, India, South Africa, Spain, Vitry
DESCRIPTION: Crossing a stream with meat in his mouth he sees his reflection; thinking it another dog with meat he dives for it and loses his meat.
Prides herself on her beauty.
Attempts to drink the lake dry.
The next day when she sees fish, she lets it escape.
Thinks it is gold.
Meantime rascal steals the fruit itself.

Foreigner asks who owns property, clothing, servants; whose wife an attractive woman is; whose funeral is in progress? Answer to each question is "I don't understand," which foreigner takes to be a person's name.
A cleric is asked whether he is of legitimate birth ("de legitimo thoro"). "No, I am not from that place; I am from Schmich."
Word for wife is similar, so wife is covered.
Father finds Prince Sobur.
People dive into tank to recover treasure they think he has lost.
or giving the name of the young man she wants.
Hears a rooster crow, saying: "Cocky kuko! It's the same everywhere!" He returns home.
Numskull burns field.
Hunchback springs into it to burn to his death.
Fool kills his wife because he thinks that she has eaten part of them.
Simpleton lets it run over.
Actually his wife has added cold water.
Cook eats one; none left.
The peasant entertains a priest at tea. Making it, puts in all the tea, six pounds of sugar, a piece of bacon, etc.
Small boy is at home to watch the dinner. Runs into church, calls out to his mother that the sheep's head has eaten all the dumplings (or butted them out of the pot).
They fill the room.
As he is making water he hears a brook flowing and mistakes what it is. He waits for a day and a half.

A fool, liking the shoes on the feet of a man hanged on a gallows, cuts off the swollen feet in order to carry off the shoes. In the room in which he sleeps that night is a newborn calf. The next morning the man takes the shoes but leaves the feet. Peasants agree that the calf has eaten the man all but the feet. They burn the house to destroy the calf.
Other animals are shouting at him.
Peasants go to visit the sea. They see a waving flax-field, and, thinking it is the sea, jump in to swim.
Mistaken for sea.
Fool sees the image of Christ elevated on Ascension Day to the beams of the church. He accuses Christ of having fooled the people into believing that he has gone to heaven.

A man refuses to have anything to do with the crucifix because once an image of Christ has fallen on him in church and broken his arm. Reminded that this image is not the same, he replies that it is the son of the other and is just as bad.
Maidservant on way to church on Palm Sunday meets priests leading ass on which Jesus rode. The maid runs home and tells her mistress that the Lord has mounted and has just gone away.
At a wedding after a period of silent prayer the bishop begins an antiphony. The fools walks up and strikes the bishop: "You have made this shouting in the church."
Draws his sword.
Numskull refuses communion because his sister died shortly after eating the bread.
Makes ridiculous report to his king.
Good people do not need them; bad people do not reform as a result of them.
A nobleman praises his falcon. His fool, supposing they were praising the falcon as food, kills the bird, but is disappointed in the taste.

A pope in writing to a king says, "To our dear son Frederick." Upon hearing this the fool cries out, "That is a lie; he is no priest's son. I knew his father and mother and they were both honest people."
A fool sees a boat (with rowers) obedient to commands, "Right! Left!" etc. He asks what kind of wood the boat is made of. Later he gets a log of that wood and tries to make it obey commands.
A landlord in anger throws a dish out the window. The numskull throws the rest out, thinking that the landlord wanted to eat outdoors.
Through misunderstanding one of the men jumps into the river. He calls out; the others think that he wants them to follow, and all jump in and are drowned.
He strikes at a fly on the bishop's nose because it seems to be killing the bishop.
The delegate slips and falls, cursing: "The devil may take you!" The serfs outside think this was the congratulation, and all cry in chorus: "You and your family!"
On the way home from town he destroys his purchases.
Foolish soldier at guard by cannon therefore quits.
He has been sent to mill to have it ground.
They have frightened his fleeing ass from the water.
Numskulls hear birds calling and give them gifts.
When he comes for his money the bird flies to a trash pile, where the fool finds a treasure.
Next day he finds a treasure there.
Treasure found.
He is told not to sell to talkative people. The statue is the only one he can find who is not talkative.
Fool sells goods to a statue and when it will not pay him knocks it to pieces. He finds a treasure inside.

An ox strays on the rascal's land but escapes from him. The next week he sees the ox yoked up and gives him a beating. The master is astonished. The rascal: "Let me alone; he knows well enough what he has done."
A man's coat is stolen when he leaves his ass for a moment. He takes the saddle off the ass and says that he will give it back if the ass will return the coat.
Blamed for not teaching calf better.
On a rainy day when shot will not go a man flogs the shot. It goes and he shoots a deer.
In a land where the sickle is not known the new sickle cuts off the head of a man. It is drowned.
The men hang themselves in the attempt.
Numskull sees cracks in the ground and feels so sorry for them that he greases them with the butter he is taking home.
Numskull hears limbs creaking in the wind. He is sorry for them and holds them apart. While he is caught between them his enemies take advantage of him.
When the wagon stops its creaking, fool decides it has died; he cremates it.
A numskull climbs a tree to help a cuckoo so that he may call louder than the one in the neighboring forest. Meanwhile his horse is eaten by a wolf.
Rascal misappropriates funds.
A fool eats nuts. A kernel slips from him. The fool: "Everything tries to escape from death."
The woman thinks the boiling pot is complaining.
Numskulls try to take home a wave of the sea in a bamboo rod. At home when it refuses to wave they say that it is homesick for its mother, the sea.
Numskull thinks money piece covered with perspiration after he has held it for awhile is weeping.
Numskull lets one roll down hill; sends the other to bring it back.

REFERENCES: England, Missouri French, N. A. Indian, Spanish

DESCRIPTION: The man asks his wife if it has arrived before him, finds that it has not. "I thought not. I came a shorter way."
Since he is a swift runner they expect it to reach the landlord in time.
Fool directs them as he places them in stream.
Fool believes they can be taught.
Fool made to believe that his ass (ox) has been educated and has become mayor.
He thinks they are dancing when he sees them waving.
The woman tries to tire out her rival's boat so as to win the race, but only tires herself.
A boy roasts snails and they make noise in cooking. "Wretches, your house burns and yet you sing!"
Fool puts black clothes on his hen's necks. He tells people that they mourn their mother.
Fools chain a wheelbarrow, bitten by a mad dog, lest it bite others.
An old woman enraptured with the sound of a cathedral organ prays for it to come to her house and gives it directions as to where she lives.
A man has drunk so much of various wines that he is sick. He says to the wines, "Have peace among yourselves and don't quarrel or I'll throw you out the window."
On his deathbed refuses to forgive nails which ruined his tools.
Sea says that it is calm itself, but the wind blew it up and broke the ship.
A boy recently home from school sees his mother trying to catch the cock. "Don't mother, don't break his freedom or we will suffer for it."
Begs that people not believe what calf said.
A woman wants her hen to lay many eggs. Overfeeds her and she stops laying altogether.
Cautions people to be quiet and not frighten the eggs.
When the calf will not drink, the peasant woman throws the water on its back.
When the customer refuses to take the milk he puts it back into the goat's mouth so that it will flow back into the udder.
A farmer who wanted to fatten a pig fed it only twice a day. When told to feed it three times a day he says, "A working man must have more to eat than a pig."
Decision: it lives on air.
Fools build an enclosure to keep in the cuckoo. She flies over the hedge. They say that they have not built the hedge high enough.
All are killed.
Numskull considers what will happen if river burns up.
The brother who owns the front end tries to drive the cow and will not let the owner of the rear end milk her.
(Only frightens it.)
A man has a cat trained to hold up lighted candles on its head. The king has a mouse let loose. The cat drops the candle and chases the mouse.
Later in his net they jump about without the aid of the flute.
Fool says, "Just as soon as the body of a colt bred from this mare is in proper proportion to its ears you will have a fine horse."
He says, "Such is bad conduct. If I were to do that they would say that I was eating it."
Sticks needle through it.
Wrings the child's neck.
Dies.
Fails in the war.
None of them feeds him, supposing that the others have. The mule dies.
A trickster cuts off the bill and legs of a stork to make him look more like a real bird.

A fool is asked where the river is fordable. He says, "Everywhere." The man tries to ride across and is almost drowned. The fool, "Those little ducks were able to cross here; why couldn't a big fellow like you?"
A dog has eaten 14 pounds of butter; the fool squeezes 16 pounds from him.
He does so.
An object falls into the sea from a boat. Numskulls mark the place on the boat-rail to indicate where it fell.
Numskulls leave a knife in the field, marking the place by putting it under a heavy cloud. Next day the cloud is gone and the knife lost.
Vessel left under mound in sand while owner is swimming. Others make similar mounds so that it is lost.
Numskull looks for bread that he threw away a year before.
Good coins are supposed to swim, counterfeit to sink.
He wants to take it home.
Numskull plans to dig a hole so as to have a place to throw the earth from his excavation.
A peasant hangs boots and an accompanying letter on a telegraph wire, expecting them to reach the city.
A man stands before mirror with his eyes shut to see how he looks in his sleep.
Numskull asked to identify corpse tries to do so by his cough.
Numskull objects to unhealthy place for his tomb.
They put meal in the boiling current of the ice hole and then, one after another, they jump in to taste the porridge.
A numskull cries from a tower and then runs away to see how far his voice will reach.
A numskull ties yarn around the stove to keep the heat from escaping.
Numskull tries to find the time of night.
They accuse each other of eating all the pears.
Numskull stretches out his hands toward the fire across the river.
So says the numskull after riding to town on his stick horse.
Fool told that he needed only the two.
Fool loses his mother's corpse on way to funeral. Mistakes old woman for mother and substitutes her.
An old woman who has forgotten to knead it in the dough throws it into the stove.
Several others have burned up.
In a storm on the ice, numskulls stick needles into the ice to keep from blowing away.
But the man who uses the crowbar is to blame for the downfall of the wall.
He comes to a stream but not wishing to get his feet wet he sits down to wait for the stream to run down. He helps to bale the stream out with a hazelnut shell and keeps it up for months.
Absurd attempt to punish sea.
Sleeps with a negro. His friends blacken him during the night. When he is waked up, he complains that they have waked the wrong man.
He barks at people.
A numskull ties a pumpkin to his leg at night so that he shall know himself in the morning. Someone ties the pumpkin to another's leg and the numskull is not sure of his identity next morning.
A stranger helps them with a switch. (Usually get them mixed up when they sit down to bathe their feet.)
Finds it only when the rest ride away and he takes the only one left.
I didn't get on backward but the horse seems to be left-handed.
Are really pounding each other.
Numskulls conclude that one of their number is drowned.
They then count the holes.
Why?
Ten men are called in; each is to take a goose. If all have a goose, there are ten. One man is left without one. Numskull: "You should have taken one before they were all gone."
While the merchant is making calculations, he asks the age of his youngest daughter, the elder daughter, and the mother, and always adds this to the number he has reached.
Numskull goes to buy goods for his wife.
As result of his absent-mindedness he is given a heavy mortar to take to his master. The latter makes him return it as punishment.
Absurd results.
Air-castles.
In his excitement he breaks the jar.
In his excitement he breaks the glassware.
In her excitement she breaks all the eggs.
Proud milkmaid tosses her head (or kicks the pail in her sleep) and spills the milk.
Old woman thinks about the horse she is finally to get from the sale. In her imagination she spurs it and spills the milk.
In his excitement he wakes the deer, who runs off.

One man plans to buy sheep; another says that he shall not drive them across the bridge. They quarrel over the sheep, which have not yet been acquired. A third numskull to convince them of their foolishness pours all his meal out in the water so as to show them the empty sack. "How much meal is in the sack?" he asks. "None." "There is just that much wit in your heads."
Does the ghee protect the saucer, or the saucer the ghee?

(Clever Else.) Girl sent to cellar to get wine to serve the suitor begins weeping over the troubles of the child which she might have if she married the suitor. Her parents join her. Meanwhile the suitor leaves.
She has threatened to throw the child to the wolf.
A butcher has threatened to hit him with a piece of meat.
Is told that money is thus made.
He sees it dangling.
A woman plans to sacrifice her only son so that the gods will permit her to give birth to another son.

REFERENCES: Bolte Zs. Breton, India, Indonesia, Japanese, Spanish Exempla
DESCRIPTION: Three wishes will be granted: used up foolishly.
Everything to turn to gold.
Birds eat it up.
He blows his nose and it pulls out long.

The man complains that he is a mere slave of his stomach. His wish is granted and the stomach taken away from him. He discovers soon that life has become very uninteresting to him, and recovers his stomach again.
Killed by jackals.
Given to two persons with opposite results.
One begins pulling linen out of a box; other in anger begins throwing water on the pig and must do so all day.
One gets help in work, other in striking his wife (etc.).
(The covetous and the envious). A can have a wish, but B will get twice the wish. A wishes that he may lose an eye, so that B may be blind.
A husband, given three wishes, transfers one to his wife, who wastes it on a trifle; in his anger he wishes the article in her body and must use the third to get it out.
Wife uses two transferred wishes selfishly. Husband kills wife and uses remaining wish to his advantage.
Husband wishes her into a pig; son must use third wish to restore her.
Granted any wish, the fool chooses a trifle.

LOCATIONS: Africa, Cf., England, India, Indonesia, Nigeria, United States
REFERENCES: . Cf. Africa (Ibo, Nigeria), English, India, Indonesia, N. A. Indian (Zuni)
DESCRIPTION: Finally nothing left.
A numskull has paid twice the regular amount for a shave. The barber shaves the wife.
In the grain sale the fool sells a third of a cask for the price of a fourth, thinking that he is cheating the buyer.
The fool sells two fox-skins pulled into each other.
Thinks to cheat the buyer.
A fool buys nine eggs and sells ten for the same price. He says that business is improving.
The woman sells cows and gets one of them back as a pledge for the unpaid purchase price.
The auctioneer praises the man's worthless cow so much in his speech that the man takes her back himself.
A numskull having an over-short turban for sale at auction warns the prospective buyer that it is too short.
The numskull tells the thief where his door-key, his cakes, and his roasts are and warns him not to steal them.
Thief leaves sign "Here it is not."
A man finds a treasure, but is robbed by porters whom he has employed to rid him of the trouble of carrying it.
The recipient is also a numskull and doesn't know its value.
Choice of eating 100 onions, receiving 100 blows, or paying 100 coins. Fool tries onions in vain, then the blows, and finally must give the coins.
She has been falsely told that the sack is filled with gold.
In a land in which cats are not known, one is bought at a great price. It eats many mice. By misunderstanding, they think the cat is a monster. In order to get rid of it they set the house on fire.
Woman wishing to punish a cat fastens cotton to its tail and lights it. The whole village is burnt.
The house catches fire and burns.
Snakes eat numskull's family.
A farmer troubled with mice eating his cheese places a cat in the tub with the cheese. She eats the mice and the cheese.
Woman puts cat in flour bin to catch a mouse. The cat eats the pie in the bin and loses interest in the mouse.
Peasant asks a nobleman's help against a rabbit. The nobleman chases the rabbit on horseback for five days and ruins the peasant's crop.
When it gives too much heat numskulls decide to move it instead of putting out the fire.
A cow fouls a church. Numskulls try to move the church with ropes.
To keep croaking frogs from disturbing him, the fools shoot at the frogs all night.
It makes him the more violent.
A man is bitten by a dog. On the advice of an old woman he rubs bread on the wound and gives it to the dog. All dogs will bite him if they thus get double reward.
Soon all are gone.
A calf gets its head caught in a pot. A fool cuts off the calf's head and then breaks the pot to get it out.
Farmer takes a few feet off his journey and lifts a wheelbarrow over 22 stiles in so doing.
Boy has rice in joined hands and arms around a pillar. Afraid to move lest rice be lost. Roof is removed and boy lifted over pillar.
When this plan does not succeed, they gradually pull down the house to get light.
They are put in one big pool, but an eel eats them up.
Numskull ties their beaks and weights them down in the river with stones.
Numskull is to carry a can of oil with especial care since it has a little hole in it. In order to find the hole he turns the can about and lets all the oil run out.
A peasant kills his hen so that he can immediately get all the eggs she will lay during the next year.
He has been told to stick it in his sleeve. It is lost.
Numskulls take out the clothing and cover the trunks to keep rain off.
The numskull (stupid ogre) is shot.
It rolls into the lake.
Animals make him king, but detect him from his cry and turn him out.
Sticks his head into it and gets drowned himself.
The cow falls off and the man is pulled up the chimney.
Is dragged.
Bees sting the cow.
Crow pecks self loose and injures jackal's tail.
Falls and is killed.
Falls to his death.
Falls.
They all fall.
She asks question and he drops her when he answers.
He and all holding on to him fall.
They place hampers on top of one another. The fool has them take out the two on the bottom.
They fall on floating leather.
Falls and injures self and others.
Fool aims stone at inquirer saying, "I struck him like this." Inquirer is killed.
Cause great itching.

REFERENCES: Biscayans pour medicine into rice for broth with which to cook rice. Spanish

DESCRIPTION: Numskull having enough food to last him eleven out of the twelve months fasts the entire first month so as to get the ordeal over. He starves with eleven months' supply on hand.
Fox says, "If your sense were as long as your beard, you would look for exits as well as entrances."

REFERENCES: India, Indonesia, Japanese, Spanish Exempla, West Indies

DESCRIPTION: Caught.
Caught.
Rescued by wife.
Pleads successfully that he was trying to awaken the household and prevent theft.
Caught.
The fool sent in by thieves is told to bring out the heaviest thing. As this is a grain-grinder and he cannot carry it, he wakes the master of the house to help him.
Caught.
They will not help each other since the fewer thieves there are the more there is to share.
Caught.
The flea bites the man and jumps away. The bed is searched and the louse killed.
As soon as they have killed the other dogs the wolves then turn on the wolf-colored dogs which they have persuaded to join them.
Breaks both legs.
Trying to draw both legs on at once.
The shirt is sewed together at the neck. The man's head is cut off so that the shirt can be put on him.
Fool laces bedcovering to shoe.
People row to land and fetch water from a spring to put out the fire.
Fools carry log (millstone) down hill. They realize that they might have rolled it down. They therefore carry it back up hill to roll it down.
The porridge in one, the milk in another.
In preparation, the feet are cut off the evening before.
The ship has no bottom and is so narrow that nothing can get into it.
It melts.
The first lets his axe fall. The others throw theirs in the same place.
It does not occur to him to dismount.
too often. When the wolf really comes no one believes him.
He hopes to capture the lion, but loses all his beasts.
The dog: "What good to lock us up from the wolf when he is with us?"
Before eating his booty the numskull sleeps.

A numskull sees a cheese by the side of the road and tries to lift it up with his sword, but the sword is too short. He leaves the cheese and goes away to borrow a longer sword. Meantime someone else takes the cheese.
Meantime other birds eat the rabbit.
A fool in celebration of the capture of a deer puts his clothes on the bound deer. He throws a knife to cut the deer's throat but the knife cuts the snare and the deer runs away with the clothes.
Kites carry them off.
He finds two children bathing in the river and carries one to his hole. He tells the child to wait while he goes for the other child. Both children escape.
Washed with water, salt melts away.
A man about to be hanged keeps asking for his red cap which he has left in prison. He has no thought of his real peril.
A man about to be hanged is very particular about his bread lest it impair his health.
A man who has hurt his head in trying to hang himself has the head dressed by a doctor and then goes and hangs himself.
A schoolmaster whips his pupils to keep them from wrong-doing. He does not wait until after the deed is done.
Son drowns.
He either smothers them during conveyance or scalds them during bathing.
He (she) falls into a study (or chases a dog) while the spigot is open.
Gruel runs out.
A peasant on the way to a feast drinks so much ditch-water that he has no room left for the feast.
Numskulls buy a charter from their lord. In celebration they get drunk and use the seal as a candle and forfeit their charter.
Returns the next day and eats it, thinking that it tastes like chicken.

In castles on opposite hills guards play different tunes during meals. The dog goes toward the music in one castle but when he is about half way up the hill the music begins on the other. He keeps alternating and running up and down until the meals are over and he gets nothing.
Train leaves overpolite travelers.
Officers investigate; meanwhile fire burns town.

A Brahmin washes clothes to purify them. As they hang to dry, a dog walks under them and the Brahmin fears that they are polluted. By putting himself on all-fours like a dog and fastening a leaf like a dog's tail he experiments and decides that the dog must have touched the clothes. He therefore destroys them instead of rewashing them.
A foolish priest is pushed into the water. "I wish I had drowned; then you would all have been disgraced."
A trickster creates men from his excrements (or the like). They melt in the sun.
He is caught on a tree and leaves his claws in the horse's flesh.

A husband tells his wife that he has provisions for every day in the year but one. He proposes to play dead for that one day, thinking that the servants will be overcome with grief and cannot eat. After brief mourning, however, they eat more than usual. The man then thinks to frighten them by rising from the dead. One servant thinking the dead man suffering from devils kills him.
The bear plays havoc. The master threatens to cut off the ears of the meddler. The fool asks his dog not to tell on him.

A fool is told that he is to go to a neighboring castle the next morning. He is to take letters, but the next morning without reporting for instructions the fool goes on the journey. He is given a bag of stones to carry back.
A fool is sent to tell his master's wife that he will not return that day for dinner. He delays the message for a week.
People unacquainted with the sickle.
An abbot is planning to build a palace. The fool: "Why go to all that trouble? Just enjoy yourself with wine, women, and song."
No one comes when he rings to save his home from fire.
One gets the idea of taking it through the gate.
What would you do if you had to live here always?
A magpie is punished by his master, who throws him into a mud puddle. The magpie sees a muddy sow. He says, "You also must have had a quarrel with your master."
Dogs flee from their master because in time of famine he has killed his cattle. If he kills the cattle, he will surely kill the dogs.
Owner thinks he must have been a saint in a former life.
Fool thinks that the angel who comes to question him will pass him by since he has apparently been dead a long time.
They think the vessel will endure the shocks better than the reef.
A numskull who rides an ox to a tournament is ridiculed. He says, "He is swifter than a horse. You should have seen him run when he was only a calf."
A fool who was born under the sign of the Kid declares that he was born under the Goat. "Hasn't it had time in these fifty years to become a goat?"
A priest boasts of his profitable fight with the peasants, where he has received three blows for every one given.
Fool regrets that he had not eaten number seven first since that was the one that brought satisfaction.
A numskull is asked how many daily prayers (Moslem) there are. "Twenty." "There are only four." "I said that there are twenty; that is even better."
Numskull asked the number of commandments replies that there are twenty. He explains to another that he knows there must be more than twenty because the minister would not accept his answer.
A man owns half a house. He wants to sell his half so as to get money to buy the other half and thus have a whole house.
Fool warns those who ride through a field of peas. "You will burn your horses' feet. I burned my mouth with hot peas the other day."
Reason: he tried in vain as a youth to lift a certain stone; he has also tried in vain as an old man.
A thief has stolen a salted cheese. Since one always goes to the well after eating salted cheese, the thief will also come.
He must eventually come here.
After the cover is stolen, the numskulls conclude that the thief will certainly return for the bolster.
Fool therefore will take nothing but milk from his wife and starves the baby.
Fish so reason.
Fish so reason.
Man hearing this breaks oil vessels.
So concludes widow's daughter, who makes her living by spinning, when she sees so much warm goods from England.
He has walked all morning toward a mountain that seems only five miles away, but which is actually sixty miles from his starting point.
A man is robbed and later the same day is given much money. He complains to God, "What was the use of taking from me what you were going to give back to me after stealing from another?"

A man who says that he is the servant of so and so is treated with great consideration. His companion, who says that he is a servant of God is put to work. He cannot understand why God's servant should not be more important than the other.
A fool finds a dead hen and cooks it and serves it for dinner. When reproached he says "How should it be unclean when God has killed it instead of men?"
Nearly starves.
Since he is an old man he should have known that more rain was unwelcome.
One is bottomless; the other is deeper than that.
A rustic refuses to believe reports about hell from a priest who has not been there.
The fool lies still as the thief enters the house, hoping that the thief may find something so that he can take it back from the thief.
Numskull plants seed in daytime and takes it out at night. " Man must guard his treasures" (or "Growing in the daytime is enough").

(1) Student has only one eye: Aristotle says to beware of those whom nature has marked. (2) Student comes from Bremen: no one of consequence comes from there. (3) His name is Nicholas: no one with that name can succeed.
The queen has been told that the peasants have no bread.
The sheep thinks that that is the reason for loss of the contest.
Imitator of the pig's cries applauded. Fool brings real pig but fails.

Thief brought to judgment for breaking into house blames mason for building poor house. Mason blames maker of mortar, who blames potter, who blames pretty woman who diverted his attention. She blames goldsmith who caused her to go for her earrings. Goldsmith has no one to blame but he is too old to make a good execution. Hence a shopkeeper across the way is convicted.
The Indian tribe demands punishment.
Fool shoots full of holes a garment left out at night to dry. " It is a good thing I did not have it on or I would have shot myself.
The latrine is too small for the dining room table to go in.
The fool can sing in the small bathroom but cannot be heard from the minaret. He wants a bathroom built on the minaret so that his voice will carry.
A man believes himself wise because he has a book which he uses but does not understand.
As the fool starts for the doctor the wife changes her mind. He continues to the doctor so as to tell him about it and to say that now he need not come.
Fool goes to astrologer for child's name, but forgets it on way home. Later wife happens to use the word and reminds him. But he cannot see the use of the trip when she already knew this word.

Doctor may not be in and, if he is there, he may not give the medicine. He may give the medicine but it may not have any effect; or, if it does have any, he has to die someday anyway and the medicine will not prevent him from dying.
A man who is away from home writes a letter to his wife but can find no messenger. He delivers the letter himself and then goes on back to where he has been.
Must carry letter in person since no one else can read it.
A peasant falls out of a tree. A neighbor advises him not to climb trees. Another suggests that he always climb down a tree with the same skill and rapidity that he climbed up.
Fool tastes every piece of fruit before giving it to his master.
They speak while doing so.
Travelers say they will not have time to do so when attacked.
Numskull greets old moon as if it were new. " I haven't seen it before, for I have just come to the city. " (Each town thought to have a different moon.)
They get to the top of the hill a few minutes too late to reach it.
Disappointed when it rises without his aid.
The earth would become unbalanced.
Because the stars are the same.
Because his members look the same in the two places.
Guests of host who waters his wine put little fishes into the wine jug. " Now I confess that I put water into the wine; otherwise the fishes could not be there.
A drunken man falls overboard but the skipper refuses to pick him up. " A man who is soaked in wine cannot drown. No part of his body will absorb water.
A fool finding a nun in bed with a bishop and not seeing her face concludes that the bishop must have four feet and so announces it.
Peasants find a dead wolf and debate what killed it. A learned man shows that it froze internally from eating cold flesh.
Bird has chirped five times, which he thinks guarantees him five more years to live.
Numskull buys cloth used only by widows and is therefore convinced.
When this happens he lies down for dead.
Lies down for dead.
The wife tells the husband that a certain pot of preserves is poison. He decides to kill himself and eats the preserves. He believes that he is poisoned and lies down for dead.
A man takes refuge from robbers in an open grave. Robbers see him and ask what he is doing. " It is my grave. I went out to get a breath of air.
A numskull who has lain down thinking he is dead is carried off in a bier. The carriers lose their way. He speaks up, "I always went that way when I was alive.

Neighbors who have heard of the numskull's death insist on the funeral although he is alive and well. He is persuaded and is carried on a bier. They meet a busy man whom they try to persuade to join them. He pleads business. The "dead" man speaks: "It's no use, friend, to try to dissuade them.

A numskull lies in an old grave to see the Day of Judgment. He hears bells and thinks that the Last Day has come. He is beaten by mule-drivers when he tells them that he is a dead man. He returns home and tells his wife that he returns from the dead. " How goes it in heaven? " "For one thing, avoid mule-drivers.
His wife has told him that one tells a dead person by his cold hands and feet. He freezes his feet and hands and lies down for dead. Wolves eat his ass. " Lucky for you that his master is dead!
Is struck with the flat of his sword. He thinks he is dead.
She goes to a neighbor's to cook a fish. She is gone a week. She gets a new fish and cooks it and returns home with the hot fish. She convinces her husband of her short absence.
Returning persuades husband that she has not been away.

She, in another house, has had her nose cut off by mistake. She makes him believe he has done it by making him angry enough to throw a razor at her. When he throws the razor she claims it has cut off her nose.
The wife and her confederates transform the house into an inn with tables, signs, drinkers, etc. The husband cannot find his house.
Rascals have sewed his trouser leg till it is too tight.
An article is stolen. Declared that whoever does not eat all his cheese is the thief. A stone is put in the numskull's cheese so that he cannot eat it all. He admits the theft.
In having his urine examined by a doctor, a cow's is substituted by mistake. (Or he dreams that he has borne a calf.) When a calf comes into the house he thinks that he has borne it.
His wife was pregnant when he married her.
He is dressed up as a rich lord and given rich food and drink. When put back into his own clothes he thinks that he has been to heaven.
Two men's hands joined in fun with words "I marry you. " Fool thinks that he must get a bishop to annul the marriage.
Thus his lazy wife is relieved from spinning.
Actually bag contained only ashes.
A student tells a woman that he comes from Paris. She understands him to say from paradise and gives him money and goods to take to her husband.
Dupe gives them to trickster.
Blindfolded and put on an ass.
He thinks that it is filled with the weather.
To see whether the church is moving someone lays down his coat in front of it. It is stolen. They think that the church has passed over it.
Administrador de la yesca.
At night turned around by a joker.
Hunters shoot a stag and hide it. Another who sees puts a dead ass in the bag instead. When the bag is opened, one cries, "Oh Jesus, we have shot a stag with iron shoes!
She bears a girl.
The latter is made to believe it is legitimate.

Woman tells husband that she has become pregnant during his absence according to his own instructions.
J2342.3	Italy	Italian Novella	Husband dismisses the truthful accusers saying that she knows her shortcomings better than anyone else, and she denies it.
J2342.4	India	India	Rascal tests it and finds it lacking.
J2342.5	India	India	
J2345	India	India	Dreams he is being kissed by fairy. Is really a pig.
J2346	Canada, England, U.S.	U.S.	An apprentice, or newcomer or ignorant person, etc., is sent for absurd or misleading or nonexistent object or on a ridiculous quest.
J2347	U.S.	U.S.

J2349.2	Italy	Italian Novella

J2349.4			Gets many impossible answers, which she believes. E.g., The cock has become sexton. " "Yes, that is why he sang so well in the morning. " (First edition +X941.)
He scolds in turn his feet, eyes, ears, and tail. In his excitement he sticks out his tail from his hiding place.
When the horse strikes sparks with his hoofs the lion is frightened and picks up the boastful wolf to show him the horse. He squeezes the wolf to death.
One brother receives the sacrament; the other is refused it because he cannot pray. He replies that his brother cannot pray either and thus deprives him also of the sacrament.

To prove that a woman cannot keep a secret the man tells his wife that a crow has flown out of his belly (or that he has laid an egg). She tells her neighbor that two crows have flown. Soon he hears from his neighbors that there were fifty crows.

Man boasts to boss that his brother can do twice the work he does. The boss hires him. The two brothers tell him their father can do as much work in a day as the boys can do in a week. The boss fires them, tells them to send their father to work for him.
Told not to serve a man with a red beard or to keep sausage for the long winter, etc.
He is to avoid his companions lest they smell what he has been eating.

Thieves stumble over him as he lies on the ground. " What is this, a log? " The fool: "Does a log have five annas in its pocket? " When they have robbed him he says, "Ask the merchant in the tree if my money is good. " They rob the merchant.
He is being carried through the air by a bird.
He says to the mourners, "When your fathers die, I too will come and lament their departure. " They brand him as a fool.
He gives them twice-threshed straw to eat as punishment.
Wishes his enemies to know that he is not afraid. Enemies go there before him.
Get no answers.
The witness tells. The judge: "You are wonderful; I have tried it thirty times and succeeded only once.

Just lain down to sleep, a man is awakened by a neighbor announcing that his she-ass has borne a young one without ears or tail. The man lies awake all night wondering how the ass will keep the harness on.
The second fool imitates the first who leaps from a palm tree by means of a looped rope. The first kills himself. The second wants to see just how it happened and kills himself too.

As his ox, who has enormous horns, is asleep, the fool gets on the horns. The ox wakes and throws him off. When he comes to his senses, the fool says, "I had a hard time, but my curiosity is satisfied.
The accused pleads that the plaintiff bit his own ear off. The judge takes time for consideration, tries to bite his own ear, but falls down and breaks his head.

A master sets his servant to keep watch over his horse at night. He soon asks the servant if he is asleep. " No, I was thinking of who created so many stars in the sky. " The second time the servant answers, "No, I was thinking of who dug the sea. Where did he put the soil? " The third time: "I was wondering who would carry the saddle now that the horse is stolen.
A man curious as to what a robber is going to do waits to intervene and goes back to sleep.
A man's head is snatched off by accident and his companions do not see what has happened. Debate: did he ever have a head?
A fool hides his purse on a pole on a cliff. A rascal substitutes cow-dung for the money. The fool is interested only in how the cow could have reached the purse.
On Good Friday an old woman who has heard the Passion Story exclaims, "How hard it was for the Jews who had to watch all night with Christ!
Fool experiments with shut eyes and gets lost.
Which has greatest attraction to earth, cup or contents? Father shows great attraction of fool's back and a stick.

REFERENCES: Irish myth, Missouri French, N. A. Indian, Spanish

LOCATIONS: Carriire, French, Greece, India, Lithuania, Missouri, Spain
REFERENCES: Greek, India, Lithuanian, Missouri French, Spanish

DESCRIPTION: Christ takes off a horse's foot to shoe it and then successfully replaces it.
Person does self injury.
A friend has cured his foot with this remedy.
He has had a tooth pulled and the pain ceased.
A peasant envying a doctor's fee for giving him a plaster and predicting a son, poses as a doctor. He predicts a son for a eunuch and gives a plaster for heart disease.

A doctor tells his patient that he has eaten too much chicken, and this the patient confesses. The doctor's son wants to know how the diagnosis was made. The doctor says that as he rode up he observed chicken feathers and made his conclusions. The son imitates. He sees an ass's saddle. Diagnosis: you have eaten too much ass's flesh.

A man whose wife refuses to talk remembers that a priest drank black cherry juice whenever he lost his voice. He cannot get the cordial but concluding that a limb of the cherry tree will have the same effect beats his wife with is. She is cured.
Fool has cooled objects thus.
Has seen melon thus dislodged from camel's throat.
He is driven off.
Beaten for his pains.
Is caught in the lamb's fleece.
Says that he has received large pay. He has his leg hidden under his wing. The elephant (hippopotamus) cuts his off and bleeds to death.
He has his neck hidden under his wing. The hare cuts his off and dies.
Wants to kill a horse. He asks the cat: "Is my back bristled, etc." The horse kills him with a kick.
Killed.
Is mired at water's edge.
Is killed.

REFERENCES: Arab, Chinese, India, Lithuanian, West Indies
DESCRIPTION: Because one man has had good luck a numskull imitates and thinks he will have equal luck. He is disappointed.

REFERENCES: England, India, Italian Novella, West Indies
DESCRIPTION: A farmer takes an extraordinary beet as present to the king and receives a large reward. His companion is eager for a reward and leads a handsome steed to the palace. The king rewards him with the beet.

Ruler rewards the gift of a clever donkey. Greedy nobleman seeking a like reward sends ruler two donkeys in rich trappings. Ruler advises the donor that he is sorry that his gift will deprive him of worthy companionship.
A famous poet presented to the king some poems and was richly rewarded. Another poet likewise gave the king some poetry. The king gave him the first poet's verses.
One man rewarded with forty crowns for picking louse from king's robe. Imitator given forty lashes for picking flea.
Falls in instead of being rewarded.
Brahmin goes to heaven, ascetic to hell.
Stepdaughter, married to a snake, appears decorated with jewels. Stepmother desires a snake be procured for her daughter. She is swallowed instead.
When his foot is caught in a wheel, they keep repeating his call for help as a song.
He slips and all fall to floor.
He has seen the smith spit on the hot iron.
All have theirs cut off.

A trickster sees a man throwing his eyes into the air and replacing them. He also receives this power but he must not use the power beyond a specified number of times. When he does so, he loses his eyes. He usually gets animal eyes as substitutes.

REFERENCES: N. A. Indian, S. A. Indian (Warrau, Carrib, Shipaya)
DESCRIPTION: A trickster sees a man with a sharpened leg. He also receives the power of sharpening his leg without harm if he will use it but four times. He breaks the tabu and is left with his leg sticking in a tree.

REFERENCES: Cape Verde Islands, Jamaica, Lepers Island, N. A. Indian
DESCRIPTION: A trickster (animal) visits various animals who display their peculiar powers in obtaining food (often magic). He returns the invitation and tries to provide food in similar ways. He fails and usually has a narrow escape from death.
He sees another man being shaved and thinks that the man is having his ears cut off. He orders his wife to cut off his ears.
He tries in vain to sell his cow and succeeds only when he says that she is with calf. When suitors come wooing his daughter, he tries the same plan disastrously.

He hears that great lords take a part in the business of the exchange where he sees great heaps of money. He throws down a penny and says, "You may like it or not, but I want money in the exchange, too.
All goes wrong.
Disastrous attempt to save him from tree in same way.
Man has had stork protect him from rain by covering him with his wing. Man tries to protect his wife from rain with his arm.
(To burn land, then sow seed. Opposite done.)

LOCATIONS: Africa, China, India, Indonesia, Japan, Lithuania, Spain
DESCRIPTION: The mother teaches the boy (the man his wife) what he should say (do) in this or that circumstance. He uses the words in the most impossible cases and is always punished.
He has sent a pig home alone. Told that he should have led it by a string.
He has wept at a wedding and been told to be gay.
Told that he should have thrown water in the fire when the house burnt.
Told that he should have cut up the pancakes which he has eaten whole.
Cooks five peas. Next time he is told to cook an abundance. Cooks half-bushel.
Told to put in three measures of rice to boil.
On last trip he has lost the gloves and has been told that he should have put them in his bosom. He puts the hawk inside his shirt.
He has killed a sparrow by his stupidity and has been told that he should have carried it in his hand.
Told to bring shiny things; brings out looking glass.
Numskull gives wrong greeting and is told how to give the correct one. When he tries it, however, the conditions are wrong.
Told that he should have kissed the old woman.
Servant stays away a year and then returns to claim salary.
Fool refuses to take six rupees for it.
Fool waits till master is laughing at servant's stupidity.
The foolish bridegroom is told to put parsley in the soup. He throws in his dog, which is named Parsley.
The foolish bridegroom is told to cast sheep's eyes at the bride. He buys some at the butcher shop and throws them at her.
While her parents are away from home, a matchmaker and a suitor come to the foolish girl. By following her mother's advice literally, she gives away her dower to the tricksters.
The girl shortly to be married complains: "It was all very well for you, mother, to marry father, but I am to marry a complete stranger.

The wooer makes boasts to the girl and the servant always doubles the master's boast. Finally the master says, "I have poor eyesight. "   The servant, "You don't see at all. " (Or the master coughs and apologizes; the servant says that he coughs all night.)
The wife throws the meal into the well and the pigs after it.
The woman breaks the pots into fragments and piles them up.
Fool feeds it steaming food and kills it.
Numskulls, told to shove the boy along if he is lazy about weeding, do so with their weeding-knives and kill him.
Fool stuffs and kills her.
Fool uses boiling water and kills it.
Boiling water poured over her.
Fool throws out all the furniture.
Fool floods it.
put it on my head! Numskulls asking old woman where to put grain obey and smother her.
Literal fool told to cut at plow if it sticks on roots cuts at bullock's legs.

Fool sews them to trees.
J2465.10	India	India	  Fool piles up their carcasses.
Cuts off child's ears.
Told to plow above a certain tree (on the hillside), numskulls haul oxen and plow into tree and destroy them.

Fool plows them out of ground.

The man, advised to cure his wife with a box on the ears, goes to the pharmacy and gets one. He cures his wife.
One man prays to the Virgin of Aix-la-Chapelle. The other: "That place is too far away; she can't be here in time to help. " He prays to the Virgin of a nearer town.
The Lord's Prayer has little power. I forgive my debtors but my debtors do not forgive me.
An actor representing Christ in a Passion Play is beaten by Jews. He throws the cross down: "The devil may be God; I won't.
An artist, ordered to make a crucifix, asks peasants if they want a living God. They say yes. " If we don't like him we can kill him ourselves.
