The fool asks where he got the large nose. Is removed from the room. He comes back to mend matters. He says, "What a small nose you have! " He is again taken from the room. The third time: "What difference does it make whether you have a nose or not?
A fool hearing of the effectiveness of holy water for the forgiveness of sins pours the whole supply over himself.
In a land where the sickle is not known the new sickle cuts off the head of a man and is thereupon given back to the original owner.
Hero gets revenge.

Fool starves himself at table. Later hunts food in house and gets into trouble.

Philosopher loses all his wealth at sea. Thanks Fortune for taking him out of business. Can now devote his life to philosophy.
J2571	Italy	Italian Novella	  Man contends that melons should not grow on slender vines but on tall trees. He is hit on the nose by a falling nut. Is thankful it wasn't a melon.
Man told it is well he did not obtain girl he loved because his heart might not have been able to stand it.
Seven men make strenuous plans for the attack on the fierce animal. One screams with fright and the animal runs away.
Fool steps on a rake and falls down crying, "I surrender!
Think it is a drum.
When they hear "whirr! " the army flees.
The snipe: "It is a bill, but it is good for nothing (weak). " The hawk is no longer afraid.
A man awakes with his knees in the air. He thinks the knees are a lion and splits them with his axe.

A man falls asleep by a gallows. A company of wags come and invite the dead man on the gallows to accompany them. The sleeper awakes with a start and says, "I'll come at once. " The wags flee in terror.

The girl dies. The lover, thinking that she is asleep, talks to her. When he hears the father speak of her as dead he is frightened that he has talked to the dead. The father hears the lover talk and thinks that it is the girl's spirit. Both flee.
Falls on a knife and kills himself.
Admits guilt. Husband: "Had you denied it I would have killed you!
Hides in trousers of plowman who fights the men.
Fool worries lest earthquake make him fall against an open knife.
Accidentally strikes the dog dead, drowns the midwife, and kills the child.
One falls from the tree and kills herself; the other breaks the pot.
Foolishly kills his horse and throws his axe into the lake to kill a duck. Undresses to recover axe. Clothes stolen. Goes into barrel of tar to hide. In tar and feathers.
A fool finds a treasure and takes some of it to a judge so as to purchase influence. The judge sends him back for the rest.
When the servant girl presents the cup to the emperor she holds the handle herself. When there are two handles she holds one in each hand, and when there are three she holds the third one toward her.
Gives him a slap and breaks his skin.
One woman says to another, You are an adulteress and a thief, and I know that I am just as good as you are.
I saw him hit him over the head with an axe but don't know whether he hit him or not.
They escape but he is captured and stupidly betrays their hiding places.

A servant is sent by his master to find a girl for him. If he returns with one he is to say, "I have a fox"; if without, "I have a hare. " When he returns he has forgotten the agreement. " I don't know whether it is a fox or a hare, but the girl is down stairs.
(He usually forgets them.)
He keeps repeating a word to remember it but changes it so that it seems to refer unfavorably to people whom he meets.
Says it is an "earth egg" (confused with name for potatoes).

A man hears a noise outside the house at night. He wraps a bed cover about him and goes to investigate. The robbers take the bed cover and flee. The wife asks what the debate was about. "About the bed cover. When they got it, the quarrel was over."
He tries to rescue woman caught by crab. Is caught himself and found in embarrassing position.
The grocer sends him a cheese. The buyer has forgotten to draw the hole.
Fool gives three explanations: (1) It was formerly a deep well; dug up and set out; (2) it was built by a very tall man; (3) it was built flat on the ground and then set up.
(Ring). "In its first state it was in the mountains; it is round and flat." Fool: "A millstone."
What does it look like? What outside and yellow inside. It is a hollowed turnip filled with carrots.
The fool seeks advice as to how to answer this question: Who is the father of Stoffer's three sons? Stoffer, of course. Then who was the father of Noah's three sons? Stoffer.

One fool to another: "What would happen if you cut off your nose?" "I couldn't smell." "What would happen if you cut off your ears?" "I couldn't see." "Why couldn't you see?" "My hat would fall down over my eyes."

One fool docks the tail of his horse; the horse of the second gets tail caught in gate, is docked too. One notches ear of his horse; the second horse notches its ear on the fence. Finally they measure heights of their horses. The black horse is two inches taller than the white.
King will give wealth to person toward whom the cat jumps. Clever woman has brought mouse along and thus entices the cat.

REFERENCES: Icelandic, Irish myth, N. A. Indian (Seneca)

DESCRIPTION: One of the contestants places his relatives (or others that resemble him) in the line of the race. The opponent always thinks the trickster is just ahead of him. (Told of animals or of men; often of the hare and the turtle.)

LOCATIONS: Africa, Carolina, China, Indonesia, Italy, Jamaica, Japan, Kalispel, North, Pennsylvania, Virginia
REFERENCES: . Italian Novella, Africa (Vai), American Negro (Virginia), Chinese, Indonesia, Jamaica, Japanese, N. A. Indian
DESCRIPTION: One contestant rides on the other's back.

LOCATIONS: Africa, Bahama, Canada, Carolina, Florida, India, Indies, Japan, London, North, Pennsylvania, South, United States, West
REFERENCES: Africa (West Africa), Ainu, American Negro (Pennsylvania), Bahama, Haupt Zs. Japanese, N. A. Indian (Ojibwa), West Indies
DESCRIPTION: In a race between the fast and the slow animal, the fast animal sleeps on the road and allows the slow animal to pass him.
A rival in a chariot race inserts linchpins of wax instead of those of bronze in the hero's chariot. The latter is dragged to death.
The trickster feigns lameness and receives a handicap in the race. He then returns and eats up the food which is the prize.
A man challenged by an ogre to a running race persuades the ogre to race with his little son instead. By this he means a rabbit.
Certain goal to be touched. Man shoots arrow and wins.
Hare accused of removing obstacles from his course.
The ogre squeezes the man so that his eyes bulge out. The ogre: "Why do you glare so?" "I am looking to see where to throw you." The ogre flees (Cf. +K18.1.)
A man challenged by an ogre persuades the latter to wrestle with his old grandfather instead. By this he means a bear.
Giant invincible in wrestling because with each contact with earth his strength is renewed.
Man places stone image at wrestling-place; fever enters image and shatters it.
Deer defeated but always pleads illness.
All comers are challenged and all are killed until the hero defeats the challenger. (Argonauts and Amycus.)
The boat is already sawed through.
The ogre agrees to contest against the man's young one, i.e., a squirrel.
Trickster comes up and breathes under some floating brush, where he is not detected.

LOCATIONS: Africa, Angola, Carolina, Georgia, Jamaica, South

DESCRIPTION: A hole is already dug and covered with boughs.
Wren goes into mouse hole.
The devil is not to look behind him. The man runs downstairs (or otherwise cheats).
Frog filled with shot.
He is trying to warn the people beyond the sea with his cry. The ogre is intimidated.
Offers him the ogre's cane. The ogre is intimidated.
Trickster shows the ogre the club he has thrown. (Really only a bright spot on the cloud.)

REFERENCES: Africa, French Canadian, Lappish, N. A. Indian, Philippine
DESCRIPTION: The ogre throws a stone; the hero a bird which flies out of sight.

LOCATIONS: Africa, Bahama, Cape, Georgia, Indies, Islands, Janeiro, Nigeria, Rhodesia, Rio, United States, Verde, West, de
REFERENCES: Africa (Mpongwe), American Negro (Georgia), Bahama, Cape Verde Islands, South American Negro, West Indies
DESCRIPTION: Small animal challenges two large animals to a tug-of-war. Arranges it so that they unwittingly pull against each other (or one end of rope is tied to a tree).
Wren hides in eagle's wings.
One animal chooses cotton; the other, seeing that a rain is coming, chooses salt and wins.
The man sends his wife on all fours in tar and feathers. The ogre has never heard of such a bird.

A man puts a dead hare under a tree and shows it to his dog. He tells people to look at the hare under the tree. At the distance no one can see it. He tells them that he will shoot it. He shoots and has his dog bring the hare.

God and the devil contest in plowing. The devil plows with a horse, God with a hare. While the devil is asleep, God takes the devil's horse and plows the field. When he wakes, the devil thinks the hare has plowed so much and gladly trades his horse for the hare.
Pig plows while dog sleeps. Then dog runs back and forth in furrow to claim victory.
The man calls out, "The wolves are coming!" The ogre is intimidated.
The man takes the center of the field. The ogre is given a dull sickle and mows around the outside of the field.
God mows with a chisel, the devil with a scythe. God deceives devil into changing scythe for chisel.
Hero challenged to cut down bundles of bamboo suspended in air but a strip of iron is treacherously inserted in each.
The ogre sews with the whole length of the thread. When he returns from the first stitch, the tailor has his task finished.
The fox places himself on a hill facing the east; the hog in a lower place facing the high trees to the west. The sun shines on the top of the trees, and the hog wins.
One keeps awake, the other sleeps. The first thinks that he sees the sun and cries out prematurely, thus waking the other, who wins.

LOCATIONS: Africa, Bahama, Georgia, Indonesia, Ireland, Jamaica, Louisiana, Nigeria
REFERENCES: Africa (Nigeria), Bahama, Indonesia, Irish myth, Jamaica, Louisiana Creole

DESCRIPTION: Hero and ogre to vie in pushing a hole in a tree with their heads.

REFERENCES: Africa, American Negro (Georgia), Caucasian, Danish, Malay, Philippine
DESCRIPTION: The ogre squeezes a stone; the trickster a cheese or egg.
The ogre bites a stone; the man a nut.
Substitutes soft food.

Two men take an end of a steak in their teeth; each attempts to pull it away from the other. After each has a good hold, the Irishman says (with clenched teeth) "Noo're ready?" The Dutchman says, "Yah!" , loses the steak.
The trickster has the dupe carry the branches of a tree while he carries the trunk. He rides on the trunk.
The ogre carries it on his back and soon tires; the man carries it between his legs (rides).
The man has an iron glove on.
The man has an iron finger.

LOCATIONS: Bay, Greenland, Hudson, India, Koryak, West
REFERENCES: Eskimo (West Hudson Bay), Koryak, N. A. Indian

LOCATIONS: Africa, Canada, Denmark, France, Iceland, India
REFERENCES: . Icelandic, Africa, Danish, French Canadian, India, N. A. Indian
DESCRIPTION: The hero slips his food into a bag and makes the ogre believe that he is the greater eater. (In many versions the hero cuts open the bag; the ogre imitates and kills himself.)
Trickster wins with the aid of substitutes.
Hero can produce unlimited food which opponents must eat.
Food secretly furnished one, but plan detected and foiled.
The trickster lets the water run out through a hole; the dupe drinks himself to death.
Buffalo and heron wager as to which can drink the sea until the water falls. The buffalo drinks as the tide is coming in; the heron drinks in the falling tide and wins.
The man drinks water, the devil is given vinegar.
One bullock keeps mouth in water. Other drinks self to death.

The man sends his wife to meet the ogre with whom he is to have a scratching contest. She tells the ogre that her husband has gone to have his nails sharpened. She shows him deep wounds that her husband has scratched on her body (obscene). The ogre leaves in terror.
The ogre tries to laugh as long as the dead horse with a grinning mouth. Laughs till he dies.
Arrow sent as a curse.
Winning coin had been rubbed on a pear.
Three daughters are to wet hands; the first to have hands dry is to be the first to marry. The youngest waves her hands, exclaiming, "I don't want a man!" She wins.
Gold required for its manufacture carried off by manufacturer.
It needs only the addition of a few vegetables and a bit of meat.
It already has the ingredients in it.
Dupe kills his wife (mother) and is unable to resuscitate her.

REFERENCES: French Canadian, N. A. Indian, Philippine

DESCRIPTION: The dupe takes it. "It is dog's dung," he says and spits it out. The trickster says that he is telling the truth and demands pay.
Woman sold a letter to wear around her neck which will prevent eye trouble. It helps only so long as she believes in it.
Actually works. When opened it contains nonsense.
Obscene contents.
Obscene contents.
A sailor boy sells a seasick Jew "Babylon stones" as a cure. They are pieces of coal.
Found to contain snake's eggs.
Alleged to be a swift deliverer of letters.

Caught in the rain, a trickster finds that his horse will not budge. He undresses, puts his clothes under the horse's belly and keeps them dry. When he reaches the king, he reports that his horse has run so fast that he has had no time to get wet. The king buys the horse.
He gives a description that is literally correct.
Said to swallow up the cold so that if he is near, one may sleep comfortably in the cold.
Dupe deceived.
The magic animals disappear.
For a gulden he tells him that he should wear all his clothes when he goes horseback in winter.
Dupe persuaded to pay for learning this dance (really moving toward and away from a fire).
Sun to shine on fools' backs as they go to town in morning and return in afternoon.
People think this is some Government phrase.

LOCATIONS: Denmark, French, India, Indies, Japan, Missouri, Spain, Switserland, United States, West
REFERENCES: American Negro, Danish, India, Japanese, Missouri French, N. A. Indian, Spanish Exempla, Swiss, West Indies
DESCRIPTION: Of root crops the ogre (stupid animal) chooses the tops; of other crops the roots.
The bear chooses the chaff because of its greater bulk. At the mill the fox's grain makes a different sound from the bear's.
The clever man chooses the kernel of the nuts and the outside of the olive.
Trickster sacrifices only the shells of the nuts and the inside of the dates.
All with curly tails belong to the trickster, others to the dupe.
The trickster shears the sheep; the dupe the pig.
Evil takes lower half of wife, Good takes upper half. Child begotten by Evil not permitted to nurse the top half which belongs to Good.
Evil chooses lambs, leaving milk to Good. Lambs drink up all milk.
Climbs on a tree and tosses peelings down upon fox.

LOCATIONS: Breton, Cape, French, India, Indonesia, Ireland, Islands, Missouri, Verde
REFERENCES: Breton, Cape Verde Islands, India, Indonesia, Irish myth, Missouri French, N. A. Indian
DESCRIPTION: The trickster makes a bargain with his master that the first to become angry must submit to punishment. He thereupon heaps abuses on his master till the latter breaks out in anger and must take his punishment.

A servant and his mistress agree that when they are angry with each other they shall say, "May God give you a penny!" When the master says this, the servant says, "May he give you two!" They keep increasing the amount till those who hear wonder at the performance. The mistress tells them, "You don't know the coin."
The baker fixes his price at the rate for twenty loaves. The trickster eats thirty.
Trickster has an enormous sack made.
Trickster encloses whole crop.
The ogre is to fulfill three wishes of the peasant. The latter wishes for all the tobacco and brandy in the world and then some more brandy in addition. The devil must admit failure.
The first to give the greeting shall have the disputed property. The trickster is early on the scene and witnesses the other's adultery. He may keep the property without saying good morning.
Dispute is to be settled thus.
The servant girl eats secretly; the miser starves.

The ogre and the trickster agree to fell a large tree. The trickster purposely dulls his axe on a stone and then asks the ogre to exchange. Rather than work with a dull axe, the ogre does all the work.
The man who is to receive this share of the crop makes very small stacks.

A woman who has been left the ox on condition that she give the proceeds to the poor offers it for five pennies, but it must be bought along with a cock at twelve florins. She gives the five pennies to the poor and keeps the twelve florins.
House sold reserving niche. This becomes such a nuisance that buyer pays heavily for it.

Every time the copper coin is paid out, the ogre must make a new one. The man buys an extensive property and pays with a large number of copper coins. He threatens to buy another and the ogre goes back on his contract.

LOCATIONS: Egypt, Estonia, France, French, Greece, Iceland, Paris, Tartu, Wyandot
REFERENCES: Basset Revue d'ethnographie et des trad. Icelandic, Egyptian, Estonian, French, Greek, N. A. Indian (Wyandot)
DESCRIPTION: As much land bought as can be surrounded by an ox-hide. The hide is cut into very small strips.
His worshippers claim for him the whole earth.
Subject given as much land as a goose can fly over without lighting. The man carries the goose with its wings extended over an enormous territory.
An immense shawl prepared.
Only by snatching up hood does seller prevent it from covering whole territory.
One man has supernatural speed.
Thrower has extraordinary strength.
He puts bamboo on the fields before they are burnt so that they crackle.
Bought just before sunset.
This is a rapidly spreading weed which overruns the country.
Saint causes cloud to obstruct vision.
Staff of one contestant transformed to spear (or dart) and so alone reaches island. When saint touches weapon, it becomes staff again.
Trees to be neither straight nor crooked.
The boy promises the soldier what the king has promised to give him. The soldier receives a beating in place of the boy.
A man promises in confession to steal only a small amount. He steals a rope with a mare on the end of it.
As hostages the dogs are handed over to the wolves; the young wolves to the sheep. The wolves then attack and kill the sheep.
The horse must agree to be saddled and bridled. The man then refuses to release him.
This is the name of an estate, which the king unwittingly gives away.
Because of an eclipse the sun is held to have done so, and Atreus becomes king.
The rascal has had an ear cut off and this is in a distant city.

Man sells three hundred foxes to buyer who agrees to "take them as they run": reds, silvers, crosses. He gets a large payment to bind the bargain, waves his hand at the woods: "I sold them as they run; and they're running."

Man boasts of hog so big that a man could not reach its back if he holds his hand as high as possible. A stranger buys the hog, sight-unseen. The seller takes him to the hog, shows the buyer that the hog's back is much below his hand when he holds it as high as possible.
Soaks the log so that it burns a week.

Gentleman agrees to exchange his good horse for the peasant's jade, provided the peasant will eat its excrements. The peasant finds no difficulty in the task, whereas the gentleman, put to the same condition when he wants to get back his horse, finds it impossible.
The man saves it through deceit.
He is unable to read the holy words.

The hero who is riding the devil as a horse receives supernatural strength from plucking a hair from the devil's mane. He then spurs the devil until he agrees to forego his bargain for the man's soul.
The man has promised himself to the devil in return for money. He stuffs his clothes with straw and hangs them up. The devil thinks the man has hanged himself and is satisfied.

The man is to belong to the devil as soon as he has sold his goods. If he has any goods that no one will buy, he is to be free. The man puts an evil old woman in a glass case. When the devil sees her, he recognizes her. "Whoever knows her will refuse to buy her." The man goes free.
The man sends his naked wife on all fours in tar and feathers. The devil has never seen such an animal.
The man's wife in tar and feathers overhears the devil tell the secret name of the crop he has discovered (tobacco). The devil says to the supposed animal, "Get out of my tobacco!"

The sleepy man: "I am just thinking, that on earth there are more crooked trees than straight ones ... more hills than plains ... more water than land ..." The devil goes to ascertain these things, meanwhile the man sleeps. Unsuccessful imitation by another man.
The devil bargains with a man for his soul, but the man fulfills his contract and escapes. In envy two persons commit suicide. The devil rejoices that though he lost one he has gained two.
The priest, who sold his soul to the devil, orders his servant to cut him (alive) up into pieces, to crucify him on a tree (and the like), thus saves his soul from the devils.
The devil may punish the drunk man's body but has no power over his soul.
The latter says, "The devil can take only one soul from each person. I bought the soul so that when he comes I can give him one and still save my own."
The devil is to fill a cask full of money. God knocks the bottom out of the cask.
The man has himself buried in the wall of the church, partly in and partly out of the ground.
The man plants acorns.
The last leaf never falls from the oak tree.

The student is to come into the devil's power if at the end of a year he does not at least return for the heaping bushel of gold a level one. The student forthwith hands back the level bushel and keeps the surplus.

Horse bought on condition that the buyer pay ten florins and owe sixteen. In court the buyer insists on the bargain and shows that if he pays the sixteen florins which he owes he will break the bargain, for then he would no longer owe.

LOCATIONS: Africa, Cape, Georgia, India, Islands, Jamaica, Louisiana, New, Nigeria, Tremaine, Vandau, Verde, York, fl
REFERENCES: Africa, American Negro (Georgia), India, Louisiana Creole
DESCRIPTION: Trickster refuses to carry out his part of the bargain.
Trickster eats other's food and then refuses to divide his own.

A farmer plans to kill a faithful old dog. The wolf makes a plan to save the dog. The latter is to rescue the farmer's child from the wolf. The plan succeeds and the dog is rewarded. The wolf in return wants to steal the farmer's sheep. The dog refuses his assistance.
Interpreter says they are complaining that the coin is bad.
In distress a person promises a sacrifice to a god (saint) but disregards the promise when the danger passes.
But he knows that after the storm he will not try to find such a candle.
Common lamb sacrificed.
Postponed until a hawk carries off the cock. Then the woman says, "O holy St. Martin, I have long owed you a living sacrifice. Take the cock as sacrifice, and may it be pleasing to you."
The deceiver takes the horse to the church planning to remove him again, but the horse will not stir until a money equivalent has been paid.
When reminded that he does not own so many bulls he explains that he doesn't expect the deity to come to enforce payment.
When the debt is due he offers the creditor his loyalty.
(Ground hogs.)
The trickster buys it from various women. After it is all poured together he says that each may have her own back.
Shrewd group each by himself pours water thinking this will not be detected if the others pour milk.
When seller refuses credit, he pours back half gallon of the liquid now half rum and half water. Sometimes trickster repeats operation, getting richer mixture with each transaction.
Later: "Drink up the river, you shall then have fish. All the fishes there are mine."
Tomorrow never comes.
The devil keeps calling daily until the gate with the inscription rots. He then claims his debtor.
One puts on his share in cash; other makes out a check for the total amount and takes cash left by the other.
Beggar sees lights in temple. Payment refused since beggar has thus warmed himself.
Palm rat, when asked to throw down nuts according to bargain, replies that he is deaf when eating.
loses stronghold by consenting to lend it for "a day and a night."
They blindfold the bartender who is to catch one of them; the one who is caught will have to pay. While the bartender is blindfolded, the drinkers leave the tavern.
Trickster sends one of each pair back to be stretched, leaves town with pair of boots made up of the remaining boots.
He refuses to pay for the bread because he has returned the beer undrunk. He refuses to pay for the beer because he has not drunk it.
Buyer refuses to pay more.
At feast prepared by king the two tribes get into fight and king escapes.
He masks as a woman and kills the giant who is to receive the hammer.
Man holds cat which flies in devil's face.
Forty-nine are moulded out of earth.
A woman having thus sworn keeps buying and selling the same mule many times a day.
After payment, snow takes proper form.
Later all the money vanishes. Saint replies that since the money had been created from nothing, it had simply to return to that state.
Man to be released when earth is placed at his head (buried). Dies in grave.
The debtor refuses to finish shaving.
Thus he hopes to postpone payment of his own debt.
The trickster castrates the dupe and is to come the next day and be castrated himself. He sends his wife as substitute.
Keeps it.
God grants the devil one grain crop, which he can create by calling its name. The devil is tricked into forgetting the name and calling "Thistles". Hence his crop is of thistles.

A man dreams of an egg hanging under his bed. An interpreter demands half of what he finds as his fee for interpreting the dream. The man finds that the egg is a silver cup filled with gold crowns. He gives the interpreter part of the cup but none of the gold. The interpreter says, "He gave me some of the egg-white but none of the yolk."
A trickster has only a grain of corn; this is eaten by a cock, which he demands and receives as damages. Likewise when a hog eats the cock and the ox eats the hog.
Princess lets trickster's fly (alleged to be a charm) escape.
Horse concealed by owner in loft of stable at inn.
Devours the cow, hog, etc. furnished him.
Camel's tongue demanded.
Lotus leaf used.
Grain multiplies and takes up all of dupe's land.
A trickster asks a goldsmith what he would pay for a lump of gold of a certain size. Believing that the man has such a lump, the goldsmith pays him a large sum.

Man asks peddler what he pays for mink skins. Peddler says he will pay ten dollars. The man tosses a skin into the cart, receives ten dollars. The next day the peddler protests that the man has sold him a cat skin. The man says that he had not said that the skin was a mink skin and that, anyway, the cat's name had been "Mink."

A poor man in return for a steer gets permission from the priest to speak three words at the burial of his enemy, the rich man. Priest: "From earth are you come." Man: "Now the steer is dead." Priest: "In earth shall you remain." Man: "Father, do you want the meat?" Priest: "I wish you were in hell!" etc.
Devil helps shepherd boy become a minister on condition that he mention Satan by name each time he enters pulpit. Boy consents but does so in such a way that devil begs to abolish the agreement.

LOCATIONS: Carolina, Georgia, India, Indies, Jamaica, North, South, West
DESCRIPTION: In talking the trickster makes gestures and scratches without detection.
The trickster has his worthless horse jump out the window. The duke will not let his run the risk.
(Has been specially trained.)

A man with an unsolved question seeks the help of a wit. The latter refuses to answer unless paid. He takes small fees for each easy question leading up to the principal question. Before reaching that point the fee is exhausted, and the question remains unanswered.
Recovery of the old bag (containing money or having magic power) which the stupid wife has given away. The husband exchanges a new bag for it.
Hole in the hat and hat over a pit.

LOCATIONS: Africa, Chinyanja, Le, Livingstonia, London, Nioniossee, Noir, Paris, Rhodesia, Tauxier, Yatenga, du, northern
DESCRIPTION: Grass burned around food makes continued washings unavailing.
He then goes to the inn, sells the hay to the innkeeper, and pockets the money. The owner of the hay delivers it at the inn, tries to collect at the inn; the trickster absconds.
Wealth (or woman) is on platform. First thing touched is ladder leading up.

LOCATIONS: Africa, Cameroon, Canada, Duala, France, Greece, Hawaii, Iceland, India, Indonesia, Ireland, Italy, Japan, lederbogen
REFERENCES: Africa, French Canadian, Greek, Hawaii, Icelandic, India, Indonesia, Italian, Italian Novella, Japanese, Missouri French, Philippine, Werner Zs. f. Vksk. Irish myth
DESCRIPTION: Man undertakes to steal various closely guarded things. Succeeds by cleverness.
Steal from each other.
Two thieves steal a ham from a former companion who has married, have it stolen back, and resteal it.
Thief robbed of his booty.
He swallows her string of pearls in revenge.
His father's corpse is guarded by twenty knights in black and twenty in white. By disguising he steals back the corpse.
In the shroud of the supposed dead man is hidden another robber.
Is killed by his intended victim.
Steal hangings in palace.
Are admitted to court without question.
In one cask is oil; in the others the robbers are hidden. The girl kills them.
Trickster brings rabbit under his coat. When the king's watchdog gives chase the trickster enters and robs.
Fills the dupe's bag with ashes and cuts a hole in the bag.

REFERENCES: Cook Islands, Hawaii, India, Missouri French, West Indies

DESCRIPTION: The man claims to sleep thus and beguiles the ogre into sleeping, so as to rob him.

REFERENCES: Finnish, India, Irish myth, Tuamotu, Welsh
DESCRIPTION: Magic or drugs.
Servant sleeping with him steals it.

LOCATIONS: Hawaii, India, Indonesia, Mangaia, Micronesia, New, New Zealand, Tahiti, Tuamotu, Zealand
REFERENCES: Hawaii, India, Maori, Oceanic (New Zealand, Tahiti, Mangaia, Hawaii, Melanesia, Micronesia, Indonesia), Tuamotu

DESCRIPTION: A blind man's arrow is aimed for him by his mother (or wife) who deceives him into thinking that he has missed his aim. She eats the slain game herself.
The hero seizes their eye.
Thief exchanges sticks.
The fox flatters him into singing, so that he drops the cheese.

LOCATIONS: Africa, China, Georgia, India, Nigeria, Wakweli
REFERENCES: Africa (Ibo, Nigeria), American Negro (Georgia), Chinese, India, N. A. Indian

DESCRIPTION: Poor parson thus rids himself of unwelcome guests; they leave food they have brought.
Owner and family flee.
When they are turned loose in the churchyard the parson and the sexton think that they are the souls of the dead. Meanwhile the thief steals from them.
Meanwhile a confederate steals his chickens.
Pretended dog is really a lion.
Trickster upturns his eyelids and puts on boar's tusks.
Torches alleged to belong to man coming to collect damages from her.
Trickster steals the goods.
They flee and leave money.
They flee and leave money.
They flee and leave money.
They flee and leave money.

LOCATIONS: China, Estonia, India, Lithuania, Russian, Spain
REFERENCES: Chinese, Estonian, India, Lithuanian, Russian, Spanish

DESCRIPTION: Trickster hits a slain ox and cries out, "Those others did it!" The thieves flee and leave their treasure.
Are frightened away by his outcry.
They can hear him but cannot see him.
Other thieves come to steal the bees, take the heaviest hive to the forest and make a fire under it. They flee when they hear a man screaming in the beehive.
Tricksters threaten to cook a robber. All the robbers flee in terror, leaving them their booty.
Meantime his goods are stolen.
Unable to find a place by the inn fire the trickster mentions that he has lost money on the road. One by one the guests slip out to search and leave him the fire.

LOCATIONS: Andros, Bahamas, Carolina, Georgia, Islands, Japan, North, Virginia

DESCRIPTION: Meantime robs him.

LOCATIONS: Andros, Antigua, Bahamas, British, Cape, French, Georgia, India, Indies, Islands, Missouri, Verde, West
REFERENCES: American Negro (Georgia), Bahamas, British West Indies, Cape Verde Islands, India, Missouri French
DESCRIPTION: The thief drops two shoes in different places and steals a ram while the shepherd goes after the shoes.
Meantime rascal steals an animal.
Rides away on horse.
Dealer allows him to climb on horse to see how he rides; thief runs off with horse.
While the man lies on the ground and looks up, the thief steals his horse.
While the master goes to investigate, the trickster enters his bed with his wife.
Meanwhile the man's confederates rob the dupe.
Goods stolen in his absence.
The stingy woman has the tailor come to her house to cut cloth. He throws a piece out of the window, "the devil's share". While the woman has gone after it he cuts off a piece for himself.
But it contains stolen cloth.
Man then slips in cave and steals lobsters.
One thief steals, the other relates the situation, in the form of a tale, to the gentleman who is being robbed.
While singing and dancing in the farmer's house, the thief gives hints to his friend in the loft, how to steal the bacon.
The thief orders the farmer to crawl into a tub and to sit there quietly and not look about, while he makes a magic spell (cure him of childlessness). Meanwhile, he steals all the farmer's property.
Confederate picks pockets of men who come to jeer.
Three men are quarreling over the possession of a rescued girl. The umpire will give her to the one who soonest returns with the arrow he shoots. While they run, he takes the girl.

LOCATIONS: Africa, Cape, Georgia, India, Indies, Islands, Jamaica, Louisiana, Verde, West
REFERENCES: Africa (Fjort), American Negro (Georgia), Cape Verde Islands, India, Jamaica, Louisiana Creole, West Indies

DESCRIPTION: A youth poses as a rich man's servant and gets a sack of bread from a baker. The baker boy is to go along and collect. The rascal drops two loaves in the mud and sends the boy back for fresh ones. Meantime he runs off with the rest of the bread.
Woman falsely told that her father is wounded leaves her water pot with jackal.
Meantime he steals it.

The stingy parson does not want to give any one a part of his pig, which he has just slaughtered. The sexton advises him to hang the pig up in the garden over night so as to make everyone think that it has been stolen. The sexton steals it himself.
Steals it while owner sleeps.

LOCATIONS: Africa, Cameroon, Cape, Carolina, Georgia, India, Islands, South, Verde, Virginia
REFERENCES: Africa (Cameroon), American Negro (Georgia), Cape Verde Islands, India

DESCRIPTION: He gets the whole loaf when he says that he has just cut a dog with the same knife.
Servant places his one fish with Brahmin's entire catch; receives all since Brahmin considers all polluted.
Servant eats all of master's anchovies. When master asks for some, the servant brings in a covered dish, and tells him that the fish smell very bad. The master tells the servant to throw them away.
He is given all of them when he tells his companions that he is an executioner.
May take it all.
Dupe persuaded that the dung has spoiled the field. He gives the field to the trickster.

A weeping boy tells a passing thief that he has lost a silver cup in a well. The thief takes off his clothes and goes after the cup, intending to keep it. He finds nothing. When he comes up, his clothes have been stolen.

REFERENCES: Africa (Wute), India, Spanish Exempla, West Indies

DESCRIPTION: Steals the horse.
Thief rides king's horse away.
Goods stolen by guard.
Steals them.
Thief runs away with it.
Trickster's claim of relationship causes owner to relax vigilance. Goods stolen.
Robs him.
Meantime he steals it.
Goes away with them.
Makes him believe he will get order to clothe fifty poor. Trickster makes away with goods. (Or tries on boots and makes away with them.)
Disappears with it.
Goes off with them.
Trickster advises wife to slaughter pig and have the trickster eat it all.
Trickster claims to be working magic spell over food and eats it.
(Often told of camel and tent.)
He is in upper room and throws filth on those below (Cf. +K344.)
Is allowed to drink it.
Collect rent and flee.
Child shouts to father, "Fly is eating," etc. "Never mind the fly, guard against the cow."
He thus learns where food is kept.
Escape.
The numskull has been told to keep the sausage "for the long winter". When the trickster hears this, he claims to be Long Winter and receives the sausage.
A thief holds a corpse up to a lord's window. The lord shoots the corpse and leaves to bury it. The thief goes to the lady and gets a sheet to bury the corpse in and a ring to put on his finger.
A thief poses as a messenger from a husband to his wife asking that a certain silver cup be sent for repairs.
Thief asks for silver platter saying that it is needed for an intended gift of confections. Servant carrying platter is told to wait until it is filled. Thief disappears with it.
Wife deceived in the dark.
When banker refuses to redeliver deposit the owner presents false tokens to wife.
Thief steals lawyer's scarlet robe. Later he returns and tells lawyer's wife that her husband had sent him for the hood for the robe. He obtains the hood and escapes.
Rent a room at an inn and empty the mattresses of feathers, take fire wood, etc. Throw goods out of the window where confederate picks it up.
Wife tells him secret of buried money.
The trickster has a cow that leads the parson's cows to him. He thus tests the parson's text, "He who gives in God's name shall have it back a hundred-fold."
Brothers are given the choice of a cow or a calf. One chooses the cow and thinks that he has the best of the bargain. The cow longs for the calf and returns to it.
A cow allows itself to be sold; then returns to its master.
Returns to master.
Later made to disgorge rice.

LOCATIONS: Africa, Bahama, Carolina, Georgia, Japan, Louisiana, South, Virginia
REFERENCES: . Lappish, Africa (Hottentot), American Negro (Georgia), Bahama, Japanese, Louisiana Creole, N. A. Indian
DESCRIPTION: The fox plays dead; a man throws him on the wagon of fish. The fox throws the fish off and carries them away.

LOCATIONS: Africa, Bermuda, Cambridge, Carolina, France, French, Georgia, Japan, Louisiana, Mass., Mexico, Missouri, North, South, Spain, United States, Virginia
REFERENCES: . Lappish, Africa, American Negro (Georgia), Bahama, Bermuda, French, Japanese, Louisiana Creole, Missouri French, N. A. Indian, New Mexican Spanish
DESCRIPTION: By pretending that he has been invited to be godfather, the trickster makes an opportunity to steal the provisions stored by him and the dupe for the winter. When he returns on successive occasions he reports the name of the child as "Just Begun," "Half Done," etc.
Tiger accused of the theft.

A rascal steals a priest's watch. He tells the priest that he has stolen a watch and offers it to him as a payment for a past favor. The priest refuses to accept stolen goods. Commands the thief to return the watch to the owner. "But the owner has refused to accept it." "Then you may keep it."
Trickster kisses pile of money, taking some in his mouth with every kiss.

LOCATIONS: Africa, Angola, Carolina, Georgia, India, Indonesia, Jamaica, Japan, London, Rhodesia, South, South Africa
REFERENCES: Africa (Angola), American Negro (Georgia), India, Indonesia, Jamaica, Japanese
DESCRIPTION: Trickster eats the common food supply and then by smearing the mouth of the sleeping dupe with the food escapes the blame.
The crane in revenge for the loss of her young ones strews pieces of fish from the dwelling of the mongoose to that of the snake. The mongoose follows the trail and kills the snake.
Impoverished lover falsely accused so as to be rid of him.
Accused of eating the lamb's heart, the thief maintains that it had no heart.

REFERENCES: India, Italian Novella, Lithuanian, Spanish, West Indies
DESCRIPTION: Accused of eating the goose's leg, the thief maintains that it had no leg, and cleverly enforces his point by showing geese standing on one leg. (Usually the master confounds the rascal by frightening the geese so that they use both legs)
Thief maintains that the bird had no tail.

The ass as toll-gatherer is killed by the lion for asking for toll. The fox eats the ass's heart. When the lion asks for it, the fox replies that the ass could have had no heart since he was such a fool as to ask the lion for toll.
While the owner sleeps the thief steals his horse, hitches himself to the wagon, and claims that he is the horse transformed into a man.

LOCATIONS: Africa, Bahama, Cape, Carolina, French, Georgia, Iceland, Indonesia, Islands, Jamaica, Louisiana, Missouri, South, Verde, Virginia
REFERENCES: Africa (Vai), American Negro (Georgia), Bahama, Cape Verde Islands, Icelandic, Indonesia, Jamaica, Louisiana Creole, Missouri French
DESCRIPTION: Thief steals animals and sticks severed tails into the ground, claiming that animals have escaped underground.
The thief kills one ox and puts the tail in another ox's mouth: the owner thinks one ox has eaten the other.
Owner made to believe that they have escaped through the air.
The thief makes the owner believe that the grain belongs to the thief.
The thief gets a receipt from the owner and thus defends himself when accused of theft.
(Mak.)
Thief has had his arm cut off as he enters a hole in a wall. He lets his companion also enter and have his severed.
(Previously he had severed father's or brother's head to escape detection.)
In one night a thief pawns a cow four times, always stealing it immediately and finally delivering it back to its owner.
Plays all night for dance while confederate commits actual theft.

REFERENCES: Africa, India, Italian Novella, Lithuanian, Philippine

DESCRIPTION: Upbraids owner for not guarding her better.
Returns it to owner after using it all he desires.
Though he has eaten the food trusted to him, he claims to have delivered it, but cannot remember the person who opened the door.
Making off with bacon, thief accidentally enters farmer's living-room. Boldly says: "Master, the devil from hell sends you bacon." The farmer: "Take yourself off to hell with the bacon."
Hoodwinked guardians make conflicting report of theft.
Makes golden human figure and says it is a corpse. Gets by guards.
Horse catches arm of thief and holds on until help comes.
He has threatened to smash the head of the magic statue if it betrays him. The statue says, "Whoever would tell the truth now is likely to have his head smashed."
Thief steals pig. Slaughters it together with one of his own and takes both to market. Puts little pig inside large one to avoid paying tax on two. Boy notices three hind legs. Thief is caught.
I need a finer one."
When he looks in chest, girl drops lid on him.

Spending the night in company with a suspicious-looking stranger, the man does not go to sleep, but leaves his clothes in bed and waits to see what will happen. When the stranger wakes up in the night, he stabs at his sleeping companion, who shoots him down.

A robber disguised as a beggar gets night's lodging at a farm house. Using a candle made of human fat or hand of a corpse, he tries to charm the household into a deep sleep (+D1162.2.1). One man who is suspicious and has not gone to sleep sees this and kills the robber.
Man scares robber with sausage; later boasts of event at inn. Robber hears this. Innkeeper secretly lends man a real revolver; robber is shot down when boldly attempting a second attack.

Thinking that he has killed the robber, the man takes his stick or knife with big handle. The robber recovers and, disguised as a beggar, inquisitively looks at the stick. The man is suspicious and by examining finds much money inside it.

Youth told by two robbers to go to town and sell bracelet for each. He goes and offers to sell two slaves. Goes back with buyer and cries out "Did you say both?" "Yes." Youth is paid; robbers are enslaved.
He has placed a coat on the goods to be stolen. His associate changes the place of the coat.
(Playing poison.)
Owner overhears, takes the ram to the thief to collect.
Cheated.
A husband and wife are jointly under a pension from the king. She reports her husband dead and gets the whole pension. He likewise reports her dead and gets the whole money.
A lawyer takes a car as fee from a widow and an ox from her adversary. He pleads for the latter saying that the ox draws the car.
Man to furnish goods exclusively to animal. Bargains at same time with another to do the same thing.
Estranged couple both pay him to effect reconciliation.
Thief (abductor) returns and enforces reward.
Payment for keeping silence.
The chest is said falsely to be full of money and the watchers subject to severe punishment.
They look into a carriage in which it is falsely said there is a princess. Trickster's dead wife is in the carriage.

He spends the night with a cock in a house. He eats the cock but in the morning accuses the sheep of having eaten it. In the next inn likewise he says that the ox has eaten the sheep, etc. In compensation he demands a larger animal each time.
The trickster confesses that he has had intimacies with the priest's maid and then overhears the priest scold the maid.
Get money.
Shrewd suitor persuades usurer to charge him 100 per cent interest, then has him arrested. Thus gets daughter for wife.

When palace and retainers disappear after wedding and only humble hut remains, clever fox tells king his daughter's feet have brought ill luck to the groom, his master. King gives half his kingdom in compensation.

LOCATIONS: Canada, France, Iceland, India, Italy, Japan, Russian, Spain
REFERENCES: French Canadian, India, Italian Novella, Japanese, Jewish, L. Schmidt Oesterr. Zs. f. Vksk. Icelandic, Russian, Spanish Exempla
DESCRIPTION: Three pilgrims agree that the one who has the most wonderful dream shall eat the last loaf. One eats it and declares that he dreamed that the others were dead and would not need it.
First brother (knocking egg against wall): "Casca cascorum." Second (breaking shell and sprinkling dirt over it): "Sar, sale, sapiensa". Third (eating egg): "Consumatus es."
Boy eats cakes.
Boy eats rice and throws empty bag on the road.

An impostor feigns to make clothes for the emperor and says that they are visible only to those of legitimate birth. The emperor and courtiers are all afraid to admit that they cannot see the clothes. Finally a child seeing the naked emperor reveals the imposture.
All afraid to admit not seeing God.
Killed by deaf man.

A rascal sees robbers dividing their booty. He puts a red string through his only coin (a heller) and slips it into the others' money. He claims the money as his and says that he has marked it with a heller having a red string through it. The robbers divide.
Trickster drops half a grain into grain cellar then demands half of the grain supply.
His confederate thus wins an absurd wager.

A trickster wagers with a sheep driver that the sheep he is driving are hogs. The next man to overtake them will act as umpire. The trickster's confederate now arrives and declares that they are hogs.
A rascal who has hidden with a simple man a treasure found by them carries it away secretly, trying to have his associate condemned on the witness of a tree in which his father is concealed.
Priest is duped into buying it as a diamond.
Man poses as returned heir to dead man; pretends to address corpse for identification.
The umpire takes the oyster itself as fee and gives each contestant half the shell.
A parasite makes the host believe him to be a friend of a certain guest and the guest to think him a friend of the host.
Three feast at an inn and each makes the host believe that one of the others will pay. None has money and the host is cheated.
When owner comes to collect, the trickster tells the priest that a heretic has come for confession. Then he flees.

Feasters are imprisoned because of failure to pay for the food. They name the priest as surety and are released. The priest has been told that the host is possessed and agrees to come to heal him in two weeks. The host loses the money.
While the servant in the inn is bringing a glass, the trickster drinks the wine and then complains that he has been given an empty bottle. The servant must bring another.
Wager. Each lie is corroborated by a confederate, who poses as a newly arrived stranger.
Pays small sum in advance for first sum borrowed. Pays this borrowed sum in advance for larger, etc.
The trickster prays to the Virgin for a certain sum of money and promises repayment of double at the end of the month. The sexton throws the money to him, but never receives it back.
Rival buyer pays extravagant price.
In cooking dinner fox's porridge is light, bear's black. At dinner fox steals spoonful of bear's porridge and lets bear taste it. Bear believes that fox's porridge is as bad as his own.
Fox covers his head with milk and says that his brains have been knocked out. Frightens bear.
The well that he has dug falls in. He throws his clothes into the hole and hides. People going to church think that man is drowned and dig the well out.
The thief hands it to his confederate. He says, "I haven't it." The confederate says, "I didn't steal it."
Two prisoners are made stable boys on their promise not to escape secretly. Before horse race starts they ask: "Do we have your leave to go?" They go home.
Man robbed of his plate of cakes half way to fair asks another vendor, "Why go to the fair, when half way up people come demanding your plate?" Vendor goes on and meets with same fate.
Prometheus divides slain ox so that bones and entrails seem to be choicest part. (Zeus is not deceived.)
A man sews up lead in a bag and feigns to have found it. A merchant claims it and thinking it filled with gold pays him a large reward.
Wine-casks partitioned: one half wine, other half water.
Jewels bought with counterfeit money.

A woman bribes a man to get her an audience with the pope. By turning his back to the sacrament and saying that the woman had instructed him to do so, he brings it about that she is summoned into the presence.
He secures the audience's attention by beginning a tale. He then launches into his speech.
The peasant weighs the butter which he is selling to the baker along with the bread which he is buying.
Only those not changed (all black, all red, etc.) belong to the devil.
A crowd gathers and he sells all his wine.
The devil wants to know what Noah is doing when he is building the ark. He forbids Noah's wife to enter the ark until Noah has also invited him.
He confesses that he has an oversized measure and agrees to get a smaller one. He measures back the grain in the smaller measure.
The lawyer tells the butcher that the dog's owner (himself) is liable for damages. He ask double the amount of the damages as fee.
He gets paid in advance. He gradually starves the ass.
They are phrased in such a way that he understands them differently from the way they are intended.
The contract is to be fulfilled at daybreak. The wolf imitates the cock and crows, but is caught.
They eat them at night.
Mother saves part of wine because purchaser is dilatory in removing casks.
The secret is revealed, and the saint blesses the cook's successors.
Trickster unwilling to pay for burial fee of aged cow, gives cow to unwitting Brahmin as gift. Cow dies soon and Brahmin must pay.
Overhears maiden tell rival she will bring food at night, waits until rival is asleep and carries him to another bed, takes his place, and is fed by maiden.

REFERENCES: India, Indonesia, Irish myth, Missouri French

LOCATIONS: Africa, Greece, Iceland, India, Japan, t'bingen
DESCRIPTION: Falsified order of execution. A messenger is sent with a letter ordering the recipient to kill the bearer. On the way the letter is changed so that the bearer is honored.
(E.g., boy has been ordered to kill hare. Hare persuades the boy that the father said, "Kill the rooster for the hare.")
Poet (who recognizes the meaning) reports to king that inscription means a request for honorable treatment.

LOCATIONS: China, England, Iceland, India, Ireland, Italy
REFERENCES: Chinese, English, Icelandic, India, Irish, Italian, Italian Novella
DESCRIPTION: A servant charged with killing the hero (heroine) arranges the escape of the latter.

Trickster fills it with stones and tiger loses it.

The philosopher warns the king against uxoriousness. In revenge the queen beguiles the philosopher into letting her ride him on all-fours. The king comes and sees.
He hides in a chest. The chest is taken by a creditor who unwittingly delivers it to the paramour's wife.
Lover caught on magic basin and left in embarrassing position.

DESCRIPTION: (Lai l'ipervier.) The chaste wife has them one at a time undress and hide. The husband and guests come and chase them off.
The husband takes the casks to the marketplace where he opens them.
Forces them to work for her.
Chooses food.
Husband takes the chest to the waiting congregation. Clever priest comes out enacting the resurrection of Lazarus.
Mistress tells knight of priest's demands. Knight has her give assignation, and arranges around her a string lasso which he pulls, and catches priest.
Wife pushes lecherous king first into glue and then in the closet with feathers. That is "nothing"   neither bird nor man.
They later get revenge.
First induced to lie in coffin, second to sit up with the "corpse", and the third to carry a firebrand. " Corpse" thinks others are angel and devil. All come to blows.
First has him hide on thorns, second has him fall into a hole, third has him fall asleep in the street. In revenge he shows them naked, except for face, to his friends.
Instead, she uses it to defend herself against the suitor.
He thinks he is severely wounded.
Obscene tricks played on him.

She escapes.
Unwoven each night. (Penelope.)

Prepares the bath herself and pours acid into it.
Feigns illness and then escapes.

He then takes the latter's place in the mistress's bed.
Man tries in vain to learn the identity of his friend's mistress. Mounts his friend's mule, which takes him to the secret rendezvous.

He refuses payment on grounds that he is not satisfied.

When husband comes in she drops candle and sends him out for another, allowing lover to escape unseen.
The priest who has thus duped the husband enjoys the wife.
(Inclusa.) Woman goes from one to the other. Her husband is made to believe that the woman next door is her sister.
She deceives her husband by saying that she must enter and clean her dress.

A husband returning home surprises a woman and her paramour and a numskull who has blundered in. The woman hides the numskull in the bed and the paramour under it. The husband, who is leaving on a journey, lifts his hands to heaven and says, "I commend you to the Lord above. "   The numskull: "Commend her rather to the lord below!
The husband is duped into believing that the friar has come to visit the sick.
The husband returns unexpectedly to find his wife entertaining the paramour with a sumptuous feast. He is made to believe the feast is in honor of some newly-weds.
She suspects the fraud and persuades him that she knew the ruse and was testing him. He begs forgiveness.
The devil has let him see his wife's unfaithfulness in this way.
She thus deceives the spying husband under the bed.
Discovering him under the bed, she tells lover that at temple she has learned that her husband is to die soon unless she prevents death by sleeping with a strange man. The husband is satisfied.

(Tristan and Isolt.) Husband goes to wife's love tryst and hides behind a tree. The wife, having learned of his presence, tells lover that he should not allow their innocent relations to lead to gossip. Husband is appeased.
(The Tsar's Dog.)
Meetings in the grave (grave box).

The priest grants to the sexton the offerings brought by all women whom the priest has loved. The priest always calls out "Take" when these women offer. The sexton's own wife comes. The priest calls out "Take!
The husband sees the paramour who has hidden in the pen and says, "Who are you? " "I am a miserable hog. " The husband thinks that his hogs are possessed.

A procuress obtains a woman for her client by leaving a marked coat in her room. The husband drives the wife away and she joins her lover. The procuress then goes to the husband and alleges that she lost a coat with certain marks. The husband is deceived and takes the wife back.
(Usually shares his bedmate with others, not knowing that she is his wife.)
Not knowing lover's identity, husband takes him to his wife and entrusts him to her care. He then leaves on a trip.
He is taken away.
Paramour gains entrance disguised as the husband. The husband without his clothes is driven away from his home.
Comes "back to life" on hearing husband say he has seen nothing.
The paramour, naked, runs out carrying wisps of burning tow. The trickster tells the husband that he has raised the devil.
Latter exposed (otherwise discomfited).
Asks husband to bury chest with her.
The naked lover hides himself in a sooty barrel. The husband receives from a curious gentleman a good sum of money for showing him the "devil".
Hidden cuckold reveals his presence by rhymes. He responds to the rhymes made by the wife and paramour concerning their entertainment.
In this indirect manner the wife confesses and promises reform.
The artist's wife's paramour poses as a crucifix when caught. When he sees the husband's preparations, he flees naked.
Beats him (or cuts off privates).
The wife sends her maid to investigate. The maid falls in and finally the wife herself. The husband calls the neighborhood to see them.
(Vulcan, Mars, Venus.)
When he returns, his wife's face is black.
(Often on window.)
On fording a stream the mule plunges into the water. Wife drowns.
Surprised paramour pays.
Rebukes them for not shutting the door.
Husband leaves bed to go to serving maid.
Beats or otherwise discomfits wife.
Husband pretends that his wife's privates tell him of her adultery.
Wife persuades him he has killed thief.
She confesses.
Though the master does not know of the adultery, the lover is thoroughly frightened.
Has trained bird to cling to him.
The lover breaks (or removes) an article of household equipment and convinces the husband that for that reason the wife has confiscated that which he gave her as a present.
The lover regains gift of horse and wagon by pretending to the husband that the wife has confiscated them because he brought wood of uneven quality.
The lover borrows money from the husband with which to corrupt the wife, later telling the husband that the money was returned to the wife during the husband's absence.

The lover, ignorant of the identity of the husband, tells him of his experience with the wife. The husband persuades the lover to lead him to the scene, where the wife is compelled to restore all but a small part of the money.
The lover regains by a ruse and thievery the borrowed piece of cloth which he has presented to his mistress.
The woman returns the cloth but puts a live coal in it. Destroys his whole supply.
The lover presents the wife with a valuable piece of jewelry, which he regains by pretending to the husband that he has left it as a pledge.
The lover regains his gift by a ruse (obscene).
Finally has to flee.
Woman fearing exposure returns money.
Lover bargains with the husband. Pays him with worthless money.
He thus avenges himself on priest who has cheated peasant's wife of her earrings.

The rats unite and all go to houses together, increasing or decreasing their ravages with the increase or decrease in the number of cats. Thus the cats are suspected of the damage and are killed.

Distinction between treacherous relatives and cruel relatives (+S0-+S99) is frequently impossible to make. Relatives whose treachery seems to be uppermost have been listed here; those usually possessing power over their charges and exercising their power in a cruel fashion have been listed under cruel relatives.

DESCRIPTION: (Vidua.) A woman mourns night and day by her husband's grave. A knight guarding a hanged man is about to lose his life because of the corpse he has stolen from the gallows. The matron offers him her love and substitutes her husband's corpse on the gallows so that the knight can escape.
Paramour fearing a like fate refuses to go to her.

He is hung up between two fires, but his second wife cuts the strings so that he falls down and kills his enemy and takes his kingdom back.

DESCRIPTION: He tries to force his attentions upon her and then claims it was a test of fidelity.
Restricted to a single cake during Lent, the peasants make one as large as a cart wheel.
Woman thus sworn to secrecy talks to her unchristened child.
Various false explanations are given to prepare the hearer.
Saint has tribute remitted for a day and a night, i.e. forever, because there is but one day and one night in time.
Luan" means both "Monday" and "Doomsday.
The peasant has hidden the fox in a basket and promised not to tell. When the hunters come, he says, "The fox just went over the hill," but points to the basket.
Man carries sods of two countries with him that his whereabouts will be so defined.
Fights with aid of sons and grandsons. They belong to him.

When king demand fugitive, saint (who never lies) replies, "Verily, I know not where he is, if he is not under thee even where thou art. " The king is satisfied and departs. Later suspects trick and arrests fugitive.

A drunken man is employed, by the woman who has accidently slain three hunchback brothers, to throw one into the river. He does so. Then she puts another out and finally the third. The man thinks they keep coming to life. Finally he sees the woman's hunchback husband and drowns him.
In the war between the wild and the domestic animals, the cat raises her tail; the wild animals think that it is a gun and flee.
In war between birds and quadrupeds the fox's lifted tail is to be the signal for the attack. Gnats sting the fox under the tail. He drops it and the quadrupeds flee.
A cat shrieks and the frightened bear falls out of the tree and hurts himself.
Is told there is a snake in it.
He leaves in haste.
Man sets juniper afire.
Fire is attached to birds who fly in and set fire to a besieged city.
Thinking they have been poisoned, they beat a retreat.
They are easily defeated.

Trickster throws a cap or leather apron inside the gate.
The trickster demands of Peter an article which he has given in charity. He then sits on it as his own property within the gates.
Trickster wishes himself in the sack.
I want to see from above the seventh story of my mansion my great-grandsons playing in the streets and eating their cakes from golden vessels.
At table each gives his neighbor a box on the ears. The soldier is to give it to the king, but he returns it to the courtier from whom he has received it.

A nobleman steals the abbot's flocks, saying that the monks have no use for them since they eat no meat. The most learned of the monks tries to recover them, but without success. The most stupid is then sent. Asked to dinner, he eats till he can hold no more. He tells the nobleman that he ate as much as possible since he could take back with him only what he had in his stomach. The nobleman pleased with the reply returns the flocks.
They share their loot with him.
The educated stewards have always cheated. The ignorant puts his belongings in one box, his master's in another. Both master and steward gain.
The favorite child is killed through the mother's overanxiety.

Fortunate choice.

A Brahmin returns home to find a palace instead of a cottage; he recognizes his wife only after she throws off her jewels and ornaments to stand before him in her old rags.
Weaver laments loss of water vessel. Offered many new, but prefers old and modest life.

King asks prince whether he has secret of prosperity forever or a day. Prince says "forever" and is captured. Later his wife, asked same question, says "for a day" and is honored.
Gives everyone the same measure of wit, so that the smaller are more clever than the large.

This causes pagan to repent. Conversion follows.
Sun by warmth causes traveler to remove coat, while wind by violent blowing causes him to pull it closer around him.
Rain also tries unsuccessfully like wind.
Survives him and inherits property.
Slips into his stomach.
Bride asks suitors what they have to offer her. Poor youth who has nothing but love to offer gets her.
Frog alone does not expect to live to a hundred and ten years and alone escapes fisherman's net.
(King in the bath.) While the king is in the bath (or hunting) an angel in his form takes his place. The king is repulsed on all sides until he repents of his haughtiness.
He boasts that God has no power to make him poor. While he is at church, his property burns and he returns home poor.
Ring is found in fish: she becomes poor.
(Canute.)
An angel is sent to kill his people. Desists only when David repents.
He prices it in a statue shop and finds that his price is lower than other gods.
In spite of all his plans, his servant recovers the lost (exchanged) treasure.
Both served up at same meal.
Man sets self up as a god.
Car supported by eagles.
A girl takes her goat to pasture and leaves him: "My God care for you! " Peter must run everywhere after the goat.
(Glove and the Lion.)
He has formerly refused this man charity.
He kills the man who does it, but is in revenge deprived of most of his goods.
He has said of a condemned man that he deserves his punishment.
Abbot tells him to search his own heart to see if he is free of sin before attacking others.
She has passed judgment on a girl who has a bastard.
Punished for self-righteous condemnation of unchaste girl.
Throws God's footstool at an old woman thief on earth.
Is made to leave the cross for his impatience concerning the sinners.
The tame bird tells the wild one to look about him. He is shot.
Later see their error.
Caught by his horns in trees.
When well fed says, "My mother was a thoroughbred horse. " Later, hard worked, says, "My father was a miserable ass.
Has decreed that no one enter a meeting armed. He forgets to remove his sword. Kills himself.

A knight condemned for murdering his comrade is met by the latter on the way to the gallows. A centurion leads them to the emperor, who condemns all three to death: first because he has been sentenced; second for causing by his absence the conviction of his comrade; third for delay in the execution.
Those caught in adultery are to have eyes put out. When king's son is found guilty he insists on the punishment. He finally compromises by having one of his own and one of his son's eyes put out.
King leaves laws that must be kept until his death. Years later he has his bones sent back to that land to let people know that he is dead and they are free.
A king flattered by his elder daughters and angered by the seeming indifference, though real love, of the youngest, banishes the youngest and favors the elder daughters.
Pieces are then buried.
It must be by so and so or else it is worthless.

DESCRIPTION: (Faust, Theophilus.)
He jestingly offers to sell his soul. Devil in disguise buys it.
Just as it turns into wine the devil takes him, or injures him.
They are his own weapons.

Ring turns to rope. The judge cannot find a rope and is about to release the thief because of the miracle. But the ring in the box presented by the devil as a bribe turns out to be a rope. The man is hanged.
He mows with a magic sickle. The evil overseer tries to keep up with him and dies of overexhaustion.
The devil refuses to take anything not offered him with the whole heart. He hears the judge (advocate) cursed for fraud with such sincerity that he carries him off.
He must not later exorcise him from people.
For this, he must promise the devil his soul. Having become a great priest, the man finds means to save himself.
After quarreling with the devil, who asked to repair the whistle during Mass, the priest forgets all he learned and does not know how to hold Mass. Is beaten.
Giant allows hero to cut off his head; he will cut off hero's later.
Marvelous runner beheads hag.
Disputants, bear and tiger, agree not to eat him.
Person grants wish before hearing it.
A starving man lets himself be blinded in return for food.
In return he claims her as wife.
Godiva.
When the hero shows that he is willing to carry out the bargain, his helper relents.
After the agreement to divide all winnings the first man receives favors (presents, kisses) from the second's wife. He faithfully delivers them.
(Or two friends agree that the first to die shall bring news.)
In pursuance of the pledge, the living follows the other to the world of the dead.
Promises his dying wife that he will not marry unless the bride meets the specifications the dying wife imposes.
If he is in Hell it will do him no good; if he is in Heaven he won't need it; and if he is in Purgatory he can purge himself.

Hero is to drink his blood, suck his eyes and brains, and give his heart to his loved one to eat. He will become marvelously strong and his wife will have three sons and four daughters with great powers.
(They are moved by magic.)
Teacher has only been testing her promise.
Host agrees to march back a day's journey if warrior will cease his feats of arms upon them until a certain battle in the future.
