When he has nothing left he is asked for a gift. He allows man to extract a tooth from his mouth. (Father had offered reward to anyone persuading his son to have it extracted.)
Asks for the stolen plate and hides it so that it will not be found on the culprit.
Ruler asks treasurer to give man 200 crowns. Treasurer makes error and puts down 300. Ruler raises sum to 400. "I can't allow your pen to be more liberal than I." Italian Novella:
Chancellor: "If you saw such a sum it would seem large to you." King answers that it looks small and doubles it.
It is the first time that what he has given away seems too much.
The son aids him to escape.
He is won over by the generosity of his intended victim.
Would act as he should like an emperor to act toward him if he were a common man.
When he sees his house carried off by a flood, he fiddles the whole time.
Does not complain when beset by a series of misfortunes.
He returns fifty years later, finds the driller still drilling away.
He had not paid for it.
The captor frees him and the two become friends.
Each cites instances of his laziness.
He is too lazy to stop rats from playing with lighted candle.
The daughter asks which foot the coal is under.
This causes him to lose prospective bride.
His voice is damaged.
They sleep till noon.
The master has told the servant to go to work.
The peasant and the boy sleep during the rain in the hay barn. When the peasant asks, the boy always says that it is still raining.
He is bringing a goose.
Lazy wife must hold cat and is scratched.
Lazy wife beaten by husband maintains that she has done nothing. That is why he is beating her.
Supposed dead husband comes back to life and gives his wife a beating, because there was no shirt even in the event of death.
Idle daughter-in-law learns work.
They lead to his death.

Working independently, the lazy fellow spoils the materials received starts making something big, which at the end turns to nothing. For example, begins with forging a plough: this becomes an axe, the axe a knife, and knife a needle, the needle nothing.

The group take pity on him, offer him various articles to help him get started again. One offers a bushel of corn. The lazy one rises up from the bottom of the wagon or coffin where he has been lying: "Is the corn shelled?"
Told when to applaud.
In truth, gentlemen, you do well in weeping; for since you didn't fight like men to defend your land, it is suitable that now you weep like women on leaving it.
Will not drink but gets drunk nevertheless by frequent tasting.
Always says that unpleasant work is beneath his dignity.
Goes to the judge and gets better food assigned to him, but the fox cheats him out of it.
In kingdom of lions laments that he always gets the worst bits of food.
Say that it makes their water unusable.

look! she cries from the barrel. A nobleman has arranged for a peasant girl to become his mistress. When he comes to take her away he cannot find her. Disappointed, he is about to depart when the girl, who has hidden in a barrel, calls out "Look!" She really wants to be found.

REFERENCES: Icelandic, Irish myth, Jewish, West Indies

DESCRIPTION: I intend to go there myself as soon as I get well again.
Old man before dying eats his money. In church, son wants to cut corpse open and get the money. The devil: "Don't spoil the skin." Shakes money out of the corpse's throat and takes the skin.
Then she says he may have the soup.
It is better that they speak ill of me on an empty stomach than on a full one.
The servant discovers that the hot lunch is a mustard sandwich.
He is afraid she will eat the raisins out of the cakes.
They die of the shock of being fed.
Gets burned in the chimney and beaten in the bed where he hides.
Gets full benefit from it.
Strangles himself in his sleep.
Does not want the expense of a rope.
Miser annoys merchant so much over the price of a rope that the latter gives it to him provided he will hang himself as he plans to do.
Refuses to pay fee. Chain of circumstances make it infinitely more expensive.
You get no benefit from your wealth. Proves his folly.
Dismisses him and charges him for a rope which he had cut while saving the usurer from hanging.

REFERENCES: . Spanish Exempla, India, Italian Novella, Jewish
DESCRIPTION: That you were allowed to take your beak from my throat is payment enough.

REFERENCES: . Italian Novella, Africa (Ibo, Nigeria), West Indies

DESCRIPTION: A traveler saves a monkey, a snake, a tiger, and a jeweler from a pit. The monkey gives him fruit; the tiger a necklace of a princess he has killed. The jeweler accuses the rescuer before the king. The serpent saves him by biting the prince and then showing the man the proper remedy.
Gives lawbreaker a light sentence. The latter seduces the magistrate's wife.
Is killed.
The storekeeper gives him the rum; he asks for an egg in it. The storekeeper breaks an egg (the one he has just traded the needle for) into the rum. It has two yolks; the trader asks for two needles.
Horse must then assume the load.
Has no use for the manger but refuses to give it up to the horse.
Son ashamed of his peasant father who brings him money. Father disinherits him.
Neither will step aside; both fall into water.
He tries to appear friendly to both.

LOCATIONS: Carriire, French, Iceland, Ireland, Missouri, Spain
REFERENCES: Icelandic, Irish myth, Missouri French, Spanish

DESCRIPTION: Do not consider that he guards the flock.
Peasant kills him in a few days.
He stops crying so that after a rest he can cry louder than ever.
He overhears a man tell of his temper. In anger he enters and demands to know when he has ever lost his temper.
A little sickness has made him kind; more may make him kinder.
Man so angered that he refuses to pay his workmen.
The lion to the man: "The wound has healed, but the pain of harsh words still remains."
There weren't so many as that. "Well, what made the noise in the bushes?"
Man travelling alone through the forest at night, is afraid of robbers. He hangs his cap on a stick and keeps repeating: "I am not travelling alone, there are two of us."
Warriors so eager for battle they do not take time to go out of tent door but go through the tent wall.
When they agree to engage in battle, they cannot endure to be without combat.
Hero sends fairy healing charms to his enemy so that when they resume fighting it cannot be said he wins because of superior care.
Hero feels it dishonorable to fight with sorely wounded enemy, because it would be said he died of previous wounds rather than the ones hero might inflict.
Man is so poor that when he moves all he has to do is to put out the fire and whistle for the dog to follow him.

When, on the advice of a friend, he gives the ass red pepper, the ass runs away. Then he tries it on himself. He runs so fast that he passes the ass. Arriving at home, he says to his wife, "Unload the ass when he comes. I must run through the village a couple of times more."
A man eats up the dried meat of a Jew on shipboard. It happens that the Jew is carrying his dead father back home for burial in this form.
A man dreams that he finds treasure and that he marks the spot with his excrements. Only the latter part of the dream is true.
Finds cat's excrements.
They follow and are soaked when the servant purposely spills the dirty water.

A inquires for his lost animal. B talks about his work and makes a gesture. A follows the direction of the gesture and happens to find the animals. He returns and offers an injured animal to B in thanks. B thinks that he is blamed for injuring the animals. Dispute. Taken to deaf judge.
Travelers ask their direction. Peasant thinks they want to buy oxen. Peasant's wife arrives; thinks they say her food is too salty. Daughter-in-law and father-in-law misunderstand each other.
A trickster tells each of two persons before they meet that the other is hard of hearing and must be shouted at. A great shouting takes place, and each thinks the other out of his wits.
Lord: Good morning, Peter. Peasant: I come from Bingen. L. What is the hog worth? P. Two weeks from next Sunday (the wedding). L. Shall I come to the wedding? P. Three and a half gulden.
Lord: Good day, Caspar. Caspar: I am making a reel. L. Good day, Caspar. C. It is worth four pence. L. Good day, Caspar. C. Yes, my lord, whenever you wish.
A nobleman amuses himself at the expense of the deaf man. Finally Nobleman: I wish you a thousand gallows and ropes around your neck. Peasant: My lord, I wish you twice as many.
In some the people are not really deaf but fail to catch a word; in some they are deaf.
A traveller asks the way and the man keeps telling him about the bird he has caught. (The questions and answers often rhyme.)
He plans the conversation with the expected answers. The answers turn out otherwise. A. How are you? B. I am dead. Thank God! What have you eaten? Poison, I think. I hope it agrees with you.
A woodchopper. The workman answers the traveler's courtesies with remarks about his work.
The youth answers unintelligibly but is praised nevertheless.
The drunken priest says, "In the morning I take a drink of rum and afterwards four or five little drinks."
One asks name of town; another replies, "This is Wesley." Another says, "I thought it was Thursday." Third says, "So am I; let's have a drink."
Sent by his father to get the only bottle of rare wine, he sees two. Not wishing to show his father to be a liar, he breaks one really the only one.
Has appraised it at half a mark. "He saw only half a horse; otherwise he would have valued it at a mark."
Man asks bull if he is on the right road. Bull butts him and knocks him down. The man says that all that was not necessary, simply to say yes or no.
Runs lance into his posterior.
Each member has mouth turned in a different way. Unavailing attempts to blow out the light.
Amusing results.
Cannot say anything as he is too busy trying to keep his seat.
Baker cannot understand how a man who has been a miller can be a beggar. It is a wonder that the farmers are not beggars instead.
If he had been like the rest of the congregation he would have become rich.
A mad dog in place of a miller in a sack.
Drunken millers force monks to dance. Millers are enticed to monastery and beaten.
Sews the stolen piece of cloth on the outside of his coat, thinking that it is on the inside.
The object of jokes.
Devils annoyed at their noisy trade.
Anecdotes of their invective.
Woman sees the crowds of students in the law school. She knows that the one lawyer in her village has ruined nearly everyone.
The dying man has the lawyer and the notary stand on either side of him.
He enters religious order and tries to conduct the legal business without lying.
When the priest to whom he is confessing says there are but five senses, the magistrate says that he needs two more senses than other people.
One fee for teaching and one for making them forget the old teaching.
With his one art latter supports his family.
Wasps chase him.
Rings alarm.
Marries the old man to the girl and the old woman to the boy.
He wants to show how Christ rode into Jerusalem. Sexton sticks ox with needle.
Locked in church all week by mistake. When the congregation comes, the hog runs between the parson's legs and carries him out.
Has clothes torn in the back. Those that see this laugh. He wins the wager.
Rascals have spread butter on the altarbread. The parson preaches, "What is the life of man?" and therewith brings his hand down on the altar-bread: "Pure butter!"
It dies in his pocket.
The coffin-maker has fitted him to the coffin. The parson: "On the last day he will arise." One of the coffin-makers: "Did I say that?"

A sexton hears thieves in the cemetery cracking nuts and thinks it is the devil cracking bones. With the gouty parson on his back he comes upon the thieves who, thinking it is their companion with the sheep, call out, "Is he fat?" The sexton: "Fat or lean, here he is!"
The bear-showman lets the bear climb up the pulpit. The parson thinks the bear is the devil.
So says the innkeeper.
All but the priest rejoice over the good health of the community. He bemoans his loss of income from burials.
Monks eat eggs and make chickens expensive; priests eat hens and make eggs high.
Overnight at the peasant's house. The hungry parson hunts the porridge in the dark, guided by a rope the sexton has given him. Series of accidents.
Series of accidents.
Parson says that the loaves with which Jesus fed the people in the wilderness were as large as the mountains. The mason asks what kind of oven they were baked in.
The parson asks the boy: "What does your father say when you begin to eat?" Boy: "You young devil, etc."
Makes a present application of the words of the parson.
Boy: "Pay your old debts." Variants: (a) What evil did Adam do? He (shoemaker) made my shoes too small. (b) What kind of man was Moses? He was a day laborer.
He stayed to hold the oxen.
He was in the willow-grove looking for a stick to beat those who ask foolish questions.
The priest's example: the three cows. The boy: "The Holy Ghost has just had a calf."
A boy rides with a rich man. Goes into church and leaves his coat lying on the sled. When the parson preaches about the rich man who went to hell, the boy calls out, "Then he took my coat along!"
The parson sees an old woman weeping and believes that she is touched by his singing. When spoken to she says that she has been reminded of her old goat which she has lost.
The smith tells the parson whom he has summoned that he has dreamed of going to heaven where St. Peter would not admit him before he saw a parson. There were no parsons in heaven, but all in hell.
Devout woman and a priest retell their dreams. The priest has dreamed that all the devout women are to be found in hell.
Parson intones instructions to the sexton (cook) as a part of the mass.

Rector confesses his sacristan: "Have you drunk the wine designated for the mass?" "I can't hear you." Exchange of places. Sacristan asks rector: "Have you kissed my wife?" "Really, I can't hear you."
Bell breaks and priest's patron whistles in place of ringing the bell at mass.
Those who know may teach those who don't know.
Last year I told you all about his life and works. He has performed no new miracles.
Refuses to say, "I'm not worthy" at communion.
He explains situation to minister, asks to be ordained. The minister explains that the letters mean "plow corn" instead of "preach Christ".
Custom not to bury dead until someone has something good to say about him. No one will praise a dead usurer until a barber is willing to say that he had a good beard.
The parson asks the various trades and professions to rise one by one for a special blessing. When he calls for the usurers none reply.
So declares a youth paid by a usurer to protest against the priest's remarks that the devil would carry all usurers off.
It refuses to be moved by anyone else.
Someone cries, "Clothes are being auctioned off in hell."
A caretaker of an estate recently sold to a Bavarian sits among the swine so as to learn Bavarian.
Hermes and his wagon of lies break down in Arabia.

LOCATIONS: Blason, France, Le, Populaire, de, la
DESCRIPTION: Despiteful names used by one city for another.
An order is read in church forbidding the young people to marry girls from other parishes.
On one side is a bundle of straw (her husband) and on the other a dog (her child). She gives the straw bundle a push and thereupon falls on the floor herself.
She falls down.
One of the old maid's three teeth breaks off.
She keeps him for a husband.
Absurd results.
Is cured of drunkenness.
Goes to sleep and never reaches it, though at home he praises the wedding.
Absurd results.
Hears someone play the lyre.
A man who tells but one lie a year is believed because of his general truthfulness. Amusing results.
He tells a lie so often that he believes it himself.

REFERENCES: Estonian, India, Lithuanian, Livonian, Prussian, Russian

DESCRIPTION: Liar tells of shooting large number of animals with one shot (an odd number, usually 99). When asked why he did not make it a round number (or an even hundred), he replies indignantly that he would not lie for one pigeon (rabbit).
Rewards him poorly. Servant exposes him.
(Often with answer: "Many fried fish.")
He says he has shed barrels of tears because of his weakness.
He continues the lie the tricksters have made up to catch him.
Hero marks logs by pinching a piece out of end of each one.
Man skins buffalo alive, turns them loose to grow new skins.
(John Henry.) Engages in contest with steam drill; he wins the contest but dies in the attempt.

REFERENCES: French loggers prefer pea soup for all three meals. U.S.

DESCRIPTION: Cow has calf and the calf grows up and has calf before it can reach its stall.
Giant with sixty daughters.
Hunter cuts down tree packed full of animals. The tree is so full of animals that a crack in tree opens as animals inhale, closes when they exhale.
He reaches down animal's throat, grasps his tail, and turns him inside out.
Gun kills a bird which falls on loose limb of tree, which falls on bear, etc., etc. (First ed.
The frogs are caught in the ice.
Wolf's tail nailed to tree. Wolf runs away and leaves his skin hanging.
Bear chases man in July; he finally crosses a river on the ice. The bear falls in or stops following (in December).

Trickster and companion are wolf hunting. The companion goes into the wolf hole. The wolf comes. The other catches the wolf by the tail and the wolf scratches dust into the companion's eyes. "What a dust." "If the wolf's tail breaks, you will see another kind of dust!"
His tears form a stream.
Pigs also have these carts.
(E.g. Pine tops: milk good for cough syrup.)
Put back together but back legs point upwards.
Eats the horses, is harnessed and runs in the harness.
Tusks go through tree and come out on other side.
The explosion kills the mule, blows down the barn, breaks windows out of house. The hog is ill for several days.
His oxen continue to pull; he holds onto the plow, pulls the stump out of the ground.
He rolls in the field. Oats in his flanks; club in his tail kills birds.
They have been tied together as a protection.
Liar says that in a certain place bees are as big as sheep. And the bee-hives? The same as ours. How do the bees get in? (Various answers.)
They have drilled through kettle. Their bills are clinched inside like nails.
One of them meets his death between the horns of two struggling oxen, another because of two restless stallions, the third during a tussle between two giants.
Snake takes its tail in its mouth and rolls like a hoop toward its victim.
Eaten by one larger and this in turn by crow.
Animal with two short legs on one side for convenience in living on hillsides. It can walk around the hill in only one direction.
(Usually matched by tale of great pot to put cabbage in.)
(Land of Cockaygne.) Land in which impossible things happen.
Land where all is opposite from the usual.
A place where animals and things are designated by senseless names.
It is winter all summer and in fall it gets colder.
Must be thawed out by the stove.
Man shingling building during thick fog shingles several feet of fog when he gets beyond the roof line.
He acts like animal.
The animal freezes back together; man must eat his way out.
Falls through ice with his horse, wanders around on the river bottom, pushes his spear through ice from below and rises to the surface.

Man driving team with wagon uphill in rain finds on arrival at the top of the hill that the tugs of rawhide or buckskin have stretched and that the loaded wagon is still at the bottom of the hill. He unhitches the horses and throws the harness across a stump. Sometime later, or the next morning, the sun comes out and shrinks the tugs, drawing the load to the top of the hill.
He frightens the woodchopper who leaves behind his horse.
Is years ascending steps. On last step falls and curses haste.
They ate up their churches made of cheese and bacon.

REFERENCES: India, Irish myth, Italian Novella, Spanish Exempla
DESCRIPTION: Hundreds of sheep to be carried over stream one at a time, etc. The wording of the tale so arranged as to continue indefinitely.
Just as the interest is aroused the narrator quits. "If the bowl had been stronger my tale had been longer."
The manner of the telling forces the hearer to ask a particular question, to which the teller returns a ridiculous answer.
Conventional passages of set form within a tale, usually recited in a different voice from the rest.
Whose is she?
Stories which begin over and over again and repeat.
To hear the better, my child, etc.
(Used as game.)
Inventor asks one wheat-grain for first square, two for the second, four for the third, eight for the fourth, etc. The king cannot pay.
Master has no fields left.

LOCATIONS: Ballads, Cambridge, Greenleaf, Lithuania, Mass., Newfoundland, Russian, Spain
DESCRIPTION: ; Le dodici parole della verita, Las doce palabras retorneadas. The numbers from one to twelve are brought into relation with various objects, often of religious significance.
A farmer pays his servant in the first year a hen, in the second a cock, goose, goat, cow, horse, .... girl. farmstead.
On Monday they go to mill, etc. (First ed.
Finally foal in mare's belly says her name is "fly".
The suitor sent from one relation to the other for consent to the wedding.
Mosquito, toad, ant, etc. volunteer to supply the wedding feast.
Animals one by one join the procession. The funeral carriage breaks down or the procession drowns.
(Der Tod des H'hnchens.) The cock chokes and the hen seeks aid of objects and persons (stream, tree, pig, miller, baker, etc.).
She is characteristically mourned by objects and animals; e.g., flea, door, broom, cart, ashes, tree, girl.
Each act of mourning described by a neologism: the table untables itself.

Various animals pass by and propose marriage. She asks what they do at night. Each one replies with its characteristic sound, and none pleases her but the quiet little mouse, whom she marries. She leaves him to tend the stew, and he falls in and drowns. She weeps and, on learning the reason, bird cuts off its beak, dove cuts off its tail, etc. (First ed.
She begs off; he goes to kill rooster .... goose, rabbit, toad, tiger.
But who is Tulsi Das? The report is traced back to the washerman, who says: "He was my ass."
(Members of the chain not interrelated.)
A woman makes a pancake, which flees. Various animals try in vain to stop it. Finally the fox eats it up.

While the mistress is away, the cat eats the porridge, the bowl, and the ladle. When the mistress returns she says, "How fat you are!" The cat: "I ate the porridge, the bowl, and the ladle, and I will eat you." The cat meets other animals and eats them after the same conversation. Finally eats too many.
Good morning. "Why are you up so early?" "I am not up so early. I have drunk seven vats of milk and eaten seven plates of porridge and I shall eat you." She ate the pig.

A troll eats the watcher's five horses and finally the watcher himself. The master goes to investigate. The troll: "I ate the five horses, I ate the watcher, and I will eat you." Does so. Likewise the wife, servant, daughter, son, and dog. The cat scratches the troll open and rescues all.
Likewise louse eats loaf of bread, she-goat, cow, buffalo, five sepoys, wedding procession with one lakh of people, elephant, tank of water. A sepoy cuts louse in two with his sword and rescues all.

By his singing the wolf compels the old man to surrender his cattle, his children and grandchildren, and finally his wife. The old woman goes in the wolf's service. She returns home bringing butter, etc.
One animal after another tries in vain to persuade the goat to go home. Finally a wolf (bee) bites him and drives him home.

Final formula: The devil goes to strangle the Jew, the Jew to kill the ox, the ox to drink the water, the water to quench the fire, the fire to burn the stone, the stone to blunt the axe, the axe to cut the rope, the rope to tie the hunter, the hunter to shoot the goat the goat leaves the hazel bush, the wee goat leaves the hazel bush.
His beak and tail alternately stick. (Endless.)
In the fields. What have you in your beak? A knife. etc. (Tile, water, ox, firewood, old woman, friars, mass, shirt.)
A large turnip etc.
To eat seed. The owner will scold you. I'll sit on a pine tree, etc.

Sorrowing over this mishap, all show extraordinary behavior; the master puts an end to it. Final formula: hen strips off feathers, rubbish heap catches fire, oak falls to ground, hare drowns self, magpie twists leg, ox breaks horns, river flows blood, maid breaks pails, housewife scatters dough. Master locks up wife and maid, goes to seek people more foolish.
All refuse. Panther comes and devours her.
Clod fish cakes kid goat drum girl. Girl kills mouse accidentally.

LOCATIONS: Africa, France, India, Indonesia, Jamaica, Rhodesia, Spain
REFERENCES: Africa (Benga), India, Indonesia, Jamaica, Missouri French, Spanish
DESCRIPTION: Her pig will not jump over the stile so that she can go home. She appeals in vain for help until the cow gives her milk. The final formula is: cow give milk for cat; cat kill rat; rat gnaw rope; rope hang butcher; butcher kill ox; ox drink water; water quench fire; fire burn stick; stick beat dog; dog bite pig; pig jump over stile. (Various introductions.)
Recovery chain (similar to +Z41).
Asks water; water must first have horn from stag, who must first have milk from cow, etc.
Wind obeys and breaks the chain.

The cat bites off the mouse's tail and will return it in exchange for milk. The mouse goes to the cow for milk, the farmer for hay, the butcher for meat, the baker for bread. Other persons mentioned are the locksmith and the miner.
Series of helpers similar to +Z41.4.

Cupboard did not wish to give bread unless I gave it a key; smith, charcoal; charcoal-burner, calf's legbone; butcher, milk; cow, grass; meadow, water; clouds, dove's feather. Dove gave me a feather which I gave to clouds, etc.

She goes to carpenter, king, queen, who refuse to help. She asks snake to bite queen, stick to beat snake, fire to burn stick, etc. Final formula: cat eats mouse, mouse cuts plant creeper, creeper snares elephant, elephant drinks up sea, sea quenches fire, fire burns stick, stick beats snake, snake bites queen, queen speaks to king, king chides carpenter, carpenter cuts mill handle, and pea is extracted. Questions in rhyme.

Final formula: at last creeper took pity on birds, and elephant feared creeper, and ocean feared elephant, and fire feared ocean, and stick feared fire, and snake feared stick, and carpenter feared snake; and carpenter split post which gave up the grain to the birds, who went away.

Final formula: the worms begin to gnaw the rods, the rods to beat the oxen, the oxen to drink the water, the water to quench the fire, the fire to burn the hunters, the hunters to shoot the wolves, the wolves to kill the goats, the goats to gnaw the wormwood, the wormwood to rock me   it rocked and rocked me to sleep.

Final formula: That was just what the cat was waiting for it sprang to devour the mouse, the mouse to tear the spider's web, the spider to entangle the dog, the dog to eat the goat, the goat to gnaw the rushes, the rushes to grow in the stream, the stream to quench the fire, the fire to burn the stone, the stone to beat the axe, the axe soon pulled out the needle that was stuck in the seamstress's hand.

Lentils, lentils, get into my sack! Final formula: the hungry hawk attacks the hens, the hens the worms, the worms the stick, the stick the ox, the ox runs to the water, the water attacks the fire, the fire the hunters, the hunters the wolf, the wolf the goat, the goat the willow, the willow the cat, the cat the mice, the mice the lentils, the lentils go whoosh whoosh into the sack.

REFERENCES: Africa (Ekoi), Stiefel Zs. f. Vksk. India
DESCRIPTION: The frost-bitten foot. Mouse perforates wall, wall resists wind, wind dissolves cloud, cloud covers sun, sun thaws frost, frost breaks foot.
At nightfall Abraham worships a star, then the moon, then the sun, and finally gives up idolatry.

Rat devours offerings and he sets it up as his idol as a being more powerful than his idol. When cat devours rat, he worships it instead. His wife accidentally kills the cat, so he sets her up to worship. He happens to slap her and she loses consciousness. Thereafter he worships himself as most powerful after all.

A mouse throws a nut down and hits the cock on the head. He also steals the cock's whiskers. The cock goes to get an old woman to cure him. The final formula is: Fountain give up water for forest, forest give up wood for baker, baker give up bread for dog, dog give up hairs to cure the cock. (Variant: mouse loses tail.)

Magpie refuses, saying it might break its beak. Toad promises, if that happens, to get a horsehair to tie it up again. Magpie throws chestnut and breaks beak. Toad asks ass for hair, but ass first demands grass; mower demands sheep; shepherd, pup; mother dog, bread; baker, stumps. Toad cuts the stumps and gets the hair.

The cock blames the hazel bush for tearing its knickers, the hazel bush the goat for gnawing at it, the goat the shepherd-boy for not tending it, the boy his mistress for not baking him a bun, the mistress the pig for eating up the dough, the pig the wolf for killing its young.
He sends the hen to tell the duck, the duck to tell the goose, etc. Final formula: Fox, who told you? Hare. Hare, who told you? Goose, etc.

Rooster kills beetle; cat kills rooster; dog kills cat; leopard kills dog; hyena kills leopard; buffalo kills hyena; elephant kills buffalo, and lion chases elephant so that both fall into trap. Man calls wives to see meat he has killed.

Final formula: This is the farmer that sowed the corn that fed the cock that crowed in the morn, that waked the priest all shaven and shorn, that married the man all tattered and torn, that kissed the maiden all forlorn, that milked the cow with a crumpled horn, that tossed the dog, that worried the cat, that caught the rat, that ate the malt that lay in the house that Jack built.

The woman for whom he is to build the house has some beans for him. The goat eats these up. Cumulative search. Final formula: Smith give me my iron, iron which belongs to the man, man who ate up my fish, fish which belongs to the sea .... sea shirt washerwoman soap woman wood   press   grease   herder   cheese-frame   fig-tree  horn goat beans.
For want of a nail the shoe was lost, for want of a shoe the horse was lost, for the want of a horse the rider was lost .... and all for the want of a horseshoe nail.

REFERENCES: . f. Vksk. Lithuanian, India, Russian, Spanish Exempla
DESCRIPTION: The magpie is dead. Overate on horseflesh. Horses dead? Overworked at fire. House burned down? etc. (First ed.
Fox sings formula of exchanges.
I killed a priest because he said my crime was bad. A friar absolved me to avoid being killed."
Boys get help. One of them injures the helper. Pursued. Hidden by kind hen. One injures the hen. Hen pursues, etc. (First ed.
Carpenter, please pare off a little flesh from my ribs. Refused. Final formula: the scythe cuts the creeper loose.

A man catches a mango-bird eating mangoes and strikes it against the roots of a mango-tree. The bird cannot be made to say it suffers from the blow. In turn, he puts it in water, strikes it on the ground, a stile, a door-frame, singes its feathers, cuts it up, cooks it, and eats it. The bird always expresses indifference in a cumulative rhyme. At last the bird asks him to look out of the window, whereupon it flies out of his nose and the man dies.
At last: "Shall I tell it again?"
The fire burned it down. Where is the fire? The water quenched it.
The cock snatched it. "Where is that cock?" "He drowned in the sea." "Where is that sea?" "It is grown over with reeds." "Where are those reeds?" "The maids have cut them down", etc.
The farmer explained to him how bread is made. He keeps on asking: "Shall I then be able to eat?" Decides he will not have enough patience to make bread.

Deer steps on kitten: cat investigates. Deer has been frightened by bird, this bird by another bird .... by crab's pointed claw, crab by mouse in his hole. Cat eats mouse. (Frog croaks because turtle carries his house on his head; turtle carries house because firefly is bringing fire; firefly brings fire because mosquito tries to bite him, etc.) (First ed.

He cuts down a big bamboo; a fruit falls from bamboo and strikes a bird on the nape of the neck; the bird scratches up an ant's nest with his feet; the ant bites a wild boar in the eye; and the boar bears down upon a plantain tree where a bat dwells under a leaf; the bat seeks refuge in the ear of an elephant, and the elephant kicks down the house on an old woman. She rushes out and falls into a well.
Beetle bites calf, calf bites cow, cow hoofs carpenter, carpenter beats wife, hunters save carpenter's cow, carpenter releases birds.
Final formula: Forester attacks bear, the bear the wolf, the wolf the dog, the dog the cat, the cat the mouse, the mouse the grain the grain is bitten in two.

Final formula: The mouse holds onto the cat, the cat holds onto Mary, Mary holds onto Annie, Annie holds onto grandmother, grandmother holds onto grandfather, grandfather holds onto the turnip they all pull and pull it out.
Man takes eagle home.
(One person blames another who blames another, etc.) India:
Finally the king finds out that the sea is guilty. (The chain: mason cement mixer beautifully singing woman pearl necklace jeweller diver sea.)
Suit against owner for dangerous wall.
She swallows a spider to eat up the fly, a bird to eat up the spider, a dog to eat the bird, a cow to eat the dog. "The little old lady swallowed a horse she died, of course."
That is too bad. That is not bad at all, my wife burned it down. That is good. That is not good, etc. (First ed.

Builds cart, yokes frogs to it, arms himself with piece of reed, and proclaims war with king. Collects cat, ants, rope, club, and river. He is put by king into fowl house; cat eats up fowls. In stable rope and club beat up horses. In elephant-house ants get into their brains and kill them all. Tied to king's bed, river floods king in his bed. King gives bird back his mate.

REFERENCES: Wesselski Hessische Bldtter f. Vksk. Antigua (British West Indies)

REFERENCES: Gittee Zs. f. Vksk. Irish myth, India, Jewish, West Indies
DESCRIPTION: Various ways of expressing this idea. When black sheep turn white, when a dry branch sprouts, etc.
Till Ogham and pillar be blent together, till heaven and earth, till sun and moon be blent together.
A day and a night.
If person says he has gone to Butterby Church, he has not gone to church.
Hero marries his first sweetheart according to the proverb that the old key is better than the new.
When explanation of phenomenon is asked, three explanations are offered of which the last is always the true one.
Often from blood on snow as a suggestion, a wish is made for a child (wife) with skin like snow and cheeks like blood, etc. (Sometimes black as a raven.)
Usually applied to the cheeks, skin, and hair of a girl's lover.
These crow at dawn and scatter ghosts.

DESCRIPTION: Conventional ending of a story.
I'll huff and I'll puff till I blow your house in.
While he is bound no one can die.
Wanting to have nothing to do with a court, the wind generously makes good the damages, and punishes the judge guilty of bribery.
Depreciated, takes revenge by becoming colder; praised, makes reward, gives clothing.
She supposes he has died.
Various figures employed to show it is not good for one warrior alone to fight the battles of a host.
Message delivered by means of the fingers, etc.
Witch, aided by dragon (lion) is vanquished by maiden, aided by lamb (ram). Witch is devil; maiden, church of Christ.

REFERENCES: N. A. Indian, Oceanic, S. A. Indian (Bakuiri)
DESCRIPTION: Of brothers (sometimes twins taken from body of slain mother) one is abandoned and becomes wild. Later he joins his brother.
Brothers deliberately seek dangers they have been warned against. Triumph.
Seven mothers each with a child imprisoned. Six eat their children to keep from starving. Seventh does not. He rescues all the mothers and becomes hero.
